> Chersonesan Studies http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu A digital companion and data publication to accompany the series of publications of ICA work at Chersonesos in Crimea Wed, 29 Jul 2020 14:11:39 +0000 en-US 1.2 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu 3 arabinow@utexas.edu Adam Rabinowitz 5 colezorz@gmail.com< ![CDATA[Zachary Cole]]> Zachary Cole 6 bullionst@gmail.com Trent Bullion 7 rachel.prichett@gmail.comRachel Prichett 13 bzstratnarrative BZ Stratigraphic narrative Documentation of excavations at the site of Bezymyannaya in the chora of Chersonesos 2 srstratnarrative SR Stratigraphic narrative The synthetic narrative account of the stratigraphic record recovered from excavations in the South Region of the urban center of Crimean Chersonesos (http://pleiades. stoa.org/places/226564), 2001-2006, from topsoil down. This narrative was constructed during post-excavation study from notebooks, graphic documentation, and database records. The current written version was begun in the fall of 2014. It takes the forms of text chunked by room (of the final Byzantine building, our smallest spatial unit for recording purposes) and phase, so that the reader can construct a customized narrative for a particular area or time-period. The text can also be read as a single continuous narrative. 3 trenchbooks Trench notebooks The faithful, unedited transcriptions of the daily entries in the trench notebooks kept by the field directors and trench supervisors of the South Region excavations, 2004-2006 seasons only. Minor corrections and clarifications have been made, but have been marked as editor's notes. Illustrations and sketches in the notebooks have been described verbally. The original notebooks are also available as PDF documents. 1 uncategorized Uncategorized 9 wood trenchbooks Wood Notebook kept by Sam Wood, Assistant Site Director, 2004 excavation season. 5 2004 74 2016-07-08 12:06:58 0000-00-00 00:00:00 closed closed draft 3 1 nav_menu_item 0 _menu_item_type taxonomy _menu_item_menu_item_parent 0 _menu_item_object_id 8 _menu_item_object category _menu_item_target _menu_item_classes a:1:{i:0;s:0:"";} _menu_item_xfn _menu_item_url _menu_item_orphaned 1467979619 21/6/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=77 Mon, 21 Jun 2004 00:00:24 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=77 Work begins in block 50 – cleaning of grass, loose material over area of 01-02 excavations in preparation for conservation efforts.  Larissa, Jessica, Stuart and I discuss the database, documentation systems.  Context sheets will be filled out in Russian and English (dual recording), data entry/database will be in English.  There is a large quantity of material in the soil of the yard (02) – this is collected and assigned to the cleaning of [ark_link cxt=CH01PA_110]. -- present: Simferopol students, Clay, Shawn, Sam, Allyson, Kate, Alla, Glenn 77 2004-06-21 00:00:24 2004-06-21 00:00:24 closed closed 21604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz Trench notebooks _edit_last 5 22/6/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=85 Tue, 22 Jun 2004 17:00:00 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=85 Cleaning continues – now sections are cleaned and straightened and material eroded from them into the trench is removed. Anton, Andrei and Misha begin to excavate the layer of collapse in room 28; although it was partially excavated in 2002, the remainder is assigned  SR336 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336]) [it has been decided that the letter code for layers will now be “south region”] and photo’d. Context numbers are also assigned to destruction/collapse layers in rooms 32 (SR338) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_338]) and 33 (SR337) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_337]). Tile will be quantified by volume, according to the number of buckets filled for each layer; standard bucket size and shape is a truncated cylinder 93cm [in diameter] at the top and 65.5cm [in diameter] at the bottom, 26cm high (variation in buckets is +/- 10-15%). The number of buckets for each layer will be recorded on its context sheet. Shawn, Clay and Sam begin to excavate SR338 in room 32. The layer of collapse in room 29 (SR339) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_339]) also begins to be excavated; a baulk is left approximately 80cm from the NW wall of the room to provide an internal section. The layers of collapse extend to a greater depth than it initially appeared. An interlude of excavation with trowels is followed by a return to large picks. At [p. 4] the same time, work begins on the NW extension of the trench. Topsoil is assigned the same number it bore during the 2001 excavations (PA001) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_1]) and excavated to a depth of 5-10cm. By the end of the day, only small areas at each end of the NW extension have been removed. A conversation about small finds results in a change of the small-find identification and recording system. Larissa and I agree that glass should be treated collectively by layer, with the exception of diagnostic pieces. Nails and undifferentiated metal objects will also be treated as groups [after conversation with conservators, this was later revised to the collective treatment of nails only, with all other metal objects treated as special finds], although here we will attempt a compromise between the preservation of information and the time-consuming work of small-find recording. Each nail will still be mapped with the total station, and a short list of characteristics (mostly binary – short/long, round head/square head etc.) entered into the data collector. These nails, however, will no longer be treated as individual small finds.  This shift will take effect on Wednesday 23/6 [several nails prior to this date were treated as small finds, according to the previous system]. 85 2004-06-22 17:00:00 2004-06-22 17:00:00 closed closed 22604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 room 33 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 24/06/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=94 Thu, 24 Jun 2004 00:00:59 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=94 In the NW extension, topsoil continues to be removed. The area along the NE side of the older trench (S corner of the large room/yard in the N corner of the new trench) is overcut during excavation – in addition to topsoil, a certain amount of rubble (mainly disturbed/modern) is also removed. In room 28, cleaning of 340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]) and removal of the remains of 336 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336]) continues. 340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340])  seems to continue from NW to SE, though it slopes down abruptly at the edge of 336 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336]) . In room 32, 338 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_338]) continues to be cleaned from the surface of 341 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]). 341 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]) is an irregular layer with concentrations of roof tiles, especially just to the NE of the stairs. Once cleaned, the layer is photographed (and photographed with [colored] tacks to attempt photogrammetry [via georeferencing]). In room 29, the pit/intrusion is defined and cleaned. The pebbly loose fill (342) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_342]) is photographed and drawn by Dyma and Sasha; it is then sectioned and excavated in part, and the profile is drawn. It is likely to be a root disturbance – the remaining portion (if it was originally deeper and the upper portion was not initially noted during excavation) is very shallow. A layer of tile collapse is visible below. 94 2004-06-24 00:00:59 2004-06-24 00:00:59 closed closed 240604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 5 25/06/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=99 Fri, 25 Jun 2004 00:00:29 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=99 In the NW extension, excavation of topsoil continues. In room 28, layer 340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]) continues to be cleaned.  It varies in color from a lighter ashy gray to a dark gray-brown, but both consistency (soft but compact, slightly clayey) and inclusions (much charcoal, some small rocks, bones) are more or less the same across the layer. There is a concentration of bone of various large ruminants located roughly 1m from the NW wall, about equidistant from the SW and NE walls. There is also a pile of yellowish compact soil (SR347) ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_347]) in the area of the doorway; it appears to cover 340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]). [p. 9: sketch plan of SR340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]), SR347 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_347]), and area of bones in room 28; sketch plan at roughly 1:50 of pile of apparent in situ tile collapse in room 32] [p. 10] In rm 32, the area to the NE is cleaned and the remaining SR338 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_338]) removed in an attempt to clarify the nature of the line of stones tentatively identified as a wall along the NE side of the room. Excavation is a bit aggressive, but for the most part the soil removed seems to be consistent with 338 in the rest of the room. In rm 29, another disturbance (or the lower part of a disturbance) appears in the E corner of the room. It is filled with a soft, loose, dark brown soil with very few rocks and almost no ceramic material (SR344 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_344]), filling SR345 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_345])). After a moment in which the base of a pot was mistaken (by me) for the base of a[n artillery] shell, the intrusion began to seem life another root or animal disturbance. In the rest of the room, 339 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR])continued to be removed from a thick layer of tile collapse. 99 2004-06-25 00:00:29 2004-06-25 00:00:29 closed closed 250604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 26/06/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=107 Sat, 26 Jun 2004 00:00:29 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=107 The rest of 347 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_347]) is removed in room 28 – it seems to run very deep in the area of the threshold of the door in the NE wall, but a clear bottom and edges are identified in the area within the room. The layer plan is completed in preparation for excavation. In room 32, we begin to excavate SR341 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]) – ten cm. pass with heavy picks, starting from the SW side of the room, along the stairs. There is a pile of tiles against the SE wall of the room, about 30cm from the lowest riser of the stairs into yard 1 (photographed as a detail and put on a sketch plan here and on the cxt sheet, since in the middle of the layer of collapse). There are also several more fragments of carbonized wood, shot in as “other finds” and conserved. In room 29, the remainder of 339 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_339]) is removed.  The [p. 11: sketch of base stolen from SR339 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_339]), bottom view and profile with dimensions; sketch of the final appearance of SR340 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]) in room 28; outline of SF2137 ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2137]), bronze coin] [p. 12] base we mistook for a shell yesterday was stolen during the night – Dyma thought it might happen, but I left it as an experiment.  It was the flat base of a jar or amphora/pithos, about 12cm in diameter with walls preserved for another 5cm or so around it (see sketch opposite). Mosaic photos are taken for photogrammetry, which seems to work – so this layer is removed without afield drawing. All tiles and fragments are kept to be sorted for type and stamps. The tiles from the group in rm 32 are also kept for further study – many whole or nearly whole examples. In room 28, the area of stones along the NW wall is determined to be a new layer – SR349 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_349]) –perhaps filling a pit or area of root disturbance. 107 2004-06-26 00:00:29 2004-06-26 00:00:29 closed closed 260604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 5 28/06/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=110 Mon, 28 Jun 2004 00:00:20 +0000 cole_z http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=110 In room 32, 341  ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]) continues to be excavated. In its lower reaches are more charcoal inclusions, tiles, and at least one chunk of yellow clay that might represent unbaked mudbrick or perhaps the sealing layer of a ceiling or roof. The surface below ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_354]) seems relatively consistent and hard-packed, but is not level – slopes down from SW to NE. The NE wall of the room is uncovered on both faces, but a layer of collapse over the N end has a large number of voids between stones, and there is a strong possibility that the area between this wall and the NE section has been subject to modern disturbance to deep levels. In room 29, a confusion is resolved – the layer of tile over the room (348 [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_348]) was treated as 339 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_339]) on Saturday and this morning. Today’s bags are corrected; Saturday’s will be dealt with in the pot shed. There seems to be a layer of soft, compact greenish-gray soil similar to 341 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]) under the tile layer; it also has tiles lying flat over it, but somewhat more charcoal and several large fragments of pottery, including a pithos apparently broken in situ against the W corner of the section and the SW wall. It is cleaned and will be photographed; drawing will probably be digitization from a georeferenced photo mosaic. Examination of the finds [from this room] shows joins across 348 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_348]) and 351 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_351]) – I think that the latter is likely to have been a lower layer of 348 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_348]), distinguished simply on the basis of a series of lower tiles in flatter positions. 110 2004-06-28 00:00:20 2004-06-28 00:00:20 closed closed 280604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 5 29/6/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=122 Tue, 29 Jun 2004 00:00:05 +0000 arabinow http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=122 Topsoil cleaning continues in the NE extension – several paths [p. 16] have been left for barrows but will be removed when work ends in the three rooms currently under excavation. In rooms 32 and 29, the lower layers of tile collapse are cleaned off to reveal beaten-earth floors with some vessels broken in situ.  The roof or ceiling composition is very well represented – apart from tiles, there are quantities of sea-grass, apparently used as fill or insulation, and large spots of yellow pebbly clay, perhaps also sealant.  A sample of sea-grass is saved.  In room 32, there is also a lump of clay with a corroded mass of metal on top of it (lifted as a group and sent to conservation). In room 29, [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_351] comes down onto a hard-packed surface, as in room 32, on which sit a large number of articulated vessels apparently broken in situ.  The remainder of [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_351] (also containing large quantities of sea-grass) is removed and the vessels cleaned to be photo’d for georeferencing, A large flat stone on the floor of 32, in the E corner, is removed initially as part of the collapse.  It becomes clear, however, that it sat directly on the floor and was covered by the tile fall, and so is put back into position (with precision, since a ridge on the bottom matches a dip in the floor surface). Some confusion in rm 28 – along the NE side of the room, the soil has a yellower tinge.  After some discussion, we decide that it is still a part of [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340], with inclusions from more friable stones.  It may be that the yellow is in fact part of or related to [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_349], but if so the relationship has already been seriously confused and the finds contaminated.  Material is kept as [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340]. [p. 18] Rm 28, burnt layer [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_352] finally cleaned and drawn (some irregularities – doesn’t cover whole area of room). In situ pots removed from the floor of rm 32. In situ pots in rm 29 cleaned for georef[erencing] photo; there were 4 coins ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2146], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2147], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2157], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2160]) found just over the floor in this room, as well as a nearly-intact green-glaze jug ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2158]) and a number of pithoi/coarse jars. Conservators deal with large chunks of burnt wood [in room 28] in an effort to preserve them intact. 122 2004-06-29 00:00:05 2004-06-29 00:00:05 closed closed 29604 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 23/6/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=136 Wed, 23 Jun 2004 00:00:23 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=136 Stable teams are established: Shawn will deal with documentation for NW extension, working with Glenn, Kate, Allyson, Misha and Yuri. Clay will take care of documentation for rooms 28, 29 and 32 (Anja, Alla, Genya; Sasha and Dyma; and Anton, Andrei, and Karina, respectively). Sam will assign context numbers and keep the register. In room 28, collapse [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336] is excavated for a short time, but then we turn to the definition of the relationship between the gray ashy layer at the SW end of the room [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340] and the collapse. [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_340] appears to fall off steeply and [p. 6] is covered by [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336]. The limit of [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336] is irregular – about 50cm from the all in the W corner, about 1.2m in the S corner. Once the boundary between the layers is defined, [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336] will continue to be removed, starting from the SW. In room 32, the collapse seems to be coming down on a layer of tile collapse, albeit a poorly defined one. The collapse produces several articulated sherds/vessel fragments and a number of nails (shot in according to the new system, although a context # code was not added until mid-morning). The area of the door between 32 and 29 is determined to be collapse, not blocking, and is excavated as [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_338]. A grindstone appears in the S corner of the room. In room 29, there seems to be a disturbed area in the center of the room (pebbles and lots of snails [i.e. land snail shells], perhaps indicating a void or loose fill). Preliminary examination suggests a modern pit, especially since a piece of modern fabric [this may actually have been root material] was extracted from the soil. The room is cleaned in an attempt to define the edge of the pit. In the NW extension, removal of topsoil continues. Finds include much modern material, among which fragments of a Nazi porcelain plate [Bayern maker’s stamp with swastika and eagle wings]. The tops of the walls visible in the 2002 trench appear along the same line. Rm 32, layer [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_338] produces a grindstone at the corner of the steps up into yard 1. It is not clear if it is in situ, on supports of convenient stones, or part of the general collapse. In room 28, layer slopes steeply down below [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_336], which continues to be removed. In room 29, the edges of the intrusion in the center of the room are defined, to be cleaned, photographed and drawn tomorrow. 136 2004-06-23 00:00:23 2004-06-23 00:00:23 closed closed 23604-2 private 0 0 post 0 2004 modern Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 30/6/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=145 Wed, 30 Jun 2004 00:00:11 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=145 Room 32 has been finished.  The floor of room 29 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_364]) is cleaned; there may be a ring of stones (perhaps to support the base of the pithos collapsed in situ in this area).  The cleaning of this floor goes a bit deep toward the section left in place; in that area a coin ([ark_link sf=CH04SR_2162]) is found. Dyma excavated it and is sure that it formed part of the surface deposit ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_355]) on the floor of the room, but it is also possible that the coin was in the fabric of the floor (possible dating element for floor construction). Excavations of topsoil and modern fill in NE extension continues; barrow paths begin to be removed.  In NW extension, we begin to remove collapse in small room 30 [there must be some confusion in my notebook here – 31 is the small room – but the context numbers seem to be accurate] ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_358]) and in rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359] – both these layers will be combined with equivalent layers from 2000-2002). There is an infant or fetus deposition ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_360]) in the S corner of rm 28, apparently placed in a shallow cut ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_361]) through the floor and perhaps through bedrock. The floor may actually have been overexcavated in that area, so there is some question about the phasing of this deposition – was it pre-floor in association with the church, or was it cut into the floor after the room was built and used? [after going back and forth on the stratigraphy here several times, my feeling as of 11 July is that the grave was cut through floor and destruction layers after the abandonment of the house – see below] [p. 20] The bones are not in good order and the body is only partially complete – preservation is further compromised by the fact that someone came last night and dug up and disturbed several parts of the skull. The fill of the tomb is a soft dark gray-brown soil with large inclusions of bedrock fragments and charcoal ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_360]). The deposition is cleaned and photographed.  At the same time, the stones placed over the floor of the church are removed in preparation for the excavation of tomb 2. Increasing rain, however, cuts the excavation day short. We have a short presentation of the data collecting system at Dacha 1 and then stop for the day. 145 2004-06-30 00:00:11 2004-06-30 00:00:11 closed closed p-19 private 0 0 post 0 2004 chapel Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 31 room 32 tomb 2 Trench notebooks _edit_last 6 1/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=153 Thu, 01 Jul 2004 00:00:09 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=153
The modern intrusions and disturbances in the NE extension continue to be removed; in some areas, intact stone collapse is beginning to appear.  In the NW extension, collapse begins to be removed by room – in room 30, SR358 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_SR358]), and in room 31, SR359 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_ SR359]).  SR358 [ ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_SR359] ) is meant here – in the notebook I’ve confused the two rooms in this and the previous entry] comes down onto a layer of collapsed tiles and includes part of a small stone column found lying on its side (Larissa notes that such column frags are often used as benches in streets and alleys – was 30 [again, 31] originally an alley or an ambitus?).
The cleaning and removal of the remaining pithos fragments composing SR355 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_SR355]) reveal a ring of stones acting as a pithos stand and, next to it, another intact green-glaze jug.  Work then ceases in this area.
The cut ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_361]) for the infant burial in rm 28 is cleaned.  A fragment of burnt glass (lamp handle?) is found in the W end; in the same area, there is a roughly circular patch of charcoal, apparently predating the burial.
[the following four pages have fallen out of the notebook and are kept in an associated folder]
[p. 22]
1/7 continued
Various walls appear in rooms 30 and 31.  The rear (NW) wall of 30 is very clear, and there seems also to be a rear wall for 31, somewhat further to the NW.  There is a debate about a layer of collapse with intact tiles close to the lower surface of 31 – initially it is considered to be different from the collapse above ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_358]), but it is subsequently decided that it is simply a lower level of the same (and the georeferencing photo should be viewed from this perspective).

The NE and NW extensions now have enough visible walls to be divided into rooms.  In rooms 30 and 31, work continues; in 30, the collapse of large stones ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_358]) seems to come down onto a collapse composed of tiles and smaller stones.  In room 31, a NW wall seems to have been identified – but as I’m writing, it appears to turn into the stone base for a flight of stairs. In new rooms 35 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_374]) and 36 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]), modern disturbance seems to come down, across an uncertain interface, onto rubble collapse.  The modern disturbance is quite deep in many places. [p. 24] 2/7 cont. In room 28, the area of burnt beams in the N corner of the room is fully cleaned and georeferencing photos are taken.  Allyson also draws a sketch plan on which 11 different beams or sections of beams are labeled, to facilitate drawing; then each of those eleven pieces are given “other find” shots from the total station.  Samples will be taken and identified by the total station point number, which will then also be written on the sample packaging.  Along the SE wall, the layer of hard-packed smooth soil below 352 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_352]) is overexcavated, resulting in an artificial depression which should be ignored in the total station topo map of the floor.  There is an articulated brown-glazed juglet in pieces through the collapse; total station point for the small find is taken on the two largest pieces.  Preparation is made for the sample pieces of wood to be lifted. In the church, Renata H. begins to excavate – but before she can get to the tomb, she starts to unearth the bodies belonging to two small skulls visible in the upper level of the soil of the church.  The area in which these bodies are buried, although it lacks clear limits (the church in general was disturbed by a modern bomb), is defined as Grave 1 (to distinguish it from the built tombs 1 and 2).  The skeletons are a child of ca. 4 yrs (#1) and a fetus or neonate (#2). 157 2004-07-02 00:00:18 2004-07-02 00:00:18 closed closed 2704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 chapel modern Rabinowitz room 28 room 30 room 31 room 35 room 36 tomb 2 Trench notebooks _edit_last 6 3/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=160 Sat, 03 Jul 2004 00:00:45 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=160 In room 31, where what appears to be a surface level has been reached in the rectangular area the room was originally thought to occupy, two things become clear.  One is the base of a staircase, apparently ascending to the SE.  The other is the fact that there is no wall after the N corner of room 30.  As a result, we decide to continue to remove the [p. 25: small sketch of hypothetical reconstruction of structural arrangements in room 28 –shed-roofed wooden structure over the basin, the rest of the room unroofed] [p. 26] layer of collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359]) as it extends to the NW of room 30. In room 28, the layer of burnt wood ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_352]) continues to be cleaned, with some larger pieces left in situ on piers for possible conservation.  Finds this morning included a gold teardrop-shaped earring or piece of jewelry.  Part of the floor seems to be paved, and given the fragility of the bedrock basin and the quantity of burnt wood (and small quantity of tile), Sam and Larissa and I agree that this room may have been roofed only partially (see sketch opposite).  After the newly cleaned areas (and new beams) are photographed, the conservators arrive to begin the lifting process. In room 36, what we thought to be a layer of intact collapse is reassessed – now we’re convinced it’s modern fill, and we remove it down to the layer of yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]) already visible on the NE side of the NE wall of rm 32. In room 31, in the area behind rm 30, soil shows signs of modern disturbance.  The remaining collapse in 30 comes down onto a layer of tile and roof collapse (SR369 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_369]) ) – cleaned and photographed.
