In room 28, the remains of SR352 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_352]) are removed. Under one of the beam concentrations, there are a large number of small slag or iron fragments – they seem to be associated with those recorded as small find 2201 ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2201]). In room 29, the soil left to form a section along the NW wall is removed, context by context. In the church, work continues on tomb 2.  All non-bone non-ceramic objects from the fill – SR362 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_362]) – will be recorded as special finds; today, this begins with a nail.  Note the exception to our standard recording conventions [the same applies to glass fragments]. In room 30, SR369 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_369]) is drawn – due to some confusion, part of it was slightly excavated, so the W and N ends will have to be reconstructed.  There is a roughly circular cut at the W end, about 15cm in diameter; the bottom is especially hard-packed and along its edge (and in its fill, not recorded at the [time] of exc. but assigned SR370 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_370]) after the fact) are fragments of wood, apparently not [p. 30] 5/7 cont. belonging to roots.  It seems likely that this cut (SR371 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_371]) ) was a post-hole associated with some later (18th-19th c?) event, and that it began further up in SR358 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_358]) and was missed during excavation.  The wood, in particular, seems too well-preserved to be very old, but the compaction of the bottom surface is difficult to ignore.  It might also explain the presence of a modern hinge and hasp found in 358 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_358]) in roughly that area during excavation a few days ago. In rm 36, what appears to be a modern nail is found among the lower levels of the area we are interpreting as modern fill – shot in as a nail and saved in a nail bag. In rm 31, excavation of SR359 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359]) NW of rm 30 continues – consistent layer of loose dark brown soil with tile and large stones.  The SW wall of this room has appeared – it is badly damaged and bowed to the NE. [there follows a paragraph I wrote at a point when I thought the four loose pages had been lost, crossed out when I found them after all] [p. 32] 162 2004-07-05 00:00:17 2004-07-05 00:00:17 closed closed 5704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 modern Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 30 room 31 room 32 room 36 tomb 2 Trench notebooks _edit_last 6 6/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=165 Tue, 06 Jul 2004 00:00:43 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=165 The lowest layer of collapse (SR355 ([ark_link cxt:CH04SR_355]) ) in rm 29 is removed; in the W corner is another pithos stand, and various sherds of the pithos that stood in it are found. One is saved with the soil in it still intact, for potential residue analysis.  When the floor is clean, the remaining topographical points are taken and documentary photos done. In room 31, a new wall emerges – it runs from the middle of the door in the NW wall of rm 30 [later determined to run from the corner of the door, though some projection into the door] to the wall along the NW boundary of the NW extension.  It is built in fairly careless masonry and seems clearly to be a later addition.  The collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359]) covers it and descends on both sides to a deeper level; it still seems to be consistent, although in the S corner of the space NW of room 30 is loose and very soft – possibly soil disturbed by animal burrowing. In room 30, Anton and Taras continue to excavate 369 ([ark_link cxt:CH04SR_369]), removing it from a soft gray-brown layer, compact but friable, that probably represents the abandonment of the room (SR378 ([ark_link cxt:CH04SR_378]) ).  In this layer are found a large number of crab remains, as well as some fish bones (in 2002 a large quantity of fish bones were found on this floor).  Some of the crab remains are concentrated in an area just to the SW of the door, next to the wall.  The layer is partially excavated at the N end before it is properly photographed and leveled, but a partial photo and levels to the S are taken. The N end is shallower and comes down onto an area of stones, including one large round stone clearly sitting on the floor. In room 36, the intrusion/pit in the center of the [p. 34] 6/7 cont. room is cleaned and another attempt is made to sort out the situation.  The sandy yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]) still seems to be under the gray-green-brown layer, but voids also appear between rocks in it, and boundaries are unclear.  I’m hoping for intact collapse – perhaps yellow because of the type of soil used as mud mortar in the walls – but I fear that much of the area has been disturbed by modern activity. The possibility of yellow mud mortar – or at least yellow mud pointing – is confirmed today during the cleaning of the walls in room 28 in preparation for drawing.  Sam notices that in the S corner, the soil between the stones is of the same yellow clayey color and consistency, and he also notices that the gaps seem to be pointed and surfaced with what seems essentially to be a mud plaster.  This may explain both the color of the collapse and the general absence of plaster on these walls.  He and I both also note an area where the wall seems to be missing, just to the SE of the bedrock basin.  In the course of further investigation, Sam uncovers what appears to be a small hiding-place for valuables – a deep, slightly irregular hole cut back at a (W-NW) angle into the bedrock under the NW wall of the room and filled with silty brown soil containing, among other things, a fragment of 12th-13th century Syrian blue-glazed pot.  The hole is empty and the wall was not built back up over it, so it seems likely that if anything was hidden there, the occupants removed it shortly before [p. 35: sketch of the first layer of full depositions in t. 2 in the church, with skeleton numbers] [p. 36] or at some point after the abandonment of the room/building.  The stratigraphic relationships in this corner are unfortunately unclear, due to the overcutting mentioned earlier, but the following sequences may be proposed: 1) the hole was opened and filled in gradually, after which point the infant was buried, after which the room burned 2) the room burned, then the hole was opened and filled in gradually, and into the upper layers of destruction that filled the cut [for the hole] the tomb of an infant was cut. The first idea may be supported by the ash level visible on the wall over the level of the infant burial; the second by the likelihood that the higher levels of the infant grave were missed and by the apparent absence of ash or charcoal in most of the fill of the hole.  In addition, for the medieval period, the burial of a newborn child in an abandoned house right next to a (possibly abandoned) church seems more likely than the burial of a newborn in a functioning stable/court/smithy.  The children buried shallowly in the floor of the church may represent the same period of activity. In the church, work continues on t. 2.  The disarticulated bones at the NE end are removed to reveal 3 intact (more or less) depositions – a fourth, belonging to a child, has already been removed.  The numeration of the skeletons, at least as it was assigned in the field, is as in the sketch on the facing page.  [p. 38] 6/7 cont. In room 33, the remainder of SR337 ([ark_link cxt:CH04SR_337]) is removed and the layer beneath cleaned.  Between the two Marina identifies and distinguishes a thin and irregular layer of plaster fragments with a distinct concentration in the N corner of the room (SR375 ([ark_link cxt:CH04SR_375]) ).  It is unclear whether the very fragmentary white plaster represented is modern or medieval. 165 2004-07-06 00:00:43 2004-07-06 00:00:43 closed closed 6704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 byzantine chapel late byzantine Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 30 room 31 room 33 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 6 7/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=167 Wed, 07 Jul 2004 00:00:06 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=167 In room 33, SR380 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_380]) [beneath SR337 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_380]) ] is completely cleaned, photographed, georeference photographed, and topographically mapped (not necessarily an important or intact layer, but seems a good subject for experimentation).  Once done, it begins to be removed from the NE side. In room 36, removal of the brown soil continues – it is decided to take out what appeared to be collapse over the SE wall but which now seems to be further fill related to the pit/disturbance/crater (?) in the center of the room.  There are currently three visible layers –brown fill/collapse [SR376? ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_376]) ], sandy yellow fill/collapse [SR373 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]) ], and an orange clayey layer [later included in the sandy yellow layer] below both.  Our goal today is the removal of the rest of the brown. In room 35, the removal of compact dark brown collapse SR374 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_374]) begins.  The stones in this room are smaller and the soil darker, though Dyma and Sasha feel that the upper levels, at least, are still modern fill. In room 31, the layer of brown rocky collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359]) comes down onto a gray layer ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_386]) with more tiles, ash and charcoal inclusions, and at least one more substantial charred piece of wood.  This layer is cleaned in the area of room 31a. In room 30, the floor of the room is revealed under [p. 39: sketch of t. 2, third level of intact depositions (not to scale) with field numbering of skeletons; sketch of pits and hearth in and on the floor of room 30] [p. 40] the layer of abandonment ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_378]).  At least one fairly certain hole ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_389]) is visible in the W corner of the room; its fill is photographed and removed.  The rest of the room is cleaned; a new context number is given to the hearth, although it had a number two years ago – this will help to keep the finds situation less confusing. In the church, the third layer of bones is reached in tomb 2.  The orientation and numbering of these skeletons is as in the sketch on the facing page.  Layers: #1 had skeletons 1 and 2; 3, 4 and 5 in 2nd layer; 6, 8 in third layer; 7 in 4th layer, probably floor (Denys). 167 2004-07-07 00:00:06 2004-07-07 00:00:06 closed closed 7704 private 0 0 post 0 room 30 room 31 room 31a room 33 room 35 room 36 tomb 2 Uncategorized _edit_last 6 8/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=169 Thu, 08 Jul 2004 00:00:30 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=169 In room 30, Anton cleans the floor ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_378]), including the areas exposed in 2002, and excavates the sediment and erosion material that collected in the pit or depression along the SW wall (excavated partially, or at least identified in 2002).  See sketch opposite for location of this and other pits in this layer. In room 31a, rocky brown collapse SR359 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_359]) is removed; it covers a soft layer of grayer, ashier soil with small to medium charcoal inclusions, a piece of burnt wood, and a fairly large number of tiles ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_386]).  It is separated from its counterpart SR390 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_390]) by a very wide but poorly built wall, preserved only for a few courses and dividing rm 31 into two just to the NE of the door in the NW wall of rm 30. In room 35, the uppermost layer of rocky brown soil (SR374 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_374]) ) begins to be removed.  It seems, from the finds, to represent modern dumping, and it may fill in some pits or depressions in the uneven surface of the layer of collapse (?) below.  Finds include a spherical lead bullet of Crimean War date [or possibly 18th century—Russian bullet of a type standard until after the Crimean War]. In room 36, the loose brown pebbly soil [SR372 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_372])] along the [p. 41: sketch of the situation in rooms 36 and 33, with the large rocks in 33 postulated as an extension of the intrusion in 36; later determined that this situation was unlikely, and the rocks in room 33 probably in situ] [p. 42] NW wall of the room begins to be removed.  It seems to sit on top of the yellow soil with stones, but its relationship to the fill of the disturbance in the center of the room is unclear – they may be the same action, although when the pit was cleared it seemed to have very visible and well-defined edges.  Below this brown (and slightly greenish) soil is a layer of ashier, more compact gray-green soil similar to 341 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_341]) in room 32 (and perhaps equal to it, if it extends across the wall) [later determined to be the same fill as SR372 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_372]) , above the yellow, and removed as such].  The relation of this layer to the yellow layer is also unclear. There is a similar situation in room 33, where the final cleaning of SR375 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_375]) reveals a pinkish-red soil with ash, burnt wood and tile inclusions along both the SW and the NE sides of the room but what seems to be a thicker layer of brown soil and large stones in the center of the room, more or less of the same width as the break in the NW wall of 33.  I am starting to think that the pit/disturbance in rm 36 was much larger than we originally defined it, and that the same action was responsible for the disturbance of rooms 33 and 36, as well as the destruction of the wall. Larisa disagrees – the discussion hinges on the presence or absence of yellow soil over the destroyed part of the wall.  I am relatively certain that brown-green soil covered that area, while she remembers the presence of yellow soil.  Her interpretation would make the yellow later than the destruction of the wall, mine [potentially] earlier (see sketch opposite) [in any case, our final decision was that the yellow postdated the destruction of the wall and that both it and the brown are likely to have been some sort of mixed fill]. Room 28 receives a final cleaning.  The metalworking hearth (SR391 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_391]) ) is roughly circular, with a narrow trail of metal fragments leading away to the N/NE, perhaps representing a flue or bellows-hole.  The surface of the floor seems to be [p. 43: sketch plan of the floor of room 28; sketch of the fifth and final layer of articulated depositions in t. 2 in the church] [p. 44] burnt – or at least exposed to heat – near the door to the street, and there are several large patches of charcoal on the floor in the E quarter of the room (see sketch opposite). A bronze coin is recovered from the fabric of the floor, but is probably Hellenistic or Roman; other material recovered [from the floor] during cleaning suggests a 13th-c. date for the floor. There is no sign of the kiln or oven above the metalworking hearth. As the very bottoms of the walls were cleaned, a number of fragments of charcoal and slag came out, perhaps having been swept or kicked there during the occupation of the room. The floor also seems to contain a number of very, very heavily burnt animal bones – burnt almost to the point of vitrification. The final layer of bones in t. 2 is photographed and removed. There are three articulated skeletons, one of a child and two of infants/toddlers (see sketch opposite). The bottom and lower sides of this grave are formed by cut bedrock. 169 2004-07-08 00:00:30 2004-07-08 00:00:30 closed closed 8704 private 0 0 post 0 13th century 2004 hellenistic modern Rabinowitz roman room 28 room 30 room 31 room 31a room 32 room 33 room 35 room 36 tomb 2 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 9/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=171 Fri, 09 Jul 2004 00:00:16 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=171 In room 31, the lowest layer of tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_386]) is cleaned, revealing a relatively smooth layer that may represent either abandonment or a rough floor level ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_405]).  After that is cleaned and photographed, the corresponding lower level of collapse in room 31a is cleaned.  Since a large number of fish bones appear, and since the room seems to be connected to activity in room 30, we decided to dry-sieve the soil in an effort to capture more evidence. In room 30, Anton S. cleans and excavates the pit along the SW wall of the room – the pit was identified in 2002 but not excavated, and its extent appears not to have been fully identified. [p. 45: sketch plan, not to scale, of SR373 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]) in room 36 and SR401 in room 33] [p. 46] The fill of this pit (SR383 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_383]) ) also contains many fish bones, as well as some relatively large chunks of charcoal or charred wood. In room 35, work continues on the removal of SR374 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_374]) .  Below it is what seems to be an intact layer of rocky collapse over most of the room – but against the NE wall, there is a space of clean soil with very few rocks.  This soil may represent an intrusion, but its relationship with the rocky collapse is not yet clear.  In room 36, the situation continues to be confusing.  The brown green soil ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_372]) is removed, leaving large isolated outcrops of yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_373]); in the W corner, on the other hand, it appears to come down onto a layer of ashy destruction [later determined to be part of the same brown-green-gray layer mentioned above, and demonstrated to cover the yellow soil].  Work slows along the SW wall, since it needs to be propped up to prevent its collapse.  Along its base the layer of tile, ash and burnt wood seems to continue.  Once the brown is largely removed, we also remove the lump of yellow in the S corner.  Despite the color difference, it seems just as loose and disturbed as the brown.  Once it has been taken down to the level of the bottom of the pit, Clay, Anton and Andrei begin to remove the yellow soil in the E corner.  Like that in the S corner, it is extremely loose and friable; but unlike the other outcrop, it contains a large number of carefully worked architectural elements, some with plaster still attached and nails stuck in them. In room 33, the layer of fill/disturbance in the center of the room is removed – although it was initially designated as SR376 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_376]) to match the fill of the pit in room 36, it is subsequently changed to SR401 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_401]) when the quantity of tiles, plaster and charcoal seems to be much greater. [p. 47: elevation sketch of the location of the two cow astragaloi found in what seems to be a deliberate deposit in a hole cut in the bedrock just below the level of the SW wall of room 30] [p. 48] 9/7 cont. SR401 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_401]) is removed; it covers the center and W corner of the room.  Beneath it is a layer of yellow soil (similar to that in 36? But seems more compact) in the W corner and a layer of reddish-brown to pinkish-buff soil with traces of burning in the rest of the room (SR392 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_392]) along the SW side, SR393 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_393]) in the N corner).  Cleaning along the W side of the NW wall reveals a large iron fixture or implement, apparently in situ (photographed).  There also seem to be a number of large pithoi broken in situ in this room; whatever the disturbance in the upper layer, it does not seem to have affected the integrity of the lower levels of collapse. Anton and I consult about the boundaries of the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_389]) along the SW side of room 30; one side is cut into bedrock, but the other seems to take a particularly thick layer of the floor as its limit, and it is difficult in places to distinguish soft fill from soft lower levels of floor fill.  By the end, though, I’m confident that we have the correct limits.  While I’m over there, I notice a fairly regular cavity cut into bedrock where the bedrock terrace intersects the SE wall of room 30, about 40-50cm above the level of the floor.  In cleaning out this cavity or niche in an attempt to identify a possible drain from the courtyard into the pit in room 30, I remove a very soft, very dark brown loamy fill with inclusions of decayed bedrock, a few small pieces of ceramic, and no other finds except for two very large astragaloi, probably from cattle, set side-by-side and level and wedged into the soil of the niche.  By position and arrangement they seem very unlikely to be simple food refuse (see sketch opposite) – good luck charms associated with building? [with reference to this, it should be noted that in the early fill of the pit under the floor of room 36 were several similar astragaloi, which I should interpret as food refuse were it not for the fact that at least one was worked on both sides to flatten it – I don’t know what the explanation for this is].
[p. 50]
171 2004-07-09 00:00:16 2004-07-09 00:00:16 closed closed 9704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 31a room 33 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 6 10/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=173 Sat, 10 Jul 2004 00:00:50 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=173

The day starts with much cleaning.  Room 30 is now done and will await the excavation of the floor.  In room 31a, the layer of abandonment is removed to reveal a hard-packed floor surface in which appear two large, flattish rocks, as well as half of a circular handmill.  The level of the floor here is lower than it is in room 3, and is appropriate for the level of the doorsill.  In the W wing of room 31, a pile of collapse left outside the N corner of 30 is removed and collapsing part of wall propped; the current surface/layer in this area – either the latest, not very compacted surface or a layer of abandonment like that in rm 31a – is removed from a smoother, harder packed layer containing yellow and brown clay.

In room 35, the layer of clean soil at the NE end of the room is found to descend below the rocky collapse over the rest of the room.  That rocky collapse, after a long debate, is judged to be intact collapse rather than modern disturbance and assigned cxt # SR406 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_406]).  It begins to be excavated, rather haphazardly, from the SW end of the room.

In room 36, we finally achieve some clarity.  In removing the modern fill in the doorway in order to better understand the relation between brown and yellow soil, we find underneath both yellow & brown a charred black level, perhaps immediately over the floor.  The sequence seems to be 1) some sort of massive intrusion, 2) yellow fill, 3) brown fill, perhaps in conjunction with a new intrusion.  Newly confident that the yellow is simply fill, we begin to remove it even more aggressively.

In room 33, the removal of the fill (SR401 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_401]) ) of the intrusion [later judged to be intact collapse, probably a better interpretation] in the center of the room reveals – finally –

[p. 52]

10/7 cont. an intact layer of collapse including several iron tools/objects and at least two pithoi crushed in situ.  I’m beginning to wonder if the layer above – previously interpreted as the fill of an intentional pit – was not actually part of the real collapse of the NW wall of the room.  Perhaps the destruction of the wall was not intentional but natural, and the stones fell in a slight depression formed by the slow collapse, along sides and in corners, of the other walls of the room.

In room 36, the loose yellow soil, at a lower level, starts to produce massive amounts of tile. This is very unlike the upper levels of the same soil, which contained more stones and far fewer tile fragments. Most of the tiles are broken into fairly small pieces.

173 2004-07-10 00:00:50 2004-07-10 00:00:50 closed closed 10704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 31a room 33 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 12/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=178 Mon, 12 Jul 2004 00:00:21 +0000 bullion_t http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=178

Rooms 31, 31a and 30 have been cleaned down to floors and are left.  The edge of the NW extension is moved 40cm to the NW in order to clarify the NW face of the NW wall of room 31a.  At the same time, excavation begins in the area of the trench over the N end of courtyard 1.

In room 35, collapse continues to be removed from the smoother, more compact grayish-brown soil already visible at the NE end of the room.  At the SW end of the room, the stony collapse appears to come down onto a layer of intact tile collapse with at least one pithos apparently broken in situ.

In room 36, the yellow soil seems consistently to cover a layer of black ash and burnt material –perhaps intact medieval destruction, perhaps not.  It also becomes clear that

[p. 53: sketch of the bronze wires with hooks at the end, attached to a piece of iron, found in room 36 – initially considered to be modern, as below, but increasingly seeming like an extraordinarily well-preserved example of the hooks from which metal lamps were hung in this period]

[p. 54]

the gray-green-brown soil left as an intact collapse in the NW half of the room is, in fact, more fill that covers the yellow.  The dating of these layers remains unclear, although a thick brick and an oddly smooth and thin piece of glass continue to raise suspicions of a modern fill.

In room 33, the layer of reddish-buff soil along the SW wall is removed.  It contains a large number of nails, most of them along the SW wall – perhaps from a door?  Below it the layer of tile and pottery collapse/destruction (410 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_410]) ) appears to contain a high concentration of burnt wood.

A special find from SR372 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_372]) involves two thick wires with hooks at each end ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2354]); one end is attached to what seems to be part of an iron ring.  It bears a strong resemblance to the attachments for hanging lamps, but the wire is still flexible and only mildly corroded – in addition, surface scratches suggest that it is copper, not bronze.  We suspect 19th-c origins – the preservation simply is too good (see sketch opposite).  13/7: NB, however, that the following day other bronze or copper hooks of similar form and level of preservation are found and seem to Larisa to be from a medieval lamp [and see note for p. 53, above].

178 2004-07-12 00:00:21 2004-07-12 00:00:21 closed closed 12704 private 0 0 post 0 2004 byzantine courtyard Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 31a room 33 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 13/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=195 Tue, 13 Jul 2004 00:00:14 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=195 Room 30 is drawn. An upper layer of collapse continues to be removed from the area of the NW extension that borders courtyard 1; finds include a reused fragment of Roman gravestone ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2358]). In room 31 next to the stairs, Shawn identifies what seems to be an upper floor surface of gravelly, soft but compact gray soil. It may be related to the stairs, also a late construction; the use of space and distribution of covered/uncovered space in that area is unclear, but one might [p. 55: rough sketch indicating the location of SR416 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_416]), the layer discussed above] [p. 56] suggest the latest surface of a narrow uncovered passage providing access to the area under the stairs rising from the alley to the SE. (see sketch, opposite) In room 35, the layer of rocky collapse continues to be removed and the layer of burnt tile collapse below cleaned. The rise in level at the NE end of the room appears to be due to a rise in bedrock, analogous to that in rm 28. Room 36 continues to make explanation difficult. The yellow and brown fills continue to be removed – 372 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_372]) is uppermost and is taken off the yellow below. The yellow lies over a clear layer of burnt material and black ash, but at the same time stones and bedrock projecting from the lower part of the NE wall seem to indicate that we have descended below the level of the original floor – hacked out by whatever post-abandonment activity took place here? [later determined that the final floor was, in fact, at this level; problems with walls still not satisfactorily explained as of 22/7] The burnt material contains fragments of broken pithoi, lying flat; it may represent the base of the cut. Alternatively, there is some slight chance that the line of stones under the NE wall represents an earlier wall at a slightly different orientation – but this seems less likely. All the brown & yellow fill in this room seems, at this point, to have been disturbed – though the almost total lack of dating material is bothersome. The layers of yellow-brown collapse with some large stones in the S corner (SR392 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_392])) and yellow-brown collapse of a slightly drier and more friable consistency (SR393 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_393])) continue to be removed in room 33. More pithoi appear, broken in situ, as well as a number of articulated fragments of coarse and fineware vessels (including a [13th c.] polychrome-ware sherd [from a jug] with a siren or harpy). One of the pithoi in the W corner seems to have burnt organic material and insects in it – will be sampled when Galina Pashkevich comes. [p. 58] With Dana, I remove the soil from the hearth in rm 28. In doing so, I identify two layers of burnt fill; one, the upper, somewhat looser and with a much greater concentration of small pieces of slag; and the other cleaner, more compact with charcoal inclusions and fewer pieces of slag. Only the latter (SR415 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_415])) exists across the whole hearth. The former was partially removed when the conservators removed a piece of intact wood. The hearth is sectioned roughly along that line during excavation, and the section photographed but not drawn. All the soil from the hearth is kept in sample bags, separated according to the two contexts; the largest pieces of slag and the results of magnetic investigations (for hammer scale etc) are bagged separately and taken by Dana to conservation. 195 2004-07-13 00:00:14 2004-07-13 00:00:14 closed closed 13-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz roman room 28 room 30 room 31 room 33 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 _wp_old_date 2018-03-21 14/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=208 Wed, 14 Jul 2004 00:00:20 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=208 In the area of yard 1 included in the NW extension, rubble and collapse/fill continue to be removed, uncovering a new wall half-covered by the SW section wall and what may be another new wall – albeit very strangely wide and very poorly made – running between it and the SW wall of 31a/30 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_31]). There also seems to be a new layer under collapse to the N of the new SW-NE wall: a more compact gray layer with fewer stones, at a higher level than the surface of the courtyard. In room 34/yard 2, the fill of the cistern (?) near the N corner of the 2002 trench is excavated – the second layer of fill is a greenish brown soil with some rocks and varying compaction, perhaps as the result of animal turbation (there seems to be at least one burrow). This soil covers a hardpacked tan soil along the N side that seems to be some [p. 59: rough diagram of the burned areas visible on the inside of the pithos sherds from the vessel broken in situ in room 35]  [p. 60] sort of deliberate step or platform. The green-brown soil contains many animal and fish bones and a partially intact flat-bottomed coarseware jug. In room 35, Dyma and Sasha and Ira continue to clean off a layer of broken, burnt pithos fragments and burnt wood. The layer has a slightly confusing relation to the gray, smooth compact soil rising to the NE end of the trench; the edge of the gray soil seems to cover it, but Dyma is certain that the true edge of the gray is slightly further back and that burnt material covers the gray instead. It is interesting to note that the fragments of the pithos broken in situ were burnt in the position in which they now lie – not only are most burnt only on their upper exposed surface, but at least one shows a reserved space where another sherd lay and protected it from burning (see sketch, opposite). The pithos, then, had already been smashed or broken when the room burned – smashed by invaders or broken after abandonment? In room 36, no further clarity. The removal of the last of the yellow reveals a relatively level expanse of burnt wood and tile broken into small fragments in a matrix of slightly more compact yellow soil, somewhat similar to the soil between the sherds and tiles of the intact collapse in the rooms to either side. The area of broken tile, in fact, looks very similar to those areas, down to the inclusion of carbonized wood. But a number of questions remain, including the fate of the original floor level – it would be strange if it did not initially coincide with the level of the sills, and the way some of the burnt wood slopes down from the sides also argues against floor. [p. 62] Furthermore, the patch of soft brown soil left against the SE wall, when removed, produces a large quantity of animal bones and two articulated glazed jugs that appear to have been broken and redeposited, not crushed in situ. In room 33, the remaining parts of 393 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_393]) are removed, revealing more pithoi broken in situ and an amphora in the same state. There are also more fineware fragments and the base of a glass lamp ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2401]) of the sort that would have been placed in a hanging bronze chandelier. 208 2004-07-14 00:00:20 2004-07-14 00:00:20 closed closed 14-07-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 courtyard Rabinowitz room 33 room 34 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 15/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=210 Thu, 15 Jul 2004 00:00:06 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=210 There is a georeferencing and total station bottleneck this morning – 35, 36 and 33 have all arrived at layers that need georef photos and/or topographic survey. Much standing around; in the meantime, the road continues to be cleared, with the uppermost layer of large rocks (SR423 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_423])) removed across most of the area of the stenopos (with the exception of the E corner, where the deposit is left so as not to dirty the layer in rm 33). In rm 34/yard 2, Genja and Misha continue to excavate the cistern (?) near the street. They reach a new layer about 1.25m down – a more compact, slightly greasier grayish-brown soil (SR427 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_427])). We also attempt to make arrangements with the conservators to shore up the wall above, which is in a somewhat precarious condition. After photos are taken in 35, excavation continues, with some debate. Dyma, Sasha and Ira feel that the smooth gray-brown layer that slopes from the NE is a floor interface and perhaps earlier than the collapse; their opinion is supported by the fact that the deposit of pottery and tile ends more or less along the edge they established for the layer in question. On the other hand, dark brown to [p. 63: sketch with dimensions and profile of intact green-glaze juglet from room 36; sketch with dimensions of iron/bronze cross, perhaps a reliquary cross, from room 35] [p. 64] black burnt soil continues under that edge, quite clearly, and I think that it represents the same layer of burning. The burning is thus likely to be earlier than the gray deposit, as I see it. Difficulties arise in the absence of burning between the rising bedrock along the SE wall and the gray layer, but an analogous situation was present in room 28 – perhaps the burnt material washed/eroded more thoroughly from the exposed rock. In room 36, after the completion of photos, Clay et al. turn to the removal of the remains of the brown-green soil, to be followed by the remains of the yellow soil – this should leave a unitary layer of burnt wood and ashy black-gray soil across the area of the room. The question of floor level has still not been resolved. Finds include and intact (chipped rim but one section of profile complete) green-glazed juglet (see sketch opposite) ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2416]). In the area of yard 1 included in the NW extension, Roman and Stas continue to descend, while in the area to the NW of the large, rough wall (?), Shawn, Lena and Alla draw a layer of tile and ceramic collapse (SR426 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_426])) that appears to sit on top of a floor or use surface (flat, smooth compact grayish surface). The connection between this surface and the surface of the courtyard, which should be lower, is not yet clear. From room 35, from unsystematic sieving, comes a bronze cross pendant of a sort that apparently functions as a reliquary locket (see sketch opposite). Steve arrives to lift a series of iron special finds in rm 35 and a particularly well-preserved piece of burnt wood in rm 36. Cleaning of the lower levels reveals burnt material [p. 65: sketch of situation in room 37 as of the 16th of July, with pit and wide wall depicted, not to scale] [p. 66]  and tiles that seem increasingly like original destruction. Sam, playing devil’s advocate, argues that all the collapse above could have been original, but I don’t know how one could explain either the voids between stones or the looseness of the soil in that case. The question of the bottom of the intrusion, however, remains troublesome – how and why could the lower deposit – the burnt wood in particular – have been left in situ? I notice a piece of glazed pottery behind clay pointing in wall 281 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_281]), but Larisa dates it to the 10th c, so probably residual. Another sherd in the same wall seems to belong to an amphora with thick white slip, which Larisa attributes to the 13th c – but it is too deep in the wall to remove, so not certain. The pit in room 34 is completed; I assign a new number to the bedrock cut, since only the uppermost layer of fill was excavated in 2002. 210 2004-07-15 00:00:06 2004-07-15 00:00:06 closed closed 15-07-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 middle byzantine Rabinowitz room 28 room 33 room 34 room 35 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 16/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=212 Fri, 16 Jul 2004 00:00:38 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=212 The NW area of the courtyard starts to become clearer: there is a closing wall, possibly original, at the end of the 2002 trench, followed by a space including the wide wall or construction and a massive pit, the preliminary limits of which look as in sketch opposite. The relationship between pit & wall is not yet clear. On the other side of the large construction is the area of broken tile and ceramics, which in turn covers a gravelly gray-brown hardpack which seems to be cut by the pit (and perhaps by the foundation of the wall). This hardpack is 10-20cm above the current level of the courtyard, so [it is] difficult to tell if it is a surface (separated from by the wall the 2002 section) or [p. 67: sketch of piece of worked and joined wood in situ in room 36, not to scale] [p. 68] a compact layer of abandonment. Excavation finished yesterday on pit in room 34 – bottoms about 1.5m down on bedrock, with what may be a small settling pit. Unlined – perhaps a soak-away pit for gray water produced by activity in alley (but when filled?). In room 35, gray compact soil continues to be removed – but possibly overcut in E corner of room, where it is removed almost down to bedrock. In the center of the NE side of the room, I try to keep excavation limited to the gray soil itself (actually more yellow-brown gray in areas where slightly more moist); it seems to cover a layer of darker, ashier soil over the bedrock (remains of the layer of burning more visibly present in the SW side of the room?). In room 36, what is almost certainly an intact layer of destruction, including much burnt wood, is cleaned for documentation. As in other rooms, this seems to lie over a thin clay surface which lies in turn directly on bedrock [NB: this proved to be true for certain parts of this room, but other parts lay over a series of thin layers or over thick fills of pits and/or depressions in very irregular bedrock]. The projecting stones in the NE wall base, I’m now convinced, do represent some earlier wall, rather than the level of a preexisting floor above the current layer of destruction. It is still not clear what the situation in this room was, but it does seem clear that at the time of destruction the floor level was as low as it is now. Excavation of SR410 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_410]), the layer of destruction above the floor of room 33, begins from the area of the door to room 28. This part of the room, along the SW side, is very heavily burnt, and the melting and revitrification of the glaze of the glazed pottery in this area indicates that the fire reached very high temperatures. This is the same area that showed a concentration of nails in the layer [p. 69: sketch of burnt plank in rm 36, near door to 32, and sketch of its possible position in a wooden door set under an arched doorway]  [p. 70] above, and this morning it produces a series of objects associated with doors – a hasp ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2446], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2447]), a number of keys ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2433], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2443], [ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2448]) [some of these later tentatively identified not as keys but as metal fixtures, perhaps for a box or piece of wooden furniture]. Marina is trying to leave the broken vessels in situ for the photograph, so several of them stand on [low] pedestals. Below 410 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_410]) is a very thin layer of fine black ash, to be associated with the fire in this area; it is given a separate number, although in practice it proves almost impossible to leave it in situ while removing 410 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_410]). Work also continues in the stenopos, where a layer of tile collapse covering large portions of the street is cleaned, as are the walls of the NE side of the insula. The excavation of SR410 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_410]) produces a large stone with traces of burning and, stuck to its sides, a quantity of burnt grain, perhaps barley or emmer wheat [though similar grain from other parts of this room has been identified as triticum aestivum, naked bread what]. The grain is too fragile to remove, so the whole stone is saved as a sample ([ark_link smp=CH04SR_3]). Subsequent excavation shows that this stone rested on top of a concentration of burnt wood somewhat different from the planks and beams found in other areas of burnt collapse (thicker, more knurled), and in the center of this concentration is a pile of the same burnt barley/grain. Could this have been a wooden bucket or bin? A sample of the grain is taken ([ark_link smp=CH04SR_5]) (and other samples are being taken randomly for flotation). 212 2004-07-16 00:00:38 2004-07-16 00:00:38 closed closed 16-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 courtyard Rabinowitz room 28 room 33 room 34 room 35 room 36 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 17/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=215 Sat, 17 Jul 2004 00:00:15 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=215 Before work this morning it occurs to me that the piece of burnt wood in rm 36 with the curved end is very likely to be a slat from a door meant to fit under an arched lintel, which, from the number of voussoir blocks in the fill, seems to be a standard method of door capping (see sketch opposite). [p. 72] In the NW end of yard 1 [now technically room 37, since fully separated from the court by the wall along the line of the 2002 section], work continues on the enormous pit. Fill is still soft and brown with many bones and sherds from both coarse and fineware pots. Alla and Lena go to clean the church in preparation for the arrival of a local TV crew. In room 35, excavation of hard-packed gray ashy fill (lower level) continues along the NE side of the trench. The raised bedrock seems to contain two circular hollows, probably pithos holes; one has a small amount of broken pottery in it. The other seems to have been empty at the time the gray layer was deposited. The layer of collapse on the floor also begins to be removed; early small finds include an iron lock [?] lying in situ near the door. A small patch of broken tiles and pottery in the E pithos stand is being removed: after a moment of slight confusion, it is given its own context number (yesterday’s photo will have to be corrected in the register and database [corrected in database, not changed in register]). In room 36, the burnt layer is removed from a clean, smooth chocolate-brown floor with a few large rocks apparently in situ along the NW wall. Several large pieces of wood are pedestalled for conservation. Brief discussion of a dog turd from [under] the burnt layer – presumably left there yesterday by one of the site dogs. Room 33 continues to be cleaned, leaving collapsed vessels intact. More keys and iron objects emerge. 215 2004-07-17 00:00:15 2004-07-17 00:00:15 closed closed 17-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 chapel Rabinowitz room 33 room 35 room 36 room 37 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 18/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=217 Sun, 18 Jul 2004 00:00:59 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=217 The room delimited by the NW wall of the courtyard is assigned a new number – rm 37. NB: this number had previously been assigned to the room at the N corner of the excavated area, but since it remains largely [p. 73: sketch plan of bedrock cuts in the NE end of room 35; sketch plan of bedrock cuts in room 36 – neither to scale] [p. 74]  unexcavated and has produced no material, it seemed easier to change that than to change several days’ worth of pottery bags etc. In new rm 37, Shawn, Lena, Alla, Stas & Roman remove the wide, poorly constructed late wall that covers the large pit. The soil between the stones of this wall seems very similar to the soil of the fill of the pit; a relatively flat spread of broken tiles within this layer, immediately under the lower of the two courses of the wall, may represent an attempt to level the top of the fill of the pit (or the foundation of the wall) at the moment of construction. In room 35, the removal of the burnt deposit immediately over the floor continues. At least one of the smashed pithoi seems to be in situ between the propping stones serving as a stand. The bedrock cavities at the NE end of the room reveal very little, though there is a fairly clear small posthole cut between them (see sketch opposite). In room 36, the floor continues to be cleaned. There seem to be several postholes in this floor, in addition to the series of large irregular stones that may have served as footings for posts or furniture. While the latter are clearly in phase with the final use of the room, it is not obvious that the postholes are – they may also be the remains of earlier structures, which would support the idea that the angled wall/bedrock cut along the NE side of the room belongs to an earlier phase of construction. (see sketch opposite) In room 33, removal of the lowest layer of destruction continues, still attempting to leave pithoi in place. The fill of the pit in room 37 (SR431 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_431])) seems to extend [p. 76] throughout the pit under the level of the wall, so when the wall has been removed the remaining material is designated by the same number as the fill removed on Friday-Saturday. There are a number of well-preserved finds, including a bone tool handle, a bone knife handle with the tang and part of the iron blade still in it, and several nearly-intact vessels. There are also two pieces of glass and a piece of pottery that strikes me as later than the 13th century – perhaps even 15th [though this is based only on impression, not on any expert knowledge whatsoever]. Larisa feels that they could be intrusions into the layer, but I suspect they represent the date of the fill of the pit and the construction of the wall. 217 2004-07-18 00:00:59 2004-07-18 00:00:59 closed closed 18-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 late byzantine Rabinowitz room 33 room 35 room 36 room 37 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 20/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=220 Tue, 20 Jul 2004 00:00:46 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=220 The pit in rm 37 continues to be cleaned; the situation with the stone surface below is no clearer, but after discussion with Stas, Larisa and myself, the options seem to be the following:
  • the stones are extremely large pavers for a monumental Roman-pd public square or forum (Larisa)
  • the stones are the foundation layer for a monumental structure or, better, a city wall (Stas)
  • the stones are actually bedrock in the process of being quarried & then abandoned (me)
I see the problems with the last – not least the thickness of the seams and the cuts back over a surface, rather than only against a face – but the other two seem difficult to accept given the enormous size of the central stone (limits not visible, but at least 1.9m x 1.2m, 10-15cm thick [these dimensions were by eye, not by measurement – see next day’s notes for accurate measurements]). Once the pit is photographed, its walls are cleaned for section drawings by Pyotr. [p. 78] Work finishes in rm 35; the remaining floor material is sampled. Dyma and Sasha move back to rm 29, where the floor is sectioned along a SW-NE line about 1.5m from the NW wall. Under the current floor (SR364 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_364])) is a second floor layer – this layer, on a preliminary basis, seems to include a hearth and a posthole against the NE wall. For flotation sampling purposes, for every three buckets of earth removed one bag of earth is saved. In room 36, the last of the collapse material left to hold up wall btw 36 & 32 is removed and room is swept again in preparation for excavation of the floor. The excavation of the floor begins with the removal of the thin, patchy layer of chocolate brown soil mainly located along the NW side of the room & in the corners (SR435 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_435])). In room 33, excavation of the layers of destruction immediately above the floor continues. This morning the GIS people inform us that there has been a significant confusion of small-find numbers over the last few days – perhaps 15 numbers where wrong number assigned, number duplicated, not mapped etc. About 7 of these cannot be reconnected with spatial data; the bulk seem to be in rm 33, so the record of the large number of iron objects produced by that trench in the last two or three days will be imperfect. Similar but less widespread problems also seem to affect the large quantity of architectural fragments from rm 36. A trench stretching to the NE from the E corner of the NE extension (1m wide, 2.7m from the trench wall) is opened in an effort to capture the corner of the wall across the stenopos to the NE of our building. It seems to be an area composed almost entirely of modern fill. [p. 79: sketch of location of new trench in the street to the NE (first and second extensions); sketch of stratigraphic situation under the floor of room 29 – neither to scale] 220 2004-07-20 00:00:46 2004-07-20 00:00:46 closed closed 20-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 modern Rabinowitz roman room 29 room 32 room 33 room 35 room 36 room 37 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 21/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=223 Wed, 21 Jul 2004 00:00:56 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=223 Richard (Posamentir) came by last night to look at the stone feature; he thinks it’s the slab cover of a monumental tomb. Larisa and I visited the forum or temenos at the end of the main street today, however, and measured some of the (Hellenistic? Roman?) pavers there – our largest slab is larger, but as it appears now, not substantially so, and a pavement cannot thus be ruled out [actual measurements of slab as it appears in the pit: width 1.17m, minimum length 1.72m, minimum thickness 16.5cm; measurements of one of the largest slabs in the paving of the forum at the end of the main street: width 1.04m, length 1.63m, thickness as much as 20cm]. The extension of the NE extension over the road (see sketch opposite) produces a stone that looks, potentially, like a corner block. It is located about 2.7m from the face of our insula. Once this is uncovered, we reduce the width of this trench and extend its length to the NW – the new [dimensions are] 3.5m from the insula wall and 4.8m from the [SE] edge of the initial extension. In the area of room 30, the NW edge of the section is brought out the same 40cm that was added to the section edge in rm 31a to capture the other side of the wall [of that room]. In room 29, the stratigraphic situation becomes more complicated. As I understand it, the floor covers not only another floor but an intermediary zone of loose brown soil between the two, as well as the fill of a large circular hole cut in bedrock under the NE wall (see sketch opposite). It also covers bedrock directly in the E corner (if it is certain that no underlying layers are being removed). Some of the fill of the posthole may have been removed without a new layer # and its finds consigned to the floor (SR364 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR364])); the same is true of the leading edge of the looser brown layer. In fact, the second floor forms a rather irregular T-shape, with the vertical bar oriented toward the door, and another cut appears in the W corner of the trench (a coin was found in it). Not clear if situation w/missing floor is due in small part to overcutting, though the excavators are sure that the limits are real. [p. 82] Excavation of the floor in room 32 also begins – the room is half-sectioned arbitrarily and excavated on the NW side (the side closest to rm 29). The first layer below the gray compact surface is a dark gray ashy surface, about 2cm below floor level. Room 33 is cleaned as far as it can be before the removal of the pithoi and amphorae (which have all been given numbers and sampled – that is, the ones with organic remains). Photographed and georeferenced. 223 2004-07-21 00:00:56 2004-07-21 00:00:56 closed closed 21-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 hellenistic Rabinowitz roman room 29 room 30 room 31 room 32 room 33 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 23/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=241 Fri, 23 Jul 2004 00:00:32 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=241 No notebook writing until the end of the day – very busy, meeting with Galina N. about Bez, etc. – so some recreation [that is, of excavation circumstances]. The most exciting developments take place in the street, during the removal of the layer of tile collapse. These developments are three: 1) the marble stones serving as a bench at the corner of the main street and the stenopos turn out to be Early Byz capitals from a church ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_486]); 2) towards the S end of the street, in the center, there are a series of large paving stones in a straight line – most likely covers for a box-drain ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_489]); and 3) about 2m to the NW of the door to room 36, under the tiles in an area of ash but without a recognizable grave cut, is a skeleton ([ark_link sph=CH04SR_293]) identified by Renata as that of an older woman, lacking its head. Elsewhere the street is a fairly regular pebbled surface, running down to the center with packed-earth sidewalks along the sides. [p. 87: small sketch of iron tool found lying on the surface of the courtyard] [p. 88] In room 33, remains of articulated vessels continue to be removed & floor cleaned. Under pithos 1 is the bottom of a wooden bucket – circular flat piece of wood with raised edges ([ark_link sfi=CH04SR_2699]). It is not clear if several cyclindrical pieces of wood in this area related to this object, nor whether some strange hard organic material beneath it (leather?) is. The conservators attempt a rubber impression and a block lift. They also block-lift a couple of iron tools in another part of the room – one has short teeth that look saw-like, but seems to have a central haft leading down to a handle attached at an angle, so perhaps some sort of carding comb? See sketch opposite. In room 36, remains of bedrock fill removed. Pattern of cuts and holes is unclear in both formation process (natural rock? Cuts?) and arrangement – some aspects suggest cuts & posts for earlier structures, but not certain. In room 32, remaining floor in excavated half-section is also removed to bedrock, revealing a similar situation with cuts and pits, also a lot of unclear use and function. Many are quite deep and filled at the bottom with a layer of decayed bedrock mixed with ceramics and bone. In room 29, the layer of packing under the third floor is removed down to bedrock. The stratigraphy is still rather complex, with all three floors and packing existing only in a narrow strip extending from the doorway. The section of the floor is photographed and total station points are taken on top and bottom, but it is not drawn for reasons of time.   241 2004-07-23 00:00:32 2004-07-23 00:00:32 closed closed 23-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 early byzantine Rabinowitz room 29 room 32 room 33 room 36 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 22/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=242 Thu, 22 Jul 2004 00:00:08 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=242 Work continues in the extension of the trench into the road [perhaps “street” is better, to distinguish this from the main road – this is the terminological distinction that has been drawn in the database etc] – there still seems to be a significant quantity of disturbed material, and we have not yet been able to figure out where the line of the wall of the next block is located (or continues from the possible corner block). The tile collapse, where it is intact, seems to slope rather steeply down to the E corner. In room 36, the brown floor surface below a layer of black ash (which in turn was below the grayish surface under the uppermost brown surface – ash is 449 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_449]), grayish was 448 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_448]), lowest brown is 458 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_458])) begins to be removed in the W corner. Bedrock is exposed over most of the room – although it is clear that it has been cut down near the walls, the central part of the room is full of pits and fissures, and it is not clear whether it was original untreated bedrock or whether it had been cut. In thinking about the upper story of this house, both Larisa and I agree that 36 is likely to have had an upper story; the situation is less clear with the other rooms, especially those with intact roof collapse, which one would assume to have fallen from a single story. This may mean that the yellow & brown soil in this room was original, and of a different character b/c from an upper story. This would [p. 83: axionometric sketches and sections of two possible reconstructions of the upper floor of this complex of rooms; sketch of the location of the two postholes found in the first surface under the uppermost floor of room 32]  [p. 84] explain, to a certain extent, the presence of the nicer architectural fragments & plastered material in the collapse – from the piano nobile? See possible reconstruction ideas opposite. The direction of the wooden upper stair is confirmed as we excavate the floor of rm 32. Below the hardpacked last surface (even abandonment? Or post-burning use?) is a darker, charcoal-rich layer that has a fair amount of hammerscale [in contrast to the layer above, which produced almost nothing when examined with a magnet]. Cut into that layer are two oblong postholes along the outside line of the riser of the highest step of the stone stair, along the line an upper flight would have followed to a door in the NE wall, to an upper room. The soil is also darker and harder-packed along this line, suggesting that it might have a) been subject to more consistent traffic and b) protected from the weather a bit more than the rest of the room. Below the black metal-rich later, cut by the postholes in the wall, is a layer of loamy dark-brown fill with many sherds, bones etc [NB: the bedrock in this area seems to erode very easily and form crusts as it does so, so that areas that appear to be bedrock have consistently been found to contain pottery, nails etc; in particular, in the area of the door between 32 and 36, a thick crust of bedrock appeared to have eroded down from the door, or perhaps to have been worn down and spread by human traffic]. Pithoi and amphorae continue to be removed in rm 33 (see [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_456]). The bottom of one of the best amphorae is saved with soil intact for possible residue analysis ([ark_link smp=CH04SR_71]). More iron objects emerge from the W corner. Under one of the pithoi on the NW side of the room is another pile of burnt grain, this time with linear fibrous structures that could be straw or chaff (photo’d, sample taken ([ark_link smp=CH04SR_67])). In room 29, excavation of the floor on the SE side of the room continues. Now there seem to be at least 3 floor surfaces sitting above a layer of hard-packed soil leading in a NW-SE line running roughly from the door. This may represent fill simply packed down by the passage of people into and out of the room along this line. Late in the day, a series of flat marble blocks along the [p. 85: sketch of gameboard/graffito on the southernmost of the column capitals used as a bench outside the E corner of the insula; small sketch of the possible profile of the street] [p. 86] corner of rm 33, street side, are cleaned off – the discovery of incised gameboards (?) on one of them makes us think that they probably served as a low bench outside the house (see [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_486]). The road trench continues to refuse to provide a wall, although the road itself is visible as gaps in the collapse. A concentration of large stones and what appears to be a dip in the layer along the NE wall of this trench suggests that the building material of the wall of the block NE of ours has been removed [further excavation suggests instead that the wall is simply located another 50cm or so beyond the limit of our excavation]. There is a pit in the W corner of rm 36 – it is filled with a soft, dark brown soil with white streaks that forms small clumps, is relatively moist, and contains very large amounts of animal bone and broken pottery (heavily 9th-10th c). It has not been bottomed by the end of the day, although at the SW end there appears to be a step or shallower area. 242 2004-07-22 00:00:08 2004-07-22 00:00:08 closed closed 22-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 Rabinowitz room 29 room 32 room 33 room 36 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 24/7/04 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=246 Sat, 24 Jul 2004 00:00:52 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=246 The remaining bit of uncleaned road is cleaned and photographed; the drain is discovered to turn the corner [to the E and down] into the main street, but it becomes clear that we have not, [p. 90] in fact, captured the outside wall of the next insula. I suspect it is ca. 50cm to the NE. The bench is given a context number as a wall ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_486]), but each architectural fragment will also be removed and catalogued as a small find. The conservators continue to remove burnt wood in the W corner of rm 33, where this morning they find pieces of a wicker or reed basket and what seems to be a piece of preserved unburnt wood. This corner is occupied by a series of stones ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_487]) that seem to form the base for various containers, including pithos 1 & the bucket/barrel (and perhaps the basket as well). The stones (SR487 [ark_link cxt=CH04SR_487]) are georeferenced, photographed, and removed to facilitate the lifting of the wood. Work continues in rm 32, where the filling in the bedrock has been almost entirely removed. What is left is a series of deep, subrectangular cuts with no obvious function and no apparent relation to any of the features in rm 29 or rm 36. The remaining floor levels in rm 29 are also removed; no particular features on this side of the room, though a few shallow depressions may represent other cuts. By the end of the day, excavation is down to bedrock in the half-section of room 32, in room 36, and in room 29. The floor of room 33 has been cleaned to the last-phase level and will be left for further investigation next year, along with the floors of rooms 28 and 32 (the remaining floor of the latter). The road is cleaned along its entire exposed length, with the exception of the area containing the skeleton, which is covered with geotextile & backfill. The final events before the close of excavation are the removal of the last remains of the mound of modern backfill that sat over the plateia at the end of the trench [p. 92] and the initiation of cleaning activity in preparation for final photos. At noon excavation is closed for the season. 246 2004-07-24 00:00:52 2004-07-24 00:00:52 closed closed 24-7-04 private 0 0 post 0 2004 plateia Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 32 room 33 room 36 Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 30/6/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=256 Thu, 30 Jun 2005 00:00:49 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=256 First notebook entry, third day of excavation. First two days occupied with meetings and preparation of various sorts (tools, recording system, etc.). On site, 28 June involves cleaning of grass and plant growth from all areas of site; wet cool spring has led to large amount of vegetation, even in conserved and gravel areas. Second day (29 June) involved the laying out and excavation of two new trenches/extensions. The first is a 1m wide test trench across the main road ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]). 256 2005-06-30 00:00:49 2005-06-30 00:00:49 closed closed 30-6-2005 private 0 0 post 0 2005 plateia Rabinowitz Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 1/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=259 Fri, 01 Jul 2005 00:00:30 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=259 Notebook taking interrupted where previous entry leaves off. 1m wide test trench across the main road ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]) is meant to test stratigraphy in road in preparation for excavation all the way to the modern street next to museum buildings. In the test trench, which runs off the E corner of the 2004 trench to the other side of the main road (projected), we find two layers of modern fill -- one gray, friable, full of modern building debris (ark_link cxt=CH05SR_503]), the other dark brown, loose, full of rocks and older material (but still some modern) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]) -- and beneath them what appears to be an intact layer of collapse covering the L[ate] B[yzantine] street surface ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_516]). The latter may be contiguous with the layer of collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_582]) in the street along the NE edge of the building (now "East Stenopos"). In the East Stenopos, cleaning of topsoil began on 29 June. In the northern area, topsoil covered a layer of gray modern fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_506]). Elsewhere, it seems to cover the LB collapse levels directly. The one exception is in the area of the modern drainage trench noted in 2001-2002; that intrusion is cleanly visible in the E Stenopos as an interruption of collapse levels in both surface & section ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_581]). In consultation w[ith] C Salter, thinking about metal-working in rooms 28 & 33 develops. CS feels that there is another hearth slightly to the E of 418 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_418]); he also notes a piece of hearth floor ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_518]) remaining in 418, which we will try to lift w[ith the] bedrock under it. In room 33, a patch of denser burning under, not over, the last floor surface ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_451]) and a scatter of slag & metal debris in the E corner suggest to CS another hearth  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]). This would have been in operation earlier than the storeroom function. In general, the waste CD has seen is from small-scale working at low temperatures, more characteristic of e.g. nail-making than welding or tool-repair. We develop a sample strategy for floor of room 33: 500g samples collected at points every 50cm across the room for 2m out from the NE wall. Sample sites are flagged & shot in while bags numbered, and then appropriate bags used for sample taken around each [p. 3]  point. When this work is completed, floor of rm 33 will be excavated. NB: In dealing w[ith] same layers across different years, same procedure as last year followed: layer code will be CH05 followed by same number as last year; new context sheet w[ith] reference to old -- plus any additional info -- will be generated; new database record will be generated; and all finds etc. will be bagged w[ith] CH05 code. We conduct a new georef[erencing] vs drawing at 1:50 accuracy test in rm 38, after the collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_512]) is thoroughly cleaned. We will have Italo Giordano, who has a fair amount of drafting experience but who is not a professional draftsperson, draw approx. 1/3 of the collapse by hand, using triangulation from fixed drawing pegs, at 1:50. The same area will then be photo'd & georeferenced & digitized. Both resulting plans will be compared in the GIS to survey points taken at a series of known and recognizable spots. In this way we hope to compare the average experience of a site where planning is done by hand to the georeferencing/digitization system we have developed. In the main road, levels of modern fill are removed, starting from the edge of previous excavation in front of the block. The same gray/building debris ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_503]) & brown/rocks ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]) superposition seems to apply. In the NW end of the courtyard, we begin to excavate the large pile of rocks left untouched in 2002. These rocks were originally thought to cover another cistern, but excavation shows that they are in fact the fill of a (modern?) pit ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_523]), perhaps to be associated with the modern drainage ditch mentioned above. The cut has relatively distinct edges, where the tan-gray compact clayey soil underlying the court surface is visible. The fill is a relatively consistent brownish, friable soil with large sandy clumps, frequent land-snail shells, and very mixed material representing all periods of activity in the area ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_507]). The top of a small glass bottle with squared shoulder is probably modern and should date the fill. 259 2005-07-01 00:00:30 2005-07-01 00:00:30 closed closed 1-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 courtyard late byzantine modern plateia room 28 room 33 room 38 stenopos Uncategorized _edit_last 7 2/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=261 Fri, 01 Jul 2005 00:00:45 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=261 Work continues on modern fill in road -- apparent situation is two chronologically distinct modern layers, one dating from the 19th c. & monastery activity ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]), the other from the destruction of the monastery building in this area in the 20th century ([ark_link cxt-CH05SR_503]). Although most material is not retained, we will try to keep particularly diagnostic material to confirm or reject this idea. [arrow leads from here to paragraph beginning “also on main street” below] The Stenopos collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_423]) is documented with a series of georeferencing photos. The 1m spread of reference points with substantial overlap seems to be fairly accurate. Drawing of room 38 reveals problems with the current plan alignment of the NE wall -- needs to be rotated NE by about 5 degrees. Will be dealt with by architect this afternoon; other potential base-plan problems will be checked. also on main street: upper layer of collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_516]) is now being removed near the test trench; behind that team, another [p.4: sketch of plan of the mouth of the well at the N end of the courtyard and section of the deposits filling it, not to scale] [p.5] has begun to remove the lower layer of brown collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_582]). In rm 33, metal sample of last floor is complete ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_451]); that floor begins to be excavated down to the black ashy layer below from the NE wall of the room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]). NB x2: 1) Some illicit digging/vandalism went on during lunch yesterday in rm 33: a hole was dug at sample point in N corner and another partially under the sill of the blocked door; 2) one or more of the metallurgical samples in the area of the suspected hearth may have mixed the floor layer & the layer beneath & may give false positive (Chris aware of situation). -- In rm 33, paleobotanical flotation samples collected at rough 1m intervals in quincunx pattern [parenthetical illustration of pattern] ([ark_link smp=CH05SR_338]). Samples are approx. 1/2 size of large bags (so 1/2 size of previous year). At N end of courtyard, excavation in second pit continues ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_523]). Upper fill was large rocks; below were same rocks in increasingly visible matrix of pebbly brown loose soil with root mold (standard fill soil) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_507]). Sides of pit are ca. 2m in diam[eter]. at top; about 35cm down there is a partial floor into which a smaller extension of the pit continues; about 20-30cm after the narrowing of the pit, it begins to be cut into bedrock (see sketch opposite). Just below bedrock lip, fill starts to be softer & with fewer stones; will become new context ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_511]). Courtyard is sectioned along line projected from outside edge of rm 25. Brushed down once more in prep. for metallurgical sample collection. 261 2005-07-01 00:00:45 2005-07-01 00:00:45 closed closed 2-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard late byzantine modern plateia Rabinowitz room 25 room 33 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 6/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=263 Wed, 06 Jul 2005 00:00:46 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=263 [Passage redacted] First two days of week primarily occupied w[ith] ongoing georeferencing photography of street and room 38 (in conjunction with drawing vs georef experiment), with continued removal of modern fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]) from street, and with extensive metallurgical sampling of courtyard  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_509]) (first & last involving a lot of time with total station, so fairly slow). In main street, last of modern fill  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_504]) is cleaned from remains of ancient collapse, and remaining corner of unexcavated fill on NE side of road test trench is excavated to bring trench as a whole to square. In room 33, Nick & Olga finish cleaning, prepare to sample black patchy layer in NE side (up to ca. 2m from NE wall of room) (([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]). They also take a sample from another ashy feature in the S corner of room 33 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_518]). When this sample is complete, they will begin to sample the remaining floor in room 32 (the upper layer of soil  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_354]) was removed yesterday to reveal the ashy layer  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_460]) beneath) and excavate the potential second hearth in room 28 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_505]). In the courtyard, work continues on tomb 3 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_514]) (cover slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_513]) at W end and upper layer of fill removed yesterday). Renata [p. 6: on upper part of page, sketch of bomb crater over part of church and upper layers of tomb 3, with north arrow but not to scale; on lower part of page, sketch of ashy patches in courtyard to SW of rooms 29 and 32] [p.7] supervises as first pieces of disarticulated bone emerge. The half-section of the courtyard ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_509])  to the N of the tomb begins to be excavated in 10-15 cm passes after paleobotanical samples taken. Faunal collection w[ith] reexamination of loose [soil] in wheelbarrow. Excavation of well at N end of courtyard continues; new layer of fill with more rocks reached late yesterday, very sterile -- only a few finds of apparently Roman pottery & glassware ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_517]) . Now approaching 3m deep; sides of cut bedrock shaft slightly more square than round. Excavation begins in rm 38 -- removal of rocky collapse with patches of smaller stones and small tile fragments (very broken) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_512]). Special attention paid to areas along NE & SW walls, where stone alignment suggests buttressing or bench. First deposition reached in T.3 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_514]). Only lower half of body uncovered in area originally defined as tomb, so effort made to find head area -- built sides only extend to waist of first deposition. Head of tomb seems only to be defined by cut in fill of courtyard -- but nearby bomb damage to chapel may also have disturbed tomb (see sketch opposite). Well in N end of courtyard ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_523]) may be cistern after all -- about 3m below floor cut opens up to sides. Fill seems to be entirely of large rocks, w[ith] soil filtered down between -- almost entirely sterile. In courtyard trench, gray ashy surface soil comes down onto compact, clayey yellow fill with many sherds, bones, etc. Probably original fill of court to create surface level ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]). 263 2005-07-06 00:00:46 2005-07-06 00:00:46 closed closed 6-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard modern plateia Rabinowitz roman room 28 room 32 room 33 room 38 tomb 3 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 7/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=265 Thu, 07 Jul 2005 00:00:13 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=265 Cleaning of main road & area on NE side of test trench is completed. Clearly parts of Stenopos have been disturbed by modern activity -- but traces seem to tend not to be visible on surface. All excavated as one unit -- so any discussion of material from NW end of street should take into account contamination. -- courtyard: black patches given numbers, sampled, drawing completed. Begin to be removed ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_524]). -- well/cistern ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_523]): Odd cutting observed in SE wall of shaft, below area where chamber begins. SE side of tomb still not clear; still off double-wall situation on NW side <(see sketch opposite). Is inner “face” simply a well-aligned series of cover stones? -- In courtyard, serious confusion over limits & nature of black--dark-brown fill in largest & most central of ashy features ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_525]). Different from others in brown color & compaction of soil; Karissa and Shawn suspect it may have been more similar above & that chocolate brown soil is something new, but I don't see difference. Soil [p.10: profile sketch of small pot found partially articulated in floor below fill of room 32] [p.11]  inclusions of clayey material, some of which was distinctly green in color. Soil sample of greenish soil taken -- maybe try to test for potassium content (fertilizer?). Limits are very irregular, & I wonder if we're not looking at a planting pit for a small tree (would have been removed by last phase of courtyard). -- in well/cistern ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_523]), removal of soil continues. Dyma noted on Sat. that water drips off bedrock by itself -- rather than condensation, seems to be water borne, perhaps on surface of clay just under bedrock, from groundwater (wick effect?). When cleaning of mod[ern] fill complete, that will be taken off as only uncontaminated section of original stenopos collapse. -- in main road, boundaries of modern trench for electric cable ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_533]) are defined, & remaining collapse is determined to be original.
