The SE side of the tomb is clearly severely disturbed by the bomb (?) that damaged the adjoining wall of the chapel. Several bones can be seen sticking out at odd angles, and stones have been forced into the soil of the tomb. Some bones have calcium carbonate concretions, and there were several large chunks of calcium carbonate in the upper layer of stones over the tomb -- it is not clear if this material is decayed bedrock, mortar from the church, or, as seems to have been noted for t. 3 in 2001/2, a layer of lime sealing. -- in courtyard trench, Shawn & team continue to clean layer of yellow pebbly soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538])  to establish limits, and remaining ashy pits are removed ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_524]). Yellow seems to be present only ca. 1m out from walls on NW & NE sides, irregular outline elsewhere. -- in well/cistern, continued excavation of same layer of fill  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_520]). Some articulated late Roman ceramics, including large parts of an amphora -- what is date of filling event? Use? [p.12: upper part of page contains a sketch of numbered flying sections across courtyard and room 38; lower part of page contains sketches of the broken slab paving on the floor of t. 4 and of the relation between t. 4, t. 5, and the NW wall of the church] [p.13] -- rm 32: Nick & Rose continue to remove fill -- pit w[ith] ashy fill in [ark_link cxt=CH05SR_460] is cleaned, while Nick goes down through clayey tan fill to NE. Bedrock strip id[entifie]'d in 2004 continues; cut seems to be deliberate (?). Finds -- ceramic, glass -- similar to those in 2004 on other side. -- rms 30 & 31: surface cleaning proceeds in preparation for excavation and sieving of surfaces for faunal remains. -- rm 38: excavation of intact wall-fall proceeds ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_512]) ; in lower levels, soil reveals patches of yellow clay, probably decayed mud plaster from walls. Extra course against wall appears on NE inside face as well. Visible below brown collapse soil is grayer layer w[ith] charcoal inclusions, apparently many tiles -- intact tile collapse & burning ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535])? -- stenopos: remains of wall collapse removed ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_423]); tile collapse beneath ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]) begins to be cleaned. Rest of human body found last year revealed beneath tile collapse; present only to knee; perhaps lower legs removed by animals. -- main street: direction of attack on wall collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_516]) changed to move SW to NE, in order to leave area for cleaning. Opinion of Anton and Pavlo that collapse is intact -- no modern finds, Byz[antine] ceramics. -- rm 38: cleaning of layer reveals what seems to be final layer of tile fall & wall erosion in room; higher along walls ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_512]). Two stones of internal stair in W corner accidentally picked off & then put back in place. -- tomb 4 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_539]): second layer of disarticulated bones cleaned & removed; again, concentrated along NW side. Series of 9+ skulls at SW end; they & other bones are resting on very flat yellow cover slabs, missing along SE side but perhaps disturbed (flat similar stone off to that side) -- covering of original tomb? Lower course of stones along SE side also visible. 274 2005-07-12 00:00:26 2005-07-12 00:00:26 closed closed 12-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 byzantine courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 32 room 38 stenopos tomb 4 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 13/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=276 Wed, 13 Jul 2005 00:00:15 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=276 Standard procedure: clockwise from tomb. -- tomb 4 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_539]): becomes even more confusing this morning, & chase after osteo[logical] material I think further confuses the issue. Area of t. 4 is emptied, at foot, comes down onto bedrock, but with a regular cut parallel to the wall of the tomb; from [skeleton] waist level up, tomb is covered by flat slab that sits on a couple of stones with an incasso. One broken piece that has been off to the side for several days finally becomes totally clear -- it is the missing piece of the slab, deposited upside-down as if it had been turned up directly from its original position. To the SE of the tomb, where we had assumed there was only disturbed soil from destruction, there actually appears another (earlier?) tomb (t. 5). It shares its NW wall with t. 4, which appears to cut it, and is full of disturbed skeletal material. It seems to extend underneath the wall of the church, so if it was opened repeatedly it would need to have been under a threshold. See sketch opposite. -- courtyard: excavation of yellow-orange layer begins ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]) -- some confusion, but seems to be relatively thin. Below W corner, where layer forms corner, there is some very regular squarish structure in bedrock (?) with clay deposits. Flying sections done in this room for the first time today. [p.14: upper part of the page: sketch of the section of the shaft of the well at the N end of the courtyard; middle of the page on the left: sketch of intaglio signet gem from fill of t. 5; lower part of the page: on the left, sketches of two hypothetical reconstructions of stratigraphic section of church wall and t. 5; on the right, sketch plan of church and tombs 4 and 5] [p.15]  -- rm 32: complete - excavation down to bedrock. Odd but extremely regular linear features that appear to be cuts in bedrock ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_551]) ; clear that they do not continue into rm 29, though they may appear again in 28 (some continue under dividing wall). Brown fill extended to bedrock except -- as visible in section -- in a small lunate cut in bedrock along SW side of the room, where fill may have been slightly different (not excavated separately). Nick and team move to rm. 33, where they begin to remove hearth feature in E corner ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_555]). -- well/cistern ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_520]): continues to be excavated. Potential new context id[entifie]'d at end of day yesterday ruled out; same fill. Beneath clay level cut again visible in underlying bedrock (see sketch opposite). -- rm. 38 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535]): continued cleaning of collapse; after some consideration, it is decided that the slightly grayer layer is in fact the same as the soft, fine brown layer that had been removed to date. Quick trowel cleaning & photo followed by careful excavation of large stones in an attempt to reveal possible tile collapse beneath. Among fragments visible after cleaning is another carefully worked arch block with incasso for a window. In N corner is a small pile of pebbles and broken tile -- seems to be a separate deposit. This and other tiles along sides appear to rest on more compact, harder, smoother brownish-grey layer w[ith] charcoal inclusions -- Italo interprets as decay of mud plaster on walls. -- stenopos ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]): cleaning continues. Tile fall much less pronounces as one moves to the NW. NW end left dirty for ongoing work in 38. Steve and Olga begin to remove geotextile covering upper torso of body in street. -- rm 33: Nick & co. return to this room to remove visible surfaces, starting w[ith] hearth feature in E corner ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_555]). Upper layer of ash & metal ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]) covers a more defined depression filled with ash and metal debris; a separate patch, probably planned as the same original layer, also fills an irregular oval cut. Not yet clear if concentration of stones in S corner is simply leveling fill or a separate layer. -- main street: excavation of rocky collapse (or fill?) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_516]) is completed up to line of electric cable trench. Cleaning of sparse tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_579]) beneath begins from SW end. 276 2005-07-13 00:00:15 2005-07-13 00:00:15 closed closed 13-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 byzantine courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 28 room 29 room 33 room 38 stenopos tomb 4 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 14/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=278 Thu, 14 Jul 2005 00:00:14 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=278 -- tomb 5 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_552]): situation becomes slightly clearer as outlines of earlier tomb, lined with monumental blocks, become clearer. Tomb seems to have been uncovered during church construction, stones on NW & part of NE side removed (for use in wall?), whole SW wall reused under church wall. Still some confusion over nature of fill, which has lots of human bone from individuals of various ages, including children -- is this the fill removed from the earlier tomb, or is it related to the disarticulated material in t. 4? Two hypotheses sketched out opposite: one, church built, tomb emptied & refilled, foundations laid, & in use of t. 4 human skeletal material deposited b[e]tw[een] tomb & wall of church; and two, tomb emptied & all refilled w[ith] same material, on which church walls built -- here, bones would belong to original occupants. Ceramics, at least at first glance, seem to Larissa to be no later than 10th c, so will be important for dating of church. In support of hyp[othesis] 1, more bones along side shared w[ith] t. 4; in support of hyp[othesis] 2, no limit between the fill of the tomb & the fill under the wall & the fill w[ith] bones (& how could church wall sit on pillar of fill?). [p.16: blank]  [p.17] -- courtyard trench ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]): removal of yellow soil complete, cleaning continues. New layer of yellowish soil visible in roughly square area around square bedrock feature now visible in surface; that feature seems to be related to stratigraphy in that area. Elsewhere, brown soil with ceramic & bone ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_550]), patches of black burnt-seeming soil. Remaining ashy pits emptied; one produces very large piece of slag. -- well/cistern ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_520]): still going down. Soil wetter; finds rare, include bone, tile, some small ceramic frags. -- rm. 38 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535]): stones in brown-gray silty soil continue to be removed. More tiles below, but not as many as one would hope to find in intact collapse. No signs of burnt wood; also, depressingly, less tile fall in street in this area. Some signs of floor surface -- bedrock in area of stairs & potential door to street, beaten-earth (apparently) in patch below tiles in S corner. Cleaning in morning. Soil continues to include patches of yellow clay and concentrations of sea grass (from roof & walls, presumably). -- stenopos ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]): remains of skeleton from last year excavated, joined to remains found this year. Head present after all -- but face missing (poor preservation). Bones in burnt patch, some show signs of burning. After geophotos & recording of skeleton as separate context, excavation from under tiles begins. -- rm 33 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]): excavation of ashy deposits in floor pits in NE half of room continues. Slag, metal objects, regular debris present. Will be planned & mapped when complete -- work progressing rather slowly. -- main street ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_579]): remains of tile collapse & street surface continue to be cleaned. No good visible evidence for presence of main drain. Generally, we decide to move winch out of 2004 slab pit in order to begin excavation of courtyard/back room levels. If slabs are indeed another (intact) tomb, we have to finish it this year. 278 2005-07-14 00:00:14 2005-07-14 00:00:14 closed closed 14-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 chapel courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 33 room 38 stenopos tomb 4 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 15/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=280 Fri, 15 Jul 2005 00:00:51 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=280 Notebook entry written after end of work -- busy with second geophoto test in rm 38, other tasks. -- tomb 5 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_552]): continued excavation of brown fill; more bones found in careless deposits, mixed w[ith] animal bone including a dog skull. At one point in layer, fill of large rocks is distinct enough for Gordana to take a photo & spot heights, although there is nothing to distinguish this level as a new context. By the end of the day, the tomb is emptied -- no new info[rmation] above the bedrock-cut base. Sides seem to be plastered w[ith] plaster similar to that of church apse; some areas could be interpreted as mortar with calcium/lime base w[ith] small frags of ceramics -- but this material is fragile and only on the face of the wall, and this may be simply the plaster backing. The uppermost course on the SE side seems to have been dressed to a line after setting -- some tool marks beneath plaster. Masonry is not ashlar after all -- instead, large regular blocks in regular courses with tile levelling & plaster facing. After lunch, I clean the bedrock bottom again & define the wall [p.18: sketch of distribution of layers beneath stone collapse in room 38] [p.19] stones further. Only additional evidence for dating is from a place in the SW wall where a stone seems to be missing just above bedrock: several frags of pottery from brown damp soil that may or may not be same as fill (one frag seems to be behind a stone w[ith] plaster around it). The one that seems very datable is almost certainly late Hell[enistic] or later -- shiny, red slip with bead and reel molding along rim, either ES/Pergameme or (from fabric) much later -- Africana? No help there -- still doesn't explain relation of this tomb & the chapel. One coin from fill today -- Larissa thinks 10th c. -- courtyard ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_563]): apparent fill of trench along NW wall defined; remaining area in crescent along edge of large irregular cut in center of area given a new number (it is less dark chocolate colored than the ashy soil and has several stones & tiles set in it -- packing for edge of cut?); large pit clearly visible after rain just to S is defined and excavated. Although dimensions on horizontal [plane] are large (>1m in diam.), it is very shallow & comes down onto bedrock after ca. 10cm. -- well: new layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_565]) -- clay under the brown fill, probably eroded from clay seam just above. On top of clay the skeleton of a medium-sized dog. Under clay a new layer of rocky fill with very little soil between the stones. Still very little material, though above the clay I found -- during a descent to check up -- another Roman brick w[ith] signs of burning, v[ery]. similar to bricks and material in "burnt layer" at bottom of first layer of bedrock. -rm 37: work begins in afternoon w[ith] section cleaning. Several lenses of burnt earth, ash, charcoal are visible beneath an uppermost gray fill ca. 10-15cm thick ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_575]). Stratigraphy will be complicated. Shawn supervising; after cleaning, begins to remove gray layer along NW section in area. Preliminary investigation tends to suggest different stratigraphy on either side of the late (removed) wall that ran into the fill of the pit. -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): during slow period in rm 38 while documentation activities taking place, Harvey, Olga, Jessica H., Boris set to removing 10cm pass of last surface of this room/courtyard. All the soil from excavation in this surface will be sieved , mainly to collect faunal remains; the same will be true of the floor of rm 30, which we also plan to investigate. (5mm sieve mesh) -- rm 38 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535]): work stops after sparse tile collapse is cleaned; geophotos & drawing done. Collapse seems to have more tiles along SE side of room; in NE side, where there are stairs, the bedrock seems to have been used as the bottom riser, and there may be some sort of platform in the N corner of the room, where there is an odd deposit of rounded pebbles, few tiles, and a hard layer that may be a surface. In front of the second wall along the NW wall of the room (probable stair support) there is a substantial, roughly circular depression into which tiles & other elements of collapse seem to spill -- including two large squared blocks that may represent a pier at the corner of the stair support. Amid the tile collapse are several smallish, very regular, square terracotta elements, ca. 20cm on a side -- could be broken tiles, but should not be ruled out as paving [p. 20: on left, sketch of bedrock cuts and fill below t. 4; on right, sketch of surface of fill 519 in room 33]  [p.21] tiles for an upstairs floor. -- stenopos ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]): excavation of fallen tile layer begins. In roughly same area as skeleton, two burnt beams found -- one longer but more fragmentary, other shorter but well-preserved. Given "wood" find numbers, mapped, geophoto[graphe]'d; conservators called out to attempt a lift, in the hopes that enough rings will be present for dendro[chronological] dating. Experimental lift with foam on the more poorly-preserved example. -- rm 33: Nick & Jessica & Dan finish excavating ashy fill of circular & irregular pits and cuts in early floor (?) of room, mainly along NE wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_508]). Situation in the rest of the room is confused: the hard-pack, w[ith] few inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_451]), gives way in an indefinite manner to a loose soil fill of animal bones and ceramics (apparently a levelling fill) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_519]). I would prefer to understand the hardpack as an early use surface & the rest as fill, but I don't know where the contemporary floor in the rest of the room has gone. In addition, the high line of stones in similar soil in the S corner of the room is starting to look like it may be the remains of an earlier wall -- follows bedrock cut along SE wall in slightly too straight a line to be dismissed as casual. * in circular/irregular pit in E corner, two interesting elements: 1) large fragment of hardened soil with ash and iron slag concretion on surface, tossed into fill at an angle (clearly visible in section); 2) hardened dark brown soil at bottom of feature, clearly distinct from fill, with two circular impressions. Not clear if latter extends under limits of cut or should be associated with its use. 280 2005-07-15 00:00:51 2005-07-15 00:00:51 closed closed 15-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 chapel courtyard hellenistic Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 _wp_old_date 2018-05-14 16/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=282 Sat, 16 Jul 2005 00:00:10 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=282 Again, entry after end of working day. After work yesterday & during work today, Cathy and Inga lift part of a piece of wood -- we'll attempt to use it for dendro[chronological] analysis, if we can get a good section; we also take a sample for potential carbon-dating. - tomb 4/t. 5: slabs set in bottom of t. 4 (& clearly in phase with that tomb, as well as perhaps w[ith] t.5 -- plastered to t.4 headstone) are lifted. Beneath is a solid, dense, brown fill  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_552]) containing bones & what appears to be late Roman or early Byzantine pottery. This fill continues, without interruption, under the headstone of t. 4 and to the NW, in the area where a large circular cut has been made in bedrock. The wall of t. 5 backs up against this fill -- not clear if it was built up against a cut in that fill or if the fill was deposited after the construction of the tomb. Under the double wall of t. 4, flat stones look increasing[ly] like the ends of paving slabs (see sketch opposite). Situation is even more confused than before. Excavation ceased until larger area of courtyard to be opened. -- courtyard: brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_563]) along NW wall determined to be fill of foundation trench for that wall, emptied. Clayey orange fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_562]) of circular feature just to SE also emptied; beneath, an even harder-packed clay layer. Sequence of cuts & fills -- and their purpose -- growing increasingly obscure. [p. 22: sketch of bedrock cuts under rooms 33 and 36, with possible area of 9th-11th century sunken-floor building shaded]             [p. 23] -- well ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_565]): beneath layer of clay, largely sterile fill of large stones continues. We decide that we can't risk losing the work of that team for two more weeks w[ith]out any guarantee of finding the bottom, and close work in the well for the season. Team will move to gray soil over slabs to N. -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): continued removal of 10 cm of floor level for sieving. Cross pendant found in sieve from this layer ([ark_link sfi=CH05SR_2981]). By end of excavation day, pass is almost to stairs to upper floor of rm 38. -- rm 38: drawing continues in morning. Test of time and accuracy of hand planning at 1:50 vs geophotos from ladder continues. Currently, drawing is ca 5 hrs in field; photos are 1 hr for 2 people in field, plus another 15 hrs for one person referencing & making mosaic/catalogue. When drawing complete, excavation resumes from SE end of rm --removal of thickest part of tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535]). In S corner, fragments of a pithos apparently in situ are found -- removed before can be photographed, but position taken with total station ("other find" category reinstituted). -- stenopos: removal of tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]) continues. Segment near rm 38 still left for barrow transit [that is, to provide a surface over which wheelbarrows can pass to the spoil heap]; not yet on geophotos. Treatment of beam remains as mentioned above. -- main street: tile collapse along SE wall of bldg (complex 3) geophoto'd -- note presence of larger pieces of carbonized wood, again probably burnt beams. Limits of this deposit may be result of modern intervention in street -- but could also represent fall of porch roof (or at least roof slanted to street over rm 33). Two large stones set up against outside wall may support first idea. -- rm 33: excavation of surface or layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_451]) under ashy patch begins, after ash-filled pits are fully emptied. Starting to seem that line of rocks in S may be related to some of cuts in rm 36 bedrock -- possible that in this corner are some of the few traces of dark-age habitation. If so, building probably in mudbrick and timber w[ith] sunken floor, possibly postholes for posts to carry roof tree. Alignment 5-7º off alignment of final structures of block (see sketch opposite). Removal of layer still somewhat tentative -- concern over lack of clarity in relation of various apparent visible layers to each other. * NB: Sasha Arkhipov called his father last night to ask about intaglio signet -- AS says certainly glass, paste, since dark blue color isn't natural. Quite possible as interp, though I'm bothered by hardness and survival of design, lack of patination. [gemstone later determined to be banded agate, which does have a blue variant] 282 2005-07-16 00:00:10 2005-07-16 00:00:10 closed closed 16-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard early byzantine plateia Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 33 room 36 room 38 stenopos tomb 4 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 18/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=284 Mon, 18 Jul 2005 00:00:33 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=284 Work on well & on tombs in church closed -- some cleaning of latter for Allyson's drawing. Boris Z. has left, replaced by another Simferopol student called Alexei. [p.24:upper part of page: section of room 37, pit and layers over slabs; lower part of page: sketches of the copper-alloy padlock with lion finials found in street outside room 33] [p.25] -- in courtyard, continuing confusion. Brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_550]) with bones & stones removed in preliminary 5-10cm pass, but this reveals complex situation at NW end. In hollow in center of bedrock, at NW end, another orange clay layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_562]) , apparently just over bedrock, containing frags of roof tiles. Next to that, a medium brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_577]) w[ith] large rocks (W corner of trench), which seems in turn to be cut by a feature ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_588]) filled with an ashier dark brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_576]). This seems to sit directly on bedrock; on the other side of a slight rise in the bedrock, the same feature seems to cut a harder grayish layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_578]) . This, in its turn, is under the brown layer, but its limit to the SE is unclean. Paleobotanical samples taken from the brown being removed. -- rm 37: excavation of final floor surface begins. Examination of section in part suggests different situations on NW and SE sides, roughly along the center line of the original last-phase wall... (see 19/7/05 for completion of this entry) 284 2005-07-18 00:00:33 2005-07-18 00:00:33 closed closed 18-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard Rabinowitz room 33 room 37 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 19/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=286 Tue, 19 Jul 2005 00:00:15 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=286 ... although the last-phase wall clearly post-dates the division in the use of the room (I am continuing yesterday's entry today -- couldn't complete in field). Current hypothesis -- original fill of room sloped down to SE; gradually filled to level with fire and hearth remains. Then final floor laid down; then large pit cut, filled w[ith] rubbish, wall built on top (see sketch opposite). Dyma & co. clean off remaining pieces of final floor surface ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_575] and [ark_link cxt=CH05SR_596]) down to layer of fire/hearth ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]). -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): excavation of 10 cm pass over courtyard continues -- suddenly occurs to me that slightly harder-packed gravelly area along the stairs has probably been excavated w[ith] courtyard surface -- but in any case should have been contemporary in last phase, so probably ok. -- rm 30 (19/07): excavation in room -- for sieving for fish remains -- begins w[ith] remaining area of hearth in E corner of room (lower levels) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_677]). Sample taken or paleobotanical analysis; remaining material will be sieved for faunal remains. -- rm 38: excavation of upper layer of tile & stone collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_535]) continues in NW side of room, where it is very thin over bedrock step & deeper in area of circular feature next to stairs. Also sieved; continues to contain tile frags, ceramics, stones, nails (especially along SE wall, where underneath are pithos & amphora crushed in situ). Some carbonized woods remains. -- stenopos: tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]) removed & modern trench ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_510]) cleaned except in area of rm 38. -- main street: removal of tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]) outside rm 33 (19/07): under stone at E corner of block, lock of Eastern (Iranian?) manufacture found ([ark_link sfi=CH05SR_3065]) -- extremely good preservation, w[ith] lion finials. Two pieces found slightly separate under this stone, which seems to be part of bench with capitals (removed as special finds last year). Lock is a padlock, probably for a chest rather than a door (too fine, bronze, door locking mechanisms diff[erent]). In road due to looting? -- two pieces of semi-fallen outside wall of rm 33 picked off by mistake, replaced (roughly). [p.26: blank] [p.27] -- rm 33: excavation of fill layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_519]) beneath surface contemp[orary]. w[ith] hearth continues. In N corner, large quantity of stones in somewhat random position -- remains of packing of edges of earlier sunken-floor bldg? Bedrock is cut out from walls of 33, but also seems to be cut under wall dividing 33 and 36, in conjunction with that wall -- so not clear if early building exists or not. Earlier building could also have been divided into 3 rooms of roughly equal size... Following reflects today's activity. -- main street: another find under the stony collapse next to the wall  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_579]): bronze vessel (or helmet?) ([ark_link sfi=CH05SR_3095]) with inside it a spearpoint, several pieces of charcoal, apparent iron handle (?), fragments of a couple of pieces of glazed pottery. [this object was later identified as a copper-alloy bucket, to which the iron handle belonged; the “spearpoint” is part of a door locking mechanism] Soil from inside taken for flotation; charcoal from inside taken for possible carbon dating; photographed & shot in. -- rm 38: depression in NW side turns out to be ovoid rectangular pit w[ith] bedrock cuts along side & channel apparently leading to it ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]). Filled w[ith] tile collapse, so open at time of destruction. -- courtyard: increasingly complicated situation, w[ith] series of cuts and fills in irregular (usually circular) pits. Currently, there seems to be a dark ashy fill (in two layers) which is the latest ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_576] and [ark_link cxt=CH05SR_587]); this in turn fills a cut in a hard gray layer to the SE ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_578]) & a rocky fill to the NW (?). The rocky fill covers the edge of the layer beneath the upper orange layer, which is filled with broken tiles ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_593]). This fill in turn fills a circular cut in bedrock ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_598]). Tiles seem to be medieval -- again, issue of dating of construction of house (construction trench later than this, or earlier? When was pit filled?) -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): in angle near blocked door & blocked wall, lots of small finds, including many metal objects. 2 possible cuppels or ceramic vessels used as crucibles, in one case for gold refining. [these were later determined to be crucibles] ([ark_link sfi=CH05SR_3069] and [ark_link sfi=CH05SR_3098]) -- in unexcavated area [of the main street, between the dig site and the modern road], backhoe begins to dig. Comes across very flat mortar/concrete (?) construction slightly w[ith]in line of monastery wall on Kost[s]yushko plan – interp[retation] not clear, but certainly 19th-20th c. Also an intact cannonball. 286 2005-07-19 00:00:15 2005-07-19 00:00:15 closed closed 19-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard modern plateia Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 36 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 20/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=288 Wed, 20 Jul 2005 00:00:58 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=288 Entry written after end of work day -- too busy. Note ongoing excavation in rm 37 in afternoon (discussed w[ith] main entry below). -- courtyard: ongoing removal of various pits & fills, including remainder of brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_563]), ashy black layer in pit (?) against section ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_587]), and bottom (different) layer of tile & brown earth in pit in middle of NW side ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_593]), near foundation trench of NW wall. Two small pits/holes in bedrock under ashy layer, but otherwise no particular sense to developments in courtyard. Preliminary analysis of ceramics gives tentative 13th c. date to almost everything in courtyard, including fill of t. 5. [p.28: middle of page: sketch of room 38 floor surface, with oval pit; bottom of page: two sections of pit showing last use surface]  [p.29] -- rm 37: excavation in both morning & afternoon. Situation is confusing, despite some visible layers in section. On NE side ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_592]), substantial amount of pit wall removed under the assumption that burnt patch continued beneath; although may be slightly out of sequence, orange patch of burnt earth does seem to be more complicated than it first appeared -- runs deeper along NE wall, perhaps actually under soil to NW rather than over it. On SW side, only stable reference point is patch of burnt earth, ash & charcoal against section ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]) -- seems to sit on a surface and be covered by grayer pebbly brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_575]) on NW side. Removal of that soil & of remainder of wall sitting on it begins, extends around NW side. We are probably being more cavalier with this stratigraphy than we would under ideal circumstances, but it seems far more important to uncover the slabs by the end of the season than it does to be completely certain of the microstratigraphy of something that is almost certainly a dump (note to any future readers -- I know that sounds like defensive justification, but it really is true). -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): The S wing has now been excavated to a level much lower than the first 10cm pass in the W wing, and has produced a high number of small finds & evidence of fine metalworking (copper & gold). We turn to the W wing again to bring it down to the same level; all soil still being sieved. -- rm 38: depression along NW side turns out to be, in fact, a feature: a squared oval pit with a channel or depression leading into it and a groove in the soil running around the edge ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]). In the middle of the NW wall, against the stair base (?), is a flat rock with a small circular cut -- post base? At the W corner, the groove continues under the stair (?) construction; initially it seemed to be another hiding-place, but now more likely interpretation is a cut to seat the wood-and-wicker structure that probably sat in the groove and enclosed the pit (only way to explain the way earth walls were retained, and fits well with consistent presence of charcoal at the bottom of the groove[)]. Possibly an animal pen; apparently other parallels from Late Byz[antine] Chers[onesos]. On the other side of the room, vessels broken in situ are removed. Some evidence of burnt wood, but not as much as one would expect if the room had been subject to the same sort of fire that destroyed the rooms along the E side of complex 3. Post-destruction salvage operations? Could also explain rm 36... (see sketch and section, opposite). - Note also possible alignment of stones on opposite sides of room at SE end -- supports for shelving? coincidence? -- rm 33 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_519]): Ongoing excavation of pottery & bone-rich fill under surface associated w[ith] metal-working -- large quantities of animal remains, incl[uding]. fish bones (as elsewhere on site). Large flattish rock set deep in area where I had hoped for third posthole form earlier building -- post support? Distinct difference between pile of rocks in N corner  ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_586]) and rest of fill. [p.30: sketch of elevation of SE wall of room 33, side facing the main street, with sketch of section to explain collapse pattern] [p.31]  20 July cont. (rest of entry written 21 July) -- main street: ongoing removal of tile collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_579]), cleaning of surface below. Removal of part of outside wall of rm 33 collapsed in situ ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_582]); some stones less fixed, need to be removed to extract bucket (done in afternoon by conservators). Remaining rocks left until conversations can be had w[ith] Chris about how to deal with wall -- reconstruct from blocks clearly in situ, if fallen, or simply remove? See sketches opposite for rough elevation and section of situation. 288 2005-07-20 00:00:58 2005-07-20 00:00:58 closed closed 21-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 13th century 2005 courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 21/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=292 Thu, 21 Jul 2005 00:00:30 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=292 -- courtyard: approaching bedrock in all areas; along SE side of area, where balk left next to t. 3, line of stones appears ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_722]) (possibly in line w[ith] odd second wall of tomb). We cut back the section, not keeping pottery & w[ith]out much attention to stratigraphy, to get a better sense of the nature of these stones – tentatively, seem to be a wall. -- rm 37: another wall appears under 13th c. fill here, too -- partially destroyed, but very thick & recognizable ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_607]). More or less same alignment as walls of block & as slabs, but will need to look on plan. Not yet clear if this is in phase with slabs. Note that fill levels ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_596]), rich in pottery and animal bone, look almost identical to fill levels in rm 33 (color, composition, type of animal bones, etc.). Fill does seem to cover both ash in S corner ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]) & hard, smoother brown soil beneath it ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_620]) -- the latter seems to slope down to the buried wall. Tips [i.e.“rubbish tips”] against a ruined building? -- rm 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]): work in W wing progresses, reveals pile of stones next to large ashlar block in N corner & very regular cut line in bedrock, parallel to line of stairs and in area of greater compaction identified in 2004. Some paleobotanical sampling, ongoing sieving. -- rm 38 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_580]): layer of most of articulated sherds removed; underneath are large patches of burnt wood, very poorly preserved. Samples of charcoal taken for C14 dating &/or wood id[entification]. Roughly linear features may indicate either structural wood or furniture. Oval feature ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]) along NW wall cleaned further; good evidence for presence of wood at corner to entrance ramp & under wall at N corner. Its floor surface is different from that in the rest of the room and will be excavated first, as the last event in the room before collapse. -- rm 33: ongoing removal of loose pebbly, gray-brown fill full of bones, ceramics, tile frags ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_572]). Seems to run very deep in E & center of room, except over stone concentration in N corner (& this is beginning to look like much the same fill, although with more stones). To the SW, a harder ground ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_636]) seems to rise along the bedrock & along the potential early wall along the SE wall of rm 33 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_567]). The large stone that I proposed yesterday as a post support now has a companion, and both are starting to look more like fill than post supports. [p.32: rough sketch of bedrock below floor surface of room 30]  [p.33] -- rm 30: work resumes on floor ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_677]) (hearth sampled yesterday, but then work stopped). Meant to be a 10cm pass for sieving & paleobot[anical]. sampling; goes somewhat deeper in the area of a possible pit in the middle SW side of the room. Another possible pit in E corner, & a square bedrock feature next to it. In area of SE doorway, bedrock just under remains of floor. (see sketch opposite). -- rm 38: patch of yellow soil visible in wall of cut for pen (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]). Suggested by Italo to be sulfur, possible association w[ith] metalworking in earlier phase? 292 2005-07-21 00:00:30 2005-07-21 00:00:30 closed closed 21-07-05 private 0 0 post 0 13th century 2005 courtyard Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 22/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=294 Fri, 22 Jul 2005 00:00:46 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=294 [Passage redacted] Backhoe continues to operate in fill around NE section wall in main street area. -- courtyard: cleaning down to bedrock complete in courtyard; in N corner, there seems to be a patch of decomposed bedrock & clay cut at a 90º angle on the outside & in a rough circle on the inside (by foundation trenches and a pit?) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_605]). Although it is above the level of the bedrock elsewhere, it seems to be sterile geological soil and will be left in situ. When the surface & sections are complete, we will extend a sounding across the width of the courtyard to the center of the cistern in an attempt to understand the relation between the slabs, tomb, various walls, etc. -- rm 37: still some confusion in excavation & some material might be coming from more than one layer. On the NW side of the new wall, the dark brown-gray fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_596]) continues down to a clean tan-brown level ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_619]) below the visible course of the wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_607]). The situation is slightly different on the SE side. There, the same fill was present but the brown layer below it was somewhat overcut, esp[ecially]. in the W corner, and the layer of orange soil and ash that seemed to be a hearth ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]) under the floor on the NE side was taken out together with darker fill and perhaps part of the same brown surface. A floor or surface level above the level of several flat rocks on top of the slabs seems to have been reached ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_639]); one tile lies flat and broken on this surface. In reaching the surface, however, several layers may have been removed at once. In the S corner is a hearth w[ith] charcoal and a deep deposit of white ash ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_638]) -- this is probably on top of the brown layer, or on top of an intermediary layer of dumping. Left until out of phase, so relationships confused. -- rm 31: removal of floor ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_367]) complete -- sieved almost entirely, except when Roma, Olga, and Katia stopped sieving because they weren't finding anything in the W wing. Under the floor (ca 15cm thick) are several new surfaces/layers. [p.34: upper part of page: sketch of layers under the floor of room 31; lower part of page: sketch of layers at NW end of room 38] [p.35] The most recent seems to be a level of gray-brown soil w[ith] similar characteristics to those of the floor, but softer, looser, and with more bone and stone visible on the surface ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_615]). It seems to fill a cut ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_667]) in a smooth, compact, tan-brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_618]) along its SE side. On the NE, there is a very regular rectangular platform that appears to be made of a very fine mortar or cement ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_617]). At the SE end of the staircase, we also find part of another wall with a NE-SW orientation ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_614]). A large ashlar block against the wall shared with room 30 may also belong to this wall, as may a concentration of stones next to it. (see sketch opposite). In the S wing, also seems to be a new surface/layer -- slightly irregular but more or less level, with large quantity of ceramics. -- rm 38: final cleaning of floor level in SE part of room, topography, photos. In NW side, floor of pit/pen begins to be removed, groove seems to be deeper than originally excavated. Surface comes down onto layer of soil mixed with degraded bedrock in area of entrance to area ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_602]) -- probably indicates the presence of moisture coming down bedrock cut for access. In N corner of room, quarter-circular pit with internal triangular void -- almost certainly on a posthole with a post mold (or post void) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_599]). Related to stair structure or upper floor, or to structure in association w[ith] pen? (see sketch opposite). -- rm 33: It is becoming increasingly apparent that all the various concentrations of stone and hard earth in this room are the products of one massive filling event: separate tips in a single action ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_636]). The distribution of the various areas is interesting, however, and we plan those levels & take spot heights. Large inclusions of plaster/stucco, some apparently with form, along NE wall. Deposit seems to be harder-packed, leading down from door in a sort of ramp -- Nick wonders if it might be from original filling activity (compressed as people walked in w[ith] buckets or wheelbarrows. (see sketch below). [sketch of fill layers in room 33] [p.36: blank] [p.37] -- streets: work moves back to tile collapse at NW end of stenopos ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_434]). Now that soil from 38 is being sieved, doesn't need wheelbarrow passage. Same as tile collapse in rest of street, perhaps a bit less thick/fewer tiles than at SE end. -- rm 37: afternoon: finish removal of hearth in S corner ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]), cleaning of next floor surface down. Sequence now seems to be, from earliest to latest: 1) slabs([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_666]) 2) some sort of spoliation/fill/collapse, w[ith] large stones lying on the slabs, some tile beneath (one stone very large, flat, worked[)] ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_660]) 3) construction of the new SW-NE wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_607]), with ground level of packed earth to SE higher than ground level of foundation & packed earth surface 4) destruction and spoliation of wall, dumping over SE floor, probably in pile rising to SW along SE side of wall 5) creation of hearth in S corner, w[ith] hot, long fire that left a great deal of powdery white ash([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_591]) 6) massive 13th c. trash dumping (similar to fill of rm 33, although more compact), over area of now-broken wall, on both sides, over lower areas of existing dump, and over top of deposits placed on that dump (e.g. the hearth) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_596] and [ark_link cxt=CH05SR_575]) 7) cutting of giant pit in middle of room, through both fill & collapse ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_430]) 8) filling of pit w[ith] trash/debris ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_431]) 9) construction of large, poorly made wall on top of both the gray compact fill & the fill of the pit([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_437]) 10) some sort of slightly different activity on both sides of the wall (courtyard & open area/alley? but wall closes it from courtyard) 294 2005-07-22 00:00:46 2005-07-22 00:00:46 closed closed 22-07-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 23/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=298 Sat, 23 Jul 2005 00:00:09 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=298 Backhoe continues to excavate in area of street; brings level up to meet level of road identified in trench. Will now turn to excavation of area of road to connect with road past museum. -- courtyard: extension trench to SW opened; some sequence of layers as in rest of courtyard, with gray soft soil on top ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_509]), hard gray soil with orange inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]), compact brown soil below that ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_550]). Small balk left between excavated area and new trench so that Pyotr can draw section. -- rm 37: foundation trench along SW walls of rm 30 & rm 31a identified ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_626]); rm 30 level seems to be right, but in 31a trench may have been identified w[ith] orange soil located along that wall at a higher level. Although trench makes one line, the two segments next to the two walls are very different, in both depth and fill. It seems likely that the wall of rm 30 was built first, with a deep foundation trench that ran slightly deeper and wider at the corner (to seat the quoining). The wall of rm 31a has a much shallower trench, and uses several stones from the earlier [p.38: blank] [p.39]  wall and from the collapse or fill to its SE. The situation elsewhere seems clearer, too -- a floor level in phase with the early wall, a use surface on which the hearth in the S corner was laid, and the fill above. The latter floor level ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_639]) begins to be removed today. -- rm 31: excavation and sieving of layer of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_615]) in W corner of the room continues; it will be followed by excavation of layer in SE wing. -- rm 38: ongoing excavation of fill in pit/pen ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]) at end of room; fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_621]) is mixed trash material, with slightly different soils on each side of the bedrock skin formed in the area of the entrance. Clearly still fill of the cut – walls continue to be soil of distinctly different color. Confusion in N corner, where softer soil in area of posthole determined to <be> extend further, but then limits lost and a chunk of floor surface, I strongly suspect, was excavated. Hard to say whether perception of softer soil was accurate, but very likely that current contours are not those of original floor. Material kept with number of floor/battuto in that corner. Excavation of floor surface in SE half of room begins ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_610]). -- stenopos -- final cleaning of surface finished ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_488]). Very well-preserved street surface with small cobbles, large quantities of animal bone pressed into the surface. -- rm 33: excavation of fill continues. In NE end of room, appears to come down onto more compact clean brown soil with ash & charcoal inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_647]); in this soil is set a large chunk of very chalky stucco molding ([ark_link sfi=CH05SR_3315]), which the conservators will lift. Many other pieces of this material have been found, usually with moldings or at least one flat face; one has a nail hole with a little iron left in it and what may be the remains of painting or surfacing. It is concentrated along the NE side, but fragments have also emerged from the ramp near the door. The fill also contains bricks from the opus mixtum Roman constructions across the street, some apparently burnt. Not clear if the wall along the SE edge is still a wall or another fill event, but soil is much harder. There is an ash-filled circular, small but deep hole near the door that I suspect is an animal burrow rather than a human construction (too deep & narrow to be tool-made). Mice burrowing in for the grain in the storeroom? 298 2005-07-23 00:00:09 2005-07-23 00:00:09 closed closed 23-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 _wp_old_date 2018-05-14 25/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=300 Mon, 25 Jul 2005 00:00:05 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=300 Entry written after end of work. Backhoe continues work -- removes section separating our excavated area & the main trench. Current plan is to clean surface of road up to monastery wall, then fill in w[ith] earth ramp from museum road covering linear mortar/cement feature. -- courtyard: orange-spotted gray soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]) removed; at lower level, covers a hard, smooth more yellowish soil running along line of 2nd wall associated w[ith] t. 4. This layer seems also to be cut (or to descend) along the same rough line, with a lower level of the same orange-spotted gray-brown soil to the NE ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_538]). The gray-brown soil is similar in its small-clump composition to Late Byz[antine] fills in other parts of the trench. [p.40: sketch of the hearth in room 37; sketch of ivory head of soldier from room 38 (flat plaque with attachment hole – inlay?)] [p.41]  -- rm 37: new developments -- removal of remaining fill in S corner reveals continuing presence of ash in that corner, now in a flat area with both white ash & burnt soil patches that seems to fill a space delimited by unbaked clay bricks ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_637]). These bricks seem to bound a roughly square space; one is clearly set vertically. Some discussion about relation to the floor identified at this level in the rest of the room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_639]), but seems in the end like the floor covers the structure, instead of the structure being cut into the floor. It is also possible that the layer removed above was, in fact, the same floor/surface level, and that it was removed as a separate level in the area of the stove (?). Work continues in the afternoon. (see sketch) -- rm 31: removal of rest of fill in W corner of room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_704]) -- comes down onto bedrock in that area, forming irregular shape with edge of mortar (?) surface along NE side. Probably some fill remaining under large rocks & pile of small rocks in E corner -- don't seem to be in situ, and soft brown soil with oyster shells continues beneath. -- rm 38: we begin removal of floor deposit in SE half of room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_610]); descends onto bedrock along its NW edge, onto piles of stones elsewhere in the room. Clean brown hard-pack below may be either fill level or earlier surface -- seems fairly irregular. In pit/pen ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]) excavation of layer of decayed bedrock near entrance ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_622]), levelling of other fills until seems to represent single unitary fill -- contents still suggest midden fill, fairly clean ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_668]) Good find in sieve today from this fill -- carved bone head of warrior w[ith] hole for attachment pin at neck -- from a late Roman/Early Byz[antine] box or furniture decoration? -rm 33: finally finished with fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_519]) -- comes down onto a clean brown layer with some ash ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_636]), very little inclusion of material other than small fragments of charcoal. Ash patch in N corner on top of small layer of slightly different material; will be removed separately. Piles of stones along SE and SW sides are clearly set in harder-packed lighter soil, but much fill mixed into cracks & open spaces. Not clear if these stones formed a packing or wall foundations for an earlier sunken-floor building or simply a particularly hard-packed moment of fill -- will attempt to determine tomorrow. -- main street: preliminary consultation with Chris C. indicates that we should remove rest of collapsing wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_582]); they'll consolidate what's left. Drawn & photo[graphe]'d in preparation for removal of partially collapsed wall. 300 2005-07-25 00:00:05 2005-07-25 00:00:05 closed closed 25-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard early byzantine late byzantine plateia Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 26/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=305 Tue, 26 Jul 2005 00:00:28 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=305 Much pit digging today – slow, slightly confusing, probably some layer confusion, especially in rms 30 & 37 (latter is very hard to read and very important, so again, certain amount of precision sacrificed for speed). -- courtyard: test trench to cistern reaches bedrock in NW half, no traces of slabs or any construction. Along SE side concentration of stones ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_671]) -- traces of a wall? Some stones in similar concentration to E actually partially covered by decayed bedrock skin -- standing open with bedrock for a long time? [p.42: upper part of page: sketch of bedrock cuts under floor of room 30; middle of page: sketch of bedrock cuts in room 31]  [p.43] -- rm 37: coming down gradually to slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_666]) -- today removed collapse of stones along NW & NE sides of area, arrived at level of slabs -- along NE wall, only bedrock w[ith] layer of clay, a couple of small flat stones; elsewhere slabs continue both to SW & to NW, with areas where only clay is present. Small areas of burning/ash patches along older wall along NW trench edge -- one concentration of fine, deep black ash, several other concentrations of gray ash with chocolate brown-orange borders. Mixes in with yellow clayey layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_660]), not treated separately. Clay-brick construction (of sorts) is left intact, but after today will be documented & removed ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_637]). -- rm 30: as in rm 32, bedrock "path" down center of room with filled cuts on either side. To SW, series of at least 3 cuts leading on diagonal into W corner; to NE one very large cut filled with soil ranging in color from gray-ash/orange-burnt-soil color to dark gray-brown ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_697]) (NB: though Anton S. could not identify a limit between the two and has treated them as one layer, they may have been distinct, with the gray-orange layer covering the other). In the E corner, a separate pit/cut filled with brown soil may be cut in turn by the cut filled by the gray-orange soil. That brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_678]) was removed at the same time as the gray-orange ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_640]), although as a separate context. The gray-orange appears to have covered it along the edge of the E corner; in turn, the dark gray-brown soil appears to cover a layer of fine, compact gray ash ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_677]). See sketch opposite. -- rm 31: bedrock uncovered in W wing under gray fill w[ith] bones ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_704]), along NW side; seems to be a slab or cut bedrock in W corner. Rest of shallow cut comes down onto same layer of hard light-brown fill along SE wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_618]); delimited to NE by layer of mortar/cement ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_617]); bedrock cuts in area of E corner, under large ashlar block (pit?). See sketch. -- rm 38: ongoing oddness -- in SE side of room, last-phase beaten-earth surface is removed to reveal irregular hard-packed surface with deep, narrow trench along limit with cut bedrock platform between street door & interior stairs ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_610]) . There are certainly animal burrows in the area of this trench, and it is not clear if the fill is loose & soft because a) it was disturbed by an animal along its whole length b) it was an area where a wooden partition or construction was seated or c) it was an area where the fill was packed less thoroughly because it was so close to the higher bedrock edge. In addition, in the center of the SE side of the room, on a line with the projecting stone construction near the E corner, there is a regular rectangular cut block surrounded by a ring of stones (and set on stones) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_659]). There is a slightly softer soil in this area, perhaps from the cut to seat this stone (seems intentional -- stones around it set deep & on edge). Potential interp[retation] -- post base? In the NW side of the room, the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]) continues to descend. The difference b[e]tw[een] the NE and SW sides continues, although at this point the fill is being removed as one context. The two slightly different areas are separated by a central hard-packed area, and consistently slope down to the sides, where a softer version of the same soil is present. Does this represent use for trash dumping/composting? But presence of animal bones -- in any case, someone seems to have consistently stood in the middle and dumped trash to the sides. [p.44: upper part of page: sketch of lower floor in bedrock cut in room 33; lower part of page: section drawing of room 33, looking to the SW] [p.45] 305 2005-07-26 00:00:28 2005-07-26 00:00:28 closed closed 26-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 27/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=307 Wed, 27 Jul 2005 00:00:29 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=307 Entry written after end of working day -- too busy. In afternoon, conservation & presentation decisions made -- will fill rooms w[ith] backfill, level of gray clay on top; experiment with uncovered side of courtyard w[ith] fill of clay on top of backfill, but clay covered w[ith] small gravel mixture when wet. Trash on low side of street cut removed, high side faced w[ith] clean earth from soil heap. Entry will begin w[ith] rm 33, will cover yesterday as well. -- rm 33: layer of fill comes down onto hard, clean surface with several irregularities ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_636]). In center, bedrock visible (higher than at sides). In N corner, cut down to bedrock and through floor -- vaguely circular but shallow; not very convincing as functional cut. Next to it along the NW wall is a patch of ash covering a thin layer of yellow soil that in turn covers the floor. Is this a short-term hearth? The packing along the NW wall is removed; a coin is found in its fill. Below this surface, on Weds., we expose a lower floor with a surface of soft, damp gray ash with charcoal inclusions & patches of brown and reddish brown ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_672]). When it is clean, four features are visible: 1) a Roman brick from the bath set flat on it against the SW bedrock cut; [2)]a circular brown patch on a line to the NW, about 50cm away; [3)] an irregular cut or disturbance along the same line, again 50cm away; and [4)] an area of cut floor/bedrock with a stone set in it against the floor side, in the same line. There is also a posthole(?) against the SE wall, roughly in its center. (see sketch) There may be a slight soil difference in the W corner, where in 36 there was a pit, but a limit is not visible in the floor. (see 28/7/05 for completion of this entry) 307 2005-07-27 00:00:29 2005-07-27 00:00:29 closed closed 27-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 Rabinowitz roman room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 28/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=309 Thu, 28 Jul 2005 00:00:12 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=309 Fell asleep before last night's entry could be finished. Will continue today with yesterday's entry, starting from courtyard and moving clockwise. [rp?]-- courtyard: pile of stones ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_671]) next to second wall face (to NW) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_682]) is removed; bedrock reached in test trench. NW face of t. 4 is also removed, found to be sitting on slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_719]) bounded by an earlier wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_682]) and ending roughly at the end of the overlying wall. The NW wall delimiting the slab area ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_682]) has been partially removed in antiquity, but more aggressive cleaning reveals more of its interior. The central stone in this wall has a circular hole and a notch at the top, both sloping down to SE & area of slabs; the larger hole is partially filled with a stone w[ith] its face even with the SE face of the wall, while the interior part of the hole and the channel on top are filled with brown silt. On the NW side, there are several bedrock cuts in the same area as this block -- possible connection with the cistern ([ark_link cxt=CH01PA_111])? The wall is built over the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_669]) of a deep bedrock pit to the W ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_670]), which seems to be the same pit covered by the slabs at the SW end of t. 4. The very regular circular edge of this pit is visible on the NW side of the wall, and the narrow ridge between this pit & the cuttings near the wall should indicate that there were two cutting phases -- one before the wall, one after or in conjunction with it. On a preliminary basis, the tomb seems to cut this construction, and the courtyard [p.46:upper part of page: sketch of plan and elevation of early wall next to tomb 4, bedrock cuts; lower part of page: plan of slabs, walls, and cuts in room 37, with elevation of SE wall] [p,47] probably destroyed the NW face of the wall & its connection w[ith] the cistern. See plan & elevation sketches opposite. -- rm 37: slabs entirely cleaned ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_666]); hearth removed. Seem to be a pavement, broken in places; Stas convinced that largest block is reused wine-pressing floor. Along SE side, 3 different walls (or maybe only 2). Latest is wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_693]) in association w[ith] closing of courtyard in last phase, partially destroyed by modern trench. Below that is another, under wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_692]) that seems to rest on soil above a third wall (narrower, but one face is on same line as wall just above in E corner). The third wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_692]) rests on a thin layer of abandonment over the slabs. Along the NE wall of the later block, the construction cut is cleanly visible. The yellowish hard-packed soil ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_660]) that covered the slabs at the lowest level seems to be a surface associated with the use of the first wall; the surface above (perhaps with the hearth?) may have been associated with the second wall (unless the second wall is simply a slightly different part of the first). We continue today on the SE side of the wall in the courtyard, where we encounter a layer of brown fill covering the same yellow surface that we associate with the first wall. Material seems to indicate a 4th-5th century date for that wall & surface which puts the slabs earlier (same time as cistern?). See sketch opposite. -- rm 31: [Passage redacted: gist is that sieving ceased, some stratigraphic confusion] Situation in W wing seems to involve some bedrock cuts ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_724])/([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_725]), pits of irregular size & shape w[ith] fills of brown-tan soil, same yellow hard-packed soil into which cut for gray fill was cut (yellow soil overlies bedrock) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_704]). In E wing, pass made over soil of current uppermost layer -- brown fill, as in other parts of room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_709]). About 10-15 cm removed. -- rm 38: pit finished ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]); came down onto harder packed gray-yellow soil not that different from rest of fill, but this one continued into pit wall & was clearly cut by pit hole. In SE side, removal of brown irregular hardpack ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_610]), which Italo now considers to be a surface; below it, loose dark gray-brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_649]) with tiles, etc. In some areas -- especially in N corner near the door -- concentrations of stones ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_711]) that may represent earlier structures (may also just be diff[erent] fill). Difference along SE wall continues -- another large stone in situ against wall under fill. -- rm 30: Yesterday, lowest floor cleaned ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_678]); in W corner of bedrock cut was a small oval hole containing the bones of a 6-7 mo[nth] fetus ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_679]). Floor itself removed today, down to bedrock. One piece of 13th century pottery near bedrock, but very small and is probably intrusion. Rest of material is 9th-10th. Room will close today. -- rm 33: cleaning this morning reveals 2 possible hearth features ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_695])/([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_696]) with gray ash and brown burnt soil, some seeds, charcoal, organic material. Photo[graphe]'d and sampled, then early floor ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_672]) removed down to bedrock. Possible connection w[ith] pit in rm 36 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_471]); bedrock channels ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_731]), possibly natural, and at least one possible posthole cut where cut was visible in middle of SE side ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_714]). Material seems to be quite clearly 10th c. We also remove last of packing/foundation/compact fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_654]) in W corner along bedrock cut; wall w[ith] tile course ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_661]) in front of door will have elevations & be photographed. [p.48: middle of page: sketch of slab from paving in room 37 from top and side, showing lifting slots on bottom; bottom of page: sketch of bedrock and cuts in room 31]  [p.49] 309 2005-07-28 00:00:12 2005-07-28 00:00:12 closed closed 28-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 courtyard early byzantine middle byzantine Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 tomb 4 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 29/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=311 Fri, 29 Jul 2005 00:00:02 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=311 Entry written next day -- too much running around. Work closes today; crane on site for overhead photos. Drives up main street, then up stenopos (tight fit but ok) for complex 2 photos, then back to main street for complex 3 photos. Crane cannot extend basket far enough to get good vertical shots, especially for rm 37, but height ok for rooms closest to street. -- rm 37: drawing holds up excavation; meanwhile, excavation of strip to SE of SE wall ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_692]), between walls & well cut. At N end, bedrock cut with vaguely circular form (but could be square) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_689]); to S, large rectangular block (part of pavement?) stretches into section from under wall. On the other side of this block, the wall seems to be in phase with a clayey yellow soil (as on the other side of the wall), below which is yellow-brown fill over bedrock. The end of a second slab ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_666]) is visible beneath the wall stones on this side. The fill on the other side of the NW wall is also excavated; two circular cuts (for pithoi?) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_691]) are visible stretching into the section wall. This wall sits on a level of yellow fill ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_660]) below which there are depressions filled with gray ash and covered by black ash or reddish burnt earth. Initially we felt that these walls, which were founded on different elements (one on the slabs, one on yellow-brown earth), were two different walls from two different phases. This idea was supported by the break in alignment of the NW face of the two walls. The other face, however, seems to be continuous and to follow the natural pattern of the slabs and ground. I now wonder if they are in fact one wall built over the irregularities of the landscape in that area. In the afternoon, after all has been photographed, we decide to lift one of the slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_666]). We start with a long rectangular block along the NE side, but it is cracked in the middle. We then move to a rectangular block along the NW, which is lifted intact. Below it is clayey bedrock with a thin layer of brownish soil -- sediment & bedding layer ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_716]), which produces a piece of tableware of uncertain date and one tiny fragment of 1st-2nd [century] AD high-quality Arretine terra sigillata. We begin to lift the largest slab, but stop when it becomes clear that this block, too, is cracked in the middle. See sketch of lifted block opposite. After this (this is late afternoon), excavation in this room is closed. -- rm 31: Mad dash at the end to get to a stopping point in this room, esp[ecially] in E wing. In W wing, large circular pit ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_727]) cut into bedrock emptied; in course of this work, it becomes apparent that the level of hard white "stone" visible across the middle of the room is instead a thick layer of eroded and reconcretized bedrock ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_717]) covering a deposit of yellow-brown fill representing a very good Hellenistic context ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_809]). A second look indicates that this area is delimited by very deep parallel cuts in hard bedrock on either side, leaving a sort of channel between ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_725])/([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_726]). See sketch opposite. In the E wing, near the blocked door to 38, removal of the surface left ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_616]) after the last pass reveals a hard-packed brown smooth floor level (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_713]). In it are three cuts: two relatively shallow subrectangular cuts ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_706]; [ark_link cxt=CH05SR_708]) and one very deep, roughly [p.50: blank] [p.51] circular cut with steep walls ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_710]). In the side of this cut another wall is visible -- composed of three visible stones set in a good line about 15 cm below that floor level. Once these are cleaned, we run out of time and excavation in this area is closed. -- rm 38: Also mad scramble to finish here -- pit ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_601]) is emptied down to bottom (1.3m deep ca.) as of yesterday, but I want to take off the pile of rocks in the N corner of the other 1/2 of the room ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_711]), and I also want to start removing what seems like a unitary layer of soft brown clumpy fill with stones & tile fragments ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_649]). Effort is not entirely successful -- we get about halfway through the fill, starting from the SE wall; the layer comes down onto an equally soft layer that is very distinct in color & composition ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_712]): very smooth thin layer of beige to red-brown soil with some charcoal. The benefit of this approach, however, is to reveal the bedrock and its cuttings in the S corner of the room -- so that situation, at least, is clear. Second looks also suggest that the bedrock platform in the center of the room is covered by a deposit of decayed bedrock. Probable that all of this is one fill episode, as in rm 33, but we won't know until next year. *NB: material from rm 33 c[onte]xts 630 and 640 (fill against SW wall and hearth in N corner) is mixed during washing/sorting -- all looks 9th-10th [century AD] unitary, but should be noted if either becomes crucial for dating. -- rm 33: removal of last bits of packing ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_661]) in doorway to 28, with tile levelling & "course"; removal of remaining bedrock fill in irregular channels ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_731]) at lowest level. The pit from rm 36 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_471]) does not seem to continue into this room, although the bedrock division under the wall between 33 & 36 does not exist in this area. There is a very smooth circular cut under the packing along the SW wall [of] the larger bedrock cut -- possible posthole ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_714])? While crane photos shot etc., bit of main road leading to monastery wall cleaned -- bedrock shelf appears along NW side of street. Bulldozer starts to finish w[ith] trash heap. Inventory in storage [shed] taken (tools etc.). 311 2005-07-29 00:00:02 2005-07-29 00:00:02 closed closed 29-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 hellenistic Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 33 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 30/7/05 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=313 Sat, 30 Jul 2005 00:00:41 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=313 Work closed in all rooms. Investigations in 31 & 38 will have to continue next year. Bulldozer (backhoe) moves a bit more trash, completed, paid, departs. Backfilling by hand begins -- in consultation with Chris Cleere, begin with simplest rooms (33, 36, 29). 29 and 36 are basically completely filled with soil, will await clay surfacing. 33 is much deeper, partially filled with soil but will need another 15-20 cm to reach original floor level with clay. At 1pm, site closed for the season. 313 2005-07-30 00:00:41 2005-07-30 00:00:41 closed closed 30-7-05 private 0 0 post 0 2005 Rabinowitz room 29 room 31 room 33 room 36 room 38 Trench notebooks _edit_last 7 19/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=362 Mon, 19 Jun 2006 19:54:20 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=362

In this transcription text will be referred to only by odd page numbers and even page numbers indicate graphic notes placed on the reverse.  Notes and additions during transcription are in italics in square brackets. The notebook contains both the season of 2005 & 2006]

[p. Title: Adam Rabinowitz Field Notebook for Excavations in South Region, June-July 2005 & June-July 2006]

[the 2006 season picks up on p. 52]

[p. 52: sketch of plan and elevation of wall between rooms 31 and 31a]

rm 38 -- 712 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_712]), w[ith] new layer next to 201([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_201]) (SE side of room)

rm 31: 713 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_713]) in W wing; 717 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_717]) is eroded bedrock; 617 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_617]) is hard plaster surface

2006

FIELD NOTEBOOK FOR ADAM RABINOWITZ

19 June 2006

First set of students & staff arrive (all but three students from Kyiv). Day starts late, is spent cleaning grass growth from spring & removing backfill from rooms 38, 31, 37. Stones laid over area near altar in chapel in 2002 are removed -- this includes stones in area of door (?) to main street, which Larissa remembers as conservation work.

362 2006-06-19 19:54:20 2006-06-19 19:54:20 closed closed 19-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 plateia Rabinowitz room 31 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks Uncategorized 20/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=365 Tue, 20 Jun 2006 19:55:45 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=365

Backfill removal continues, slowly. General orientation on recording system, bags, etc. I'm off site a lot for various meetings. We decide to remove the large standing stone in the wall between rms 31 & 31a, since it will be dangerous when we need to excavate in the large trench (see sketch opposite for original position -- stone was also on plan, in drawn elevation, and in conservation photos). Conservation cap on this wall removed.
