368 2006-06-21 19:57:47 2006-06-21 19:57:47 closed closed 21-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 Rabinowitz Trench notebooks Uncategorized 22/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=371 Thu, 22 Jun 2006 19:58:46 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=371

Teams established for initial work (until arrival of Kyiv students). Shawn & Anton, w[ith] Karissa & Olga, will work on courtyard. Dyma D., Sasha, & Caitlin will work in rm 31. Lea, w[ith] Ishan, Dyma M., & Emily will work in rm 38. Backfill removal continues. Room 38 is ready for excavation, which will begin with context 712 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_712]) (remaining fill under earliest 12th-13th c. floor levels). Soil from this layer will be sieved until we can determine if that strategy is useful. Layers above in this room were sieved for faunal purposes, with good results.

In courtyard, Shawn will begin from rm 37 -- sample trench cut on SE side of SE wall over slabs. His team will then move toward the cistern. The initial stage will be an expansion of the existing trench toward the well in order to clear one side for the construction of a smaller cover [for the well] resting on bedrock.

Final removal of backfill from rm 31 completed after lunch. General checking & correction of 2005 documentation.

371 2006-06-22 19:58:46 2006-06-22 19:58:46 closed closed 22-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 37 room 38 Trench notebooks Uncategorized 23/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=374 Fri, 23 Jun 2006 20:00:15 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=374

Rain again during the night -- first part of morning spent on lecture for students, documentation checking for staff. By 8:30, dry enough to work in rm 38, where 712 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_712]) still being removed & sieved. Stone projecting from wall on stenopos side is removed, together with the earth platform on which it sits -- taken as 712 as well.

cont.

[p. 54: plan of layers of fill in S half of room 38]

[p. 55]

We are experimenting with a different method to capture surface topography & georeference photographic information -- using Photomodeller 5.2 in conjunction with total-station survey. The courtyard and room 31 are both subject to this before excavation begins.

In rm 31, excavation begins with 713 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_713]) in the E wing. The soil is a light yellow-brown color, fairly smooth & compact; it seems to occupy the entire area exposed in the E wing. Soon after excavation, along the blocking wall between this room & room 34, it is seen to come down onto a clayey tan-yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_747]) that seems to slope down to the NW quite steeply.

In rm 38, more of the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_712]) in the E corner of the room is removed, under the area of the large stone. There is a large pile of stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_711]) in this corner, and although the concentration seems distinct, the soil that fills it is similar to the rest of 712. Larissa thinks it might be a different soil altogether, but we both agree that it forms part of the same filling event (fills of different composition, as in rm 33 last year). Several of the pieces of pottery are clearly identifiable as 2nd 1/2 of 9th-early 11th c.

-- courtyard geophoto vs photogram[metry] test -- begun 11:38 am

1st end: 12:02 pm (rain)

begin again: 12:39pm            ;   stop: 1pm

374 2006-06-23 20:00:15 2006-06-23 20:00:15 closed closed 23-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 34 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks Uncategorized 24/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=377 Sat, 24 Jun 2006 20:01:05 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=377

-- geophot test cont: begin 7:35           & nbsp;          end photo 8:12

* but: interruptions for work flow in other trenches; interruptions for ATR stratigraphic discussions w[ith] other areas; interruption for dead battery at 8:12, so actual time for shots on last photo means stop at 8:40

Also: work held up for Shawn's team for entire duration listed above, although some of that time used for stratigraphic discussion.

In room 38, last of 712 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_712]) is removed. In the center of the room, it descends to a gray layer with a concentration of fine white-gray ash in the S corner of the layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_754]). It is surrounded by a dark brown layer of soft, friable soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]). Both layers contain large quantities of animal bone, ash & carbon, ceramics. (seek sketch opposite). Initially we thought that the ashy layer was the top of a pile covered by the brown layer, but further investigation showed the gray layer to lie on top of the brown layer. Yesterday Dyma M. defined what seemed to be the edge of a pit in the E corner of the room, under the pile of rocks under the protruding rock we removed. I think, however, that the "pit" is artificial -- the product of the removal of a concentration of rocks in that area. All of these layers, it seems almost certain, are products of the same simultaneous fill action.

[p. 56: upper part of page: sketch of the layers in the E wing of room 31; lower part of page: section of the layers at the N end of the courtyard]

[p. 57]

24 June 2006 cont.

In room 31, at the SE end of the E wing, 713 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_713]) comes down on a hard-packed clayey light brown soil with frequent bedrock & ceramic inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_749]). Over this, against the lowest course of the early wall that has now appeared in this area, is another small patch of yellow clay with charcoal inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_747]). There is some confusion about the extent of the hard-packed soil (a work surface for the 12th-c. construction phase?), which may have been slightly overexcavated at the edge of the small pit next to the larger one; but Dyma & Sasha are sure that 713 came down directly onto a smoother, darker brown layer below in the area of the stairs, and that 749 was absent there (see sketch opposite). There is a small subrectangular cut in the S corner of 749, filled with a soft dark brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_751]).

In the courtyard, Shawn removes a large stone set in the ground at the edge of Dyma's old sondage; we conclude that this stone, and the softer brown soil in which it is set, are probably a lower layer of fill of the trench excavated in 2001-2002. This suspicion is confirmed by the discovery of a fragment of cannonball of Crimean War date found at the bottom of this fill. It seems likely that the trench itself is not a drainage trench but a slit trench from the 1850s or 1940s -- this would explain its depth & the effort that was made to break through the existing walls. Beneath the fill is a yellow clayey layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_702]).

Experiments with Photomodeller continue -- still not quite up to speed, but getting there.

Noon -- site tour begins, supervisor by supervisor.

377 2006-06-24 20:01:05 2006-06-24 20:01:05 closed closed 24-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 11th-12th century 2006 courtyard modern Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 26/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=380 Mon, 26 Jun 2006 20:02:42 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=380

In room 38, 754 (gray ashy fill) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_754]) is removed after having been drawn. Context is sieved.

In courtyard, uppermost level of soil in new section area is removed. In the E, it has already been partially removed -- it is a compact soil varying in color from dark tan to ashy gray, with frequent charcoal inclusions and small stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_752]). It seems to cover the slightly more friable yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) that Dyma exposed over the slab in this area. On a second trowelling, however, it seems that the tan soil may be a separate layer overlying a gray ashy soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_755]), which in turn covers Dyma's yellow layer (see sketch opposite). Here, too, after the extension of the edge of the trench cut identified in 2002, Allyson draws in the new limit -- we will need to adjust the plan accordingly.

In room 31, topo surface of uppermost layers (747, 749, 751) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_747]/[ark_link cxt=CH06SR_749]/[ark_link cxt=CH06SR_751]) taken as temporary solution until photogram can be worked out. Then the fill of the small pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_751]) and the clay layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_747]) are removed.

The remainder of 754 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_754]) is removed in Rm 38, leaving a roughly square depression in the surrounding loose, crumbly brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]). The brown soil is cleaned for a photo in preparation for its removal. Fill contains a well-preserved coin

[p. 58: top of page: sketch of a coin of Basil and Constantine from room 38 fill; below that, sketch of the layers in E wing of room 31; middle of page: section of layers in courtyard; below that, sketch of cuts and layers in W wing of room 31]

[p. 59]

with a monogram, perhaps of Constantine and Basil (9th c.?) (see quick sketch of legible face opposite). When brown soil is cleaned, will be removed (753).

In room 31, 751 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_751]) is removed, revealing rough pieces of bedrock (or stones); the pit seems to have served for the placement of another stone, perhaps as part of the leveling activity. 749 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_749]) is removed over bedrock and over the smoother, more compact dark-brown surface/layer 756 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_756]). This layer has a large quantity of articulated sherds lying more or less flat in its upper reaches. Bedrock cuts along the NW and SW sides are now visible; at least one angle matches the cut along the SW side of room 38 (see sketch opposite). 756 also contains several pieces of plaster, concentrated at the S end of the E wing -- these pieces are bright red and dark yellow in color, with a very fine and smooth painted surface and a hard, even preparation layer levigated with small, smooth stones. This is initially shot as an architectural sample but then changed to be a small find ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3430]), so that it can be sent to conservaton. Similar plaster fragments were recovered from room 33? and 31? last year.

In courtyard, the soft brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_757]) with ceramics that seems to be level with the courtyard is removed on both sides of the well. To the SW, it comes down onto a very ceramics-rich layer of slightly different brown soil near the well ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_758]), which rests in turn on yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) that extends all the way to the wall of complex 1. It also seems to be under the ashy soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_755]) to the NE (see sketch opposite).

380 2006-06-26 20:02:42 2006-06-26 20:02:42 closed closed 26-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard middle byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 27/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=383 Tue, 27 Jun 2006 20:04:04 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=383

In the courtyard, Shawn & co remove the gray ashy layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_755]) at the N end of the sounding, expositing the yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) across the width of the trench. Along the wall of room 30, there may be the fill of a foundation trench, although they have not yet defined any clear boundaries.

In room 38, work continues on removal of 753 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]), with moments of confusion about areas of different consistency, piles of rocks, wetter or darker soil, etc. It seems clear that these are inconsistencies due to the filling event itself, as we saw in room 33 and elsewhere. It also seems probable that this layer represents one filling event with individual dumps of slightly different composition. Some detail photos are taken of individual groups of cut wall stones in the fill -- the stones are concentrated largely along the walls of the cut and under the wall between the room and the stenopos. The fill here also includes small pieces of plaster, here painted solid yellow.

In room 31, hard-packed brown layer 756 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_756]) continues to be removed. It seems to be deeper at the SE end of the E wing; about 1.5m from the SE wall, another smooth, lighter, compact surface (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) seems to emerge under it. In the W wing, the mortar floor or patch next to the stairs is cleaned, revealing a circular hole ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_776]) near the SE corner of the stairs. It is not clear if this layer continues under the stairs. The two holes already present in the eroded bedrock surface line up roughly with this new hole, suggesting to Larissa that they may all be postholes associated with a wooden construction. (see sketch opposite)

[p. 60: sketch of section of layers in courtyard on the 27th and 28th of June]

[p. 61]

27 June cont.

Anton, Kristina and Yura open a 1m wide trench across the stenopos, running from the wall of rm 35 to the trench cut for the electric cable. They remove the final layer of the street, uncovering a shallow, narrow strip of compact brown soil along the wall of room 35 and a very clear underlying surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_767]). The underlying surface varies in color and composition from a dark reddish-brown, with large chunks of burnt brick, ash, and metal slag, along the sides and a lighter grayish-yellow green color with clay lumps in the middle. The burnt ceramics seem to cover the lighter clayey layer, which may be associated with the construction of the box drain that we assume is present here as well as downslope.

In room 38, fill 753 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]) seems to come down onto a smoother, less rocky, fairly even layer of dark brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_768]). Too early to tell if this is a surface. Large quantity of nails.

In room 31, the floor (?) of coarsely levigated mortar near the stairs is removed. Work continues on removal of hard-packed dark tan-brown layer in E wing ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_756]).

In courtyard, situation becomes clearer. Along NE side of the trench, there is a softer brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_762]) which seems to fill a cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_763]) in the yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) currently being removed. This cut -- parallel to the wall, ca 50cm wide -- is almost certainly a cut for the foundation trench of room 30. On the other end of the sounding, however, the yellow layer seems to be uninterrupted, although the wall of complex 1 extends well below its surface. It is possible that the latter wall sits in a slit trench or against the very edge of a foundation trench in the yellow layer, & hence the foundation cut is no longer visible. If this is not the case, we might have a phasing problem.

383 2006-06-27 20:04:04 2006-06-27 20:04:04 closed closed 27-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard Rabinowitz room 30 room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 28/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=386 Wed, 28 Jun 2006 20:05:21 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=386

Questions for photos: was 31a down to bedrock? Was sondage beyond room 37 down to bedrock? answers -- no and no

In courtyard, Shawn & co. remove the rest of yellow fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]). In the SE end, it becomes clear that 759 covers the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_770]) of a pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_771]) that is subsequently cut by the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_763]); this early cut also cuts a harder, more compact yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) that seems to have accumulated around the slabs after they began to be robbed (see sketch opposite).

In room 31, it is determined that the irregular bedrock edge along the outside of the wall of room 30 is actually another skim of decayed bedrock ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_775]), perhaps created in the context of the construction of the 12th-13th c. building complex. It covers and mixes a bit with the surface of 749 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_749]) and also seems to cover 756 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_756]). 756 has now been removed, revealing another compact brown soil -- 764 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) -- with an irregular surface rising to the SW and sloping off steeply towards the course of stones along the NE side of the room.

In room 38, fill 753 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]) continues to be removed -- ceramics, large cut building stones, nails, a well-preserved coin of Constantine & Basil (as previous, but much more legible).

In the street [i.e. the stenopos], the soft brown soil previously identified as a side-walk turns out to be the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_766]) of a foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_769]) (?) along the wall of room 35. The trench is about 25cm wide and 25cm deep; it seems to be cut in the surface below the topmost surface. This is unexpected, since we assumed that more

[p. 62: middle of page: sketch of features in E wing of room 31; bottom of page: sketch of features in room 38]

[p. 63]

road surface would have been deposited in the time after the block was constructed. If these relations are accurate, and if the trench does not have some other explanation, we may have some questions about phasing.

I'm having second thoughts about the Crimean War trench (ed. note: this trench running across the courtyard and room 25 was identified as modern by Paul Arthur's team in 2002: [ark_link cxt=CH02PA_171], [ark_link cxt=CH02PA_173]), mainly because a second set of concrete bases for fenceposts run right behind it. This concrete looks just like that used for the fenceposts along the massive bank & ditch behind the site -- we take some points to check against the plan & photo.

386 2006-06-28 20:05:21 2006-06-28 20:05:21 closed closed 28-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 13th century 2006 courtyard middle byzantine modern Rabinowitz room 31 room 35 room 37 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 29/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=389 Thu, 29 Jun 2006 20:06:39 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=389

In the street, the yellowish strip down the middle gets its own number ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]); Anton decides it fills a cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_779]) in the reddish surface of the earlier road ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_767]), and removes it first. As anticipated, it comes down onto the cover slabs of the box drain ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_489]).

In room 38, what seemed to be a brown hard-packed surface over the yellower beaten earth ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_784]) below turns out to be -- we think -- a more compact trampled part of 753 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]). There is still a patch of gray ashy soil in the same place as there was in the layers above, and although it is distinct from the brown by color, its interface is unclear. Both layers have large crumbs, voids, and lenses of especially soft or loose soil, as well as jumbled ceramics and large quantities of animal bone -- characteristic of fills. Although we may be confusing a final surface in this room (or removing it), I am almost certain, on the basis of the lack of compaction and the general quality of the soil, that we are still dealing with mixed fill.

In room 31, Dyma et al. continue to remove the thick, compact dark brown-medium brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) in which (under which?) a large chunk of brick & mortar wall with plaster surface was found yesterday. Dyma feels that this chunk occupies a small pit, which he begins to define. The surface into which the pit is cut, however, remains unclear. (see sketch opposite)

In the courtyard, the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_770]) of the large pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_771]) in the bedrock is removed and sampled. The hard yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) is cleaned in preparation for removal.


In room 31a, I start some cleaning in preparation for further excavation.

In room 38, excavation also begins in the cut along the SW side of the room. There are two separate semicircles along the edge of this cut; the southern ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_729]) seems to be filled with a hard clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_780]), while the upper level of the NW cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_901]) seems to be filled with a softer, looser brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_781]). The two fills are, for the moment, recorded as separate contexts. Still a bit of confusion in the excavation process, with some trampling, some recleaning, etc.

389 2006-06-29 20:06:39 2006-06-29 20:06:39 closed closed 29-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 31a room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 30/6/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=392 Fri, 30 Jun 2006 20:07:50 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=392

Left site yesterday early -- rundown from time while I was absent is: rm 38: ongoing removal of 753 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_753]), complete; clayey layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_784]) in E corner is actually the skim just above bedrock; more fill beneath 753, still w[ith] gray in center of room, given #785 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785])

[p. 64: blank]

[p. 65]

30 June 2006 cont.

also hard layer in W corner given #784 [ed. note: this is probably a mistake for [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_768]] / rm 31: work stops for consolidation & removal of plastered wall frag [from [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]] / rm 31a: remaining surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_405]) cleaned / courtyard: fill of pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_770]) completely removed, yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) covering slabs removed, determined that in Dyma's 2005 trench bedrock was reached / in stenopos, fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]) of trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_779]) for installation/repair of drain removed, cover slabs of drain cleaned ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_489])

So: beginning morning of 30 June:

In room 38, the lower fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) begins to be removed. Work also continues on the removal of the harder fill in the larger semicircular cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_729]) visible under the buttressed wall -- dark brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_790]) seems to come down onto a sandier, yellow-tan soil that rises up under the wall [ed. note: not distinguished from 790 in subsequent excavation].

In the courtyard, the yellow hard soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) under the slabs (?) is cleaned. It seems to me that this is the same soil that we found used to level bedrock under the slabs in rm 37 last year; Shawn has given it a new number, but we will probably make it equivalent/same as. This is the last layer above bedrock here.

In the stenopos, the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]) of the trench for the drain is removed to reveal the cover slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_489]) and, in the irregular areas left between them and the edges of the trench, a loose fill of medium to small stones and some ceramic fragments with many voids & very little soil matrix. This seems to be the initial stage of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]) the cover of the drain, so it is removed before the cover will be lifted.

Backfill is removed over the slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_666]) in rm 37.

In room 31a, the uppermost layer left in 2004 begins to be removed. Samples are taken for paleobotanical analysis. It seems to come down onto a dark to medium brown layer with large crumb and many ceramic and bone fragments -- fill again? ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_405])

In courtyard, rethink of yellow layer -- along the well there is a lighter hard-pack with mortar inclusions that seems much more similar to the bedding soil under the slabs in 37. A glance at the pottery from the yellow layer now being removed shows a date in the 6th-7th c.  -- so this soil is equivalent to the soil that was above ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]), and can be related to manipulations of the area during or after the robbing of the slabs -- creation of Early Byz[antine] use surface?

Gone from site again for most of late morning. Apparently little happened in street; highest layer in rm 31a removed, some modern contamination (cigarette butts); ongoing removal of lower fill in room 38 (continues below hard-packed surface in W corner of cut, so probably one event); removal of hard clay & bedrock (& mortar/plaster?) packing layer below level of stones in courtyard, preparation for section drawing.

392 2006-06-30 20:07:50 2006-06-30 20:07:50 closed closed 30-6-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard early byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 31a room 37 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 01/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=394 Sat, 01 Jul 2006 20:09:23 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=394

In street, removal of sediment ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_791]) in drain ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_489]) begins. All soil is collected for flotation, with sample points taken after each pass/bag. A new layer of dense, more compact soil is reached beneath the upper deposit of small pebbles, faunal material, and small soil crumb.

In room 31, work resumes in area of wall fragment, now lifted by conservators. Yesterday 765 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_765]) --a layer of light brown, dry hard soil that lay under the mortar floor/patch next to the stairs. [was removed?]

[p. 66: upper part of page: sketches of various cut/fill stratigraphic situations (discussion with trench supervisor in room 31); lower part of the page: sketches of two different interpretations of stratigraphic sequence in SE section of E wing of room 31]

[p. 67]

1 July 2006 cont.

This soil covered the layer of decomposed bedrock/work surface visible in the rest of the room ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_717]). In the E wing, the medium-brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) in which the plaster & mortar wall fragment was found also contains a large quantity of Late Roman pottery (amphorae etc.), some in fairly large articulated sherds.

In room 38, the very large sub-ashlar block is removed, as is the lens (?) of hard-packed soil in the W corner. The rest of the layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) seems to contain a large quantity of medium-sized quarry stones, frequently with very little soil as a matrix. The quantity of stones seems to be somewhat greater than in the fill above, although the soil itself is more or less identical.

Work pauses for section drawing in the courtyard. Team moves to shed to move metallurgical samples.

394 2006-07-01 20:09:23 2006-07-01 20:09:23 closed closed 01-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 03/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=397 Mon, 03 Jul 2006 20:11:08 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=397

Previous entry probably not complete, but can catch up -- not too much new.

In stenopos, second surface of street ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_767]) is removed, revealing what seems to be a destruction level ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_796]) with large pithos fragments w[ith] evident traces of burning lying flat on what may be an earlier street surface. The fragments include a rim, and in and around them are frequent pieces of charcoal. They seem odd as a street surface, especially since the fragments seem to be related to a single vessel or vessel type.  They seem to rest on a lower (street?) surface that is more compact ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_797]). Although we initially thought this might be a cobble surface based on broken ceramics, the uniformity of the extent of the broken sherds, the traces of burning, and the relatively unworn edges of the pottery suggest it was not used as a street surface.

In room 38, excavation of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) in larger cut continues, with no sign of change. Soil continues to be sieved. Layer on other side of bedrock spit is cleaned from detritus accumulated over the year -- it seems to be 606 ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_606]) from CH05, although a squarish cut in the N corner is no longer visible. It is possible that 606 was removed without documentation, since one plan indicates that bedrock (or the decayed bedrock layer?) was reached in this area.

In room 31, layer 764 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) continues to be removed -- in the S corner, it comes down onto a yellow-white-gray layer of clayey ash and charcoal fragments ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_795]), over which sit several tiles lying flat, apparently on a surface. Looking at the section that has been left under the wall [the wall separating room 31 from room 25/34] it seems less likely that there were two pits than that there was one pit with a fill that spilled up over its lip and rose in a sloping heap against the wall. This would explain why the first cut identified seemed to grow wider with every pass. The tiles visible on the lower surface, under & in 764, seem to be early Byz[antine]. A lamp with traces of burning, almost whole, was found in this layer.

In the courtyard, the surface of the court is cleaned back. It is a fairly deep cleaning -- 2-4cm -- and I am worried that the final-phase surface has been removed, but Shawn feels that the soil removed was only recent accumulation. He also feels that this soil is very different from the last surface in the rest of the court -- little metal waste, lighter color.

[p. 68: rough sketch of plaster molding on block lifted from E wing of room 31; more detailed sketch on p. 70]

[p. 69]

397 2006-07-03 20:11:08 2006-07-03 20:11:08 closed closed 03-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard early byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 04/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=399 Tue, 04 Jul 2006 21:22:36 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=399

In stenopos, layer of collapse (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_796]) is removed to reveal a very clear cobbled street surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_797]). The material seems to belong to the 2nd 1/2 of the 9th-11th c., at least on a preliminary reading.

In room 38, same dark brown crumbly damp fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) continues down. Work begins on removal of top layer on other side of bedrock "wall" -- could be 606, last layer recorded here last year, or could be accumulated sediment from the winter, or could be a layer not identified last year. In any case, assigned CH06SR0606 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_606]), since that number was still open.

In room 31, Dyma & co. continue to remove 764 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]), which seems to have a very consistent 6th-7th c. date. It lies over an ashy clay surface, on which a number of tiles are lying flat ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_795]). In the W corner are fragments of a pithos and a bit of clay that seems to have served (for Dyma) as a stand for that pithos.

In room 31a, Sasha continues to remove the brown fill 794 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_794]). It seems to fill an irregular depression, along the sides of which decayed bedrock slopes down to the center. It is unclear if this decayed bedrock is equivalent to the layer in the trench in 31, but it does seem sometimes to contain ceramics & bone.

In the courtyard, Shawn & co remove the second surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_752]) in the morning (no photomodel made, but topo surface taken of next surface). They then begin to remove the next layer down ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_755]), which seems to contain some quantity of ash & charcoal & a large amount of ceramics. At the other end of the church, Renata & Rose & Kathleen start to excavate the area between the tombs & the apse, where a large number of disarticulated bones are visible. The soil in which they lie seems mixed, with no clear evidence for a specific cut. It is removed as a single context ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]). In it are found a bronze pendant ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3613]) [ed. note: actually a book clasp] [and a large fragment of stucco molding (church decoration) that seems to depict circles or foliage ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3611])]*** [the brackets and asterisks are explained on the following page, where it is noted that this seems to confuse the large piece of masonry with egg-and-dart molding from room 31 with some smaller pieces of stucco molding from the church fill]

399 2006-07-04 21:22:36 2006-07-04 21:22:36 closed closed 4-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard early byzantine middle byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 31a room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 05/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=401 Wed, 05 Jul 2006 21:26:41 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=401

No writing until after noon. I was digging in rm 31, W wing, removing "bedrock" layer 717 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_717]) The layer is composed of a hard bedrock skim, dissolved and reconstituted as the bedrock edges of the cut stood open to the air. It contains fragments of ceramics of the late Hellenistic & possibly the early Roman period, as well as bones, a large quantity of seashells, and an unexpected quantity of charcoal. Much of this material may actually have been pulled up from the brown-tan layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_809]) below, which has patches of burning and large quantities of bone & ceramics.

In room 31, the tile & pithos fragments on the lowest beaten-earth surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_800]) under 764 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_764]) are removed. In the W corner of this area, under a pithos fragment, is a jug or amphora, the mouth of which was covered by the fragment. Samples are taken of the loose brown soil inside; the pot seems to have been sunk into the floor, and its contents may be original.

In room 38, the larger square pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_728]) continues to descend; in the lower reaches is a fragment of late 10th-11th c. polychrome Constantinopolitan white ware. On the NW side in the N corner, excavation of the uppermost surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_606]) continues. In the N corner, where

[p. 70: middle of page: sketch from memory of cornice block with stylized egg-and-dart stucco molding, with caption "*although I originally wrote that this is from the church, it is in fact the large fragment with brick backing from ROOM 31 -- the church frags were all scrollwork & acanthus decoration"; below this, a sketch of the SE stratigraphic section in the stenopos; below this, a sketch of the top plan of room 38]

[p. 71]

5 July 2006 cont

a pebble construction was identified in 2005, some sea-worn pieces of pottery continue to be found. Elsewhere in this area, the surface comes down onto an orange-tan layer with traces of burning ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_810]).

In the courtyard, the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_763]) of the wall of 30 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_265]) is found to continue. Earlier stratigraphy may have to be amended, however -- it seems already to be visible in the second surface of the courtyard, and it also seems to be filled with at least two and perhaps three separate levels of fill. Its outline is irregular -- widens to a square roughly 50cm on a side at the N corner of the current area of excavation. The soil from the foundation trench begins to be excavated.

In the street, the previous surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_797]) under the ceramic destruction ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_796]) is excavated, revealing another surface with larger stone cobbles packed in a yellow clay bedding ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_803]). On the SE side of the box drain that surface is almost entirely worn away, perhaps through heavier traffic (though it's also possible that it was slightly overexcavated). On this side the bedding layer is clearly visible.

In the church last night, the conservators consolidated & lifted a piece of molded stucco cornice about 40cm long and 25cm wide, with a strange semi-ovolo molding (see sketch opposite)** [note again here that this is inaccurate: stucco moldings were lifted from the church, but they were not the large fragment with the ovolo molding]. Conservators are now working on another large fragment, perhaps a pilaster capital w[ith] acanthus decoration. Anthropological excavation in this area has ceased -- apart from the skull removed yesterday, the human bones seem to have petered out in the lower level.

401 2006-07-05 21:26:41 2006-07-05 21:26:41 closed closed 05-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard hellenistic Rabinowitz roman room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 06/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=406 Thu, 06 Jul 2006 21:29:59 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=406

-- Entry in fieldbook written in afternoon -- digging in rm 31a during the day, plus tour for Nicholas Stanley-Price.

In street, early surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_802]) above yellow preparation fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_803]) is removed; yellow fill itself begins to be removed. Soil seems to be close to bedrock, many large stones, deep deposit -- maybe major road reworking (see sketch opposite for current stratigraphy). This seems to come down on another use surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_818]), although by the end of the day only a little bit on the SW side has been revealed. Not yet clear how far from bedrock this layer is.

In room 38, the dark brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) continues. In the W corner of the trench, it comes down on a very distinct patch of gray ash with a greasy texture and charcoal inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_808]). This ash is photographed in conjunction with the edge of a large stone ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_820]) on which it sits, but it does not get a layer photo.  The stone itself seems to sit in more fill, since cleaning reveals a void below & between it and some adjoining stones in the fill. There is a hard patch along the SW side of the room which seems to be delimited to the NE by a line (layer?) of friable yellow clay below the brown fill -- not yet clear if this is a separate layer bounded by a cut. (see sketch opposite). The ash is removed by the end of the day -- it seems to be a relatively thin layer. On the other side of the bedrock ridge, in the N corner of the room, 606 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_606]) continues to be removed. In the area where the pebble-and-sea-ceramic "surface" was found, a large number of ceramic fragments worn by the sea continue to be found. Below this layer appear two new layers -- one is a very distinct deposit of charcoal and yellow powdery lumps that C[hris] S[alter] id[entifie]'s as potassium sulfate, an iron corrosion product ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_831]). This seems to sit on top of a hard-packed brown surface in the very N corner ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827]).

[p. 72: middle of the page: sketch of the top plan of the layers in the N part of the courtyard trench; below, sketch of Hellenistic stamped amphora handle and stamp -- Αθαναιου εις εμπορι[... ]

[p. 73]

6 July 2006 cont.

At the same time, on the other side of the final-phase pit, Ishan begins to remove an equivalent deposit of 606 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_606]). There, however, the two new layers are not in evidence, and all the soil seems to be the same brown fill. Visible in the section under the final-phase staircase, and probably removed in 2005, is a thin layer of red soil with on its surface an even thinner layer of ash & charcoal. This is almost certainly a burnt patch from a fire, though whether it was a hearth or a single event is unclear [ed. note: apparently never documented stratigraphically; no context number in database]. It also seems to represent a phase before the interior stairs were constructed.

In room 31, further cleaning of the tile and floor/surface deposit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_795]) of the 6th c. reveals that the structure in the S corner is, as in 37, a layer of greasy gray ash sitting on top of a clay construction. This construction seems to sit on (be set in?) a lower, more regular surface with an ashy gray-brown color & many charcoal inclusions ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_811]). It is possible that the layer above was abandonment or destruction, and that this is the actual 6th c. floor surface.

In room 31a, I excavate the layer of mixed soil & decayed bedrock ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_807]) over real (?) bedrock. The latter has an irregular, pitted, and heavily eroded surface that slopes down from three sides to the middle. As far as I can see there is no trace here of the massive cut that is visible on the other side of wall 399 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_399]). What little pottery there is seems to suggest a late date (glazed fragments).

In the courtyard, Shawn begins to remove the material from the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_763]) of the walls along the NE side of the NW segment of the courtyard. The first level of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_762]) seems to have been distinct, and one fill episode seemed yesterday to cut another. The boundaries bore no relation to the wall segments, however, and this idea seems difficult (see sketch opposite). It was clear, however, that in the horizon between the 1st ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_762]) and 2nd ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_804]) fills (?), there was a large patch of ashy soil containing plaster and large intact animal bones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_805]). This fill occupied a wider area at the NW end of the construction trench, and did seem fairly clearly to lie over the softer brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_804]) in the rest of the foundation trench. Over the rest of the area, the second level of surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_757]) is removed down to the yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) that covered the area on the other side of the section wall. The surface of this layer is more irregular -- in the center of the court, it seems to dip down, either as the result of a cut or naturally. The layer above fills this depression or cut as well (no separate fill context can be identified). Although there does seem to be a clear edge along the NE side, the lack of a cut edge on the other side suggest to me that this is a natural slope rather than an artificial one. Along the wall of complex 1, Karissa also finds a new feature -- a lump of yellow-orange clay or bedrock marl that is initially taken to be cut by something but later thought perhaps to be a structure, or part of one, buried beneath the current layer.

No work in the church today.

In W wing of room 31, Sasha finishes removing the decayed bedrock layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_717]). Among the finds from the yellow fill below that rock ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_809]) is a stamped Hellenistic amphora handle of Chers. manufacture (see sketch opposite).

406 2006-07-06 21:29:59 2006-07-06 21:29:59 closed closed 06-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard early byzantine hellenistic Rabinowitz room 31 room 31a room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks _edit_last 3 08/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=409 Sat, 08 Jul 2006 21:32:11 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=409

In the street, the yellow fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_803]) on the NE side comes down onto what seems to be a layer of charcoal and burnt soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_818]) similar to the layer on the SW side. This morning the remains of the brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_778]) for the construction trench of the drain are also removed. The burnt surface seems to cover another thin deposit of yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_836]) that in turn covers bedrock.

In room 38, the odd yellow patch ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_831]) is further cleaned -- the ash, charcoal patches, and mixed yellow & orange material is assigned its own context number ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_810]), since the yellow material clearly forms a single, clean, consistent patch beneath it. This patch -- bordered with the same rust-colored material as was visible above -- is sampled, documented, and removed as a unit. Under it seems to be an ashy layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_839]) (by the step down to the pit) and a hard-packed surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827]) (by the N corner of the room). (see sketch opposite).

In room 31, a floor ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_811]) below the final surface contemp[orary] w[ith] use of the hearth ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_800]) is uncovered. By the hearth is a patch of black hearth ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_825]) lying on an earlier surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_835]) -- contemp[orary] w[ith] first phase of hearth, or left

[p. 76: upper part of page: sketch top plan of layers in room 31 and section of layers in W wing; lower part of page: sketch of bottom of black-gloss plate with graffito; sketch of bone inlay plaque depicting upper part of Eros, measured but not to scale]

[p. 77]

8 July 2006 cont.

on surface before const[ruction] of hearth? The same surface also has a patch of black ash rich in hammerscale ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_829]) next to a fragmentary iron object ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3683]). Both ash patches are sampled (one for paleobot[anical remains], one for metallur[gical remains] ([ark_link smp=CH06SR_579])) and surface is removed. In the W wing, Sasha continues to remove the fill of the bedrock trench. Under the decayed bedrock 717 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_717]) was a layer of yellowish soil with bedrock bits ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_809]); under this are two layers, one light tan layer with no number [later assigned [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_844]] and one dark brown compact layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_828]). The latter seems to cover the former (see sketch opposite). From 828 comes the base of a black gloss plate with a graffito ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3685]) -- ligature of several letters (see sketch opposite).

In the courtyard, the upper yellow layer 759 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) is cleaned. In the N corner, it is covered by the same ashy grayish layer [possibly [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_755]?] that was visible in the initial sample trench. Along the SW wall (complex 1), it seems to run into a layer of more rubbly, rocky soil with bone fragments; this soil is looser, but of a similar color and it cannot initially be distinguished from 759.

More excavation in the church -- conservators work on plaster in the nave while Kathleen excavates disarticulated human remains in a layer of compact gray soil (final use surface?) in the apse ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]).

Day rained out at ca. 11-11:30am.

409 2006-07-08 21:32:11 2006-07-08 21:32:11 closed closed 08-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 10/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=412 Mon, 10 Jul 2006 21:33:29 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=412

I am working in the courtyard today to try to speed things up. That entry will be substantially more detailed than the others.

In the stenopos, Anton et al. finish removing the sandy light yellow fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_836]) under the thin layer of ash & reddish burnt soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_818]) that seems to form the earliest flat surface of the street. The sandy soil comes down onto irregular bedrock that seems to slope down to the N from the S on the SW side of the street, and in an irregular slope from the NE on the NE side of the street. It is difficult to imagine that this was an original Greek street surface, although there is Hellenistic material just over bedrock in the yellow fill. The box drain seems almost certainly to be medieval in date -- it sits on the bedrock edges of a cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_787]) presumably made at the same time.

In room 38, the hard-packed beaten-earth surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827]) in the NW side of the room begins to be excavated. Under it is a layer of rubbishy fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_840]) like that in the other filled rooms. A flotation sample from this layer produced<s> a bone carving of an eros with wings (see sketch opposite) [ed. note: this statement is incorrect; the bone eros ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3704]) came from flotation sample [ark_link smp=CH06SR_577] from a layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_819]) at the very bottom of the larger cut in the south part of the room]. Not yet any indication of layers in this area.

In room 31, in the E wing, further removal of surface under ash patches ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_835]). In the middle of the square of loose soil over which the stove was built, Dyma & co. find a tiny lamp set right-side up with traces of burning on the spout ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3696]). Under this floor there appears to be another surface w[ith] traces of black ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_842]) (but check current status w[ith] Dyma). In the W wing, Sasha continues to remove 828 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_828]); below it, above the light tan fill layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_844]), is a layer of grayish ashy soil with a larger proportion of charcoal [ed. note: later determined to be the same as 828; see entry for 11 July 2006].

[p.78: upper part of page: sketch top plan of layers in N end of courtyard; lower part of page: sketch top plan of layers in N end of room 38]

[p. 79]

10 July 2006 cont.

In the courtyard, 759 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) is fully removed, and the edge of the well cut ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_736]) is cleaned. The fill (?) of this cut is a brownish-black muddy soil, and I am assuming that it's material eroded into the cut over the winter (and therefore do not keep any material). The rain yesterday has also made the stratigraphic situation clearer along the NE side of the area -- there it becomes abundantly clear that the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_763]) was under-excavated initially, and that it is in fact not an irregular line but a perfectly regular trench ca. 40cm wide. Shawn and I remove the remaining fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_762]) and Allyson redraws her plan.  It is possible -- though not very likely -- that [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759] actually covered most of this trench fill, and that the portion excavated earlier was excavated out of phase where it sloped up against the wall. I think, however, that the layer was simply missed during excavation. In the same way, the rubbly concentration ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_837]) midway between the two section walls along the NE wall of the court can now clearly be seen to be the fill of a robbing trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_841]) which has removed some larger earlier wall. The cut itself seems to cut the lighter, harder yellow layer below 759 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) -- which is probably equivalent to the Early Byzantine use surface encountered in rm 37 and at the excavated NW end of the courtyard ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_715]). On the other side, there is a cut in decayed/clayey bedrock which probably represents not the robber trench but the original rock-cut foundation trench of the structure that may have been located here. Around the well there are also traces of straight edges that suggest a square enclosure or well-head at some point in time (see sketch opposite). I also remove the small piece of section at the junction between the early Byz[antine] wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_692]) over the slabs ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_666]) and what appears to be an earlier wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_944]) under the complex 1 wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_296]) -- there is an inside corner here, though we will have to clean the surface to see if there is a bond.

412 2006-07-10 21:33:29 2006-07-10 21:33:29 closed closed 10-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 courtyard early byzantine hellenistic Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 stenopos Trench notebooks 11/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=414 Tue, 11 Jul 2006 21:35:18 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=414

Work finished in stenopos -- Petya drawing both sections.

In room 38, a little confusion: several layers seem to be in play at different points in the NW side of the room, not nec[essarily] being excavated consecutively. In the W corner, the second fill layer [ed. note: despite confusion in excavation in this area, probably [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827]) seems to cover a more or less vertical layer of yellow clayey soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_838]) packed along the face of the bedrock wall -- a stone set in it suggests that it may be a facing for the cut, but it is partially excavated with the fill. The gray ashy layer near the door cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_839]) is also overexcavated with the fill above in this area, and a similar (?) soil filling a large cavity in the bedrock face is also excavated as that fill. Along the NE side of the NW part of the room, the situation is clearer -- the brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827]) comes down onto the continuation of the ashy soil in the doorway ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_839]), although with more clay and a more compact appearance. The gray soil seems to cover, on the other side, a very, very clear beaten-earth surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_847]) -- though this surface is also apparently under the fill that is currently being excavated in this area [ed. note: apparently [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_827] here too] (hence the general confusion). There are clearly a series of independent actions taking place on this side of the room, in contrast to the unitary fill on the other -- but it will be difficult to reconstruct their sequence & chronology at this point. (see sketch opposite).

[p. 80: blank]

[p. 81]

11 July 2006 cont.

In the E wing of rm 31, the early Byz[antine] floor ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_835]) is removed, revealing another floor ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_842]) with a stone construction ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_843]) on (?) it. This construction is not yet clear, but it involves a piece of vessel or pipe set concave-side down and open (flue?), and its surface seems to be at least partially covered with a thick, heavy, smooth white substance (bedrock or something else?). Another lamp ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3711]) found under the stove. In the W wing of room 31, Sasha contines to excavate fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_828]) -- he has decided that the gray ashy soil we observed yesterday was merely a lens or series of lenses, and *ALTHOUGH TODAY'S PALEOBOT[ANICAL] SAMPLES WERE FROM THAT ASHY PATCH, they have gone in as 828 as well. The material being removed in the NE end of the cut today is also being considered 828.

In the courtyard, the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_837]) of the robber trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_841]) across the SE end of the area now open is removed -- rocky brown soil full of bone and ceramics and a particularly large number of oyster shells. Although this fill is more or less consistent across the trench, and although on the E side it was certainly covered by the layer above across this area ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]), I still have doubts about the SW end. There were fragments of ceramic etc. much higher at this end than at the other, and in the section below the wall [of complex 1] it seems that part of the fill may in fact reach the area just below the 12th c. wall. To the N, however, the yellow above elsewhere also seems to cover this fill in the section -- so we should simply mention the possibility of contamination and the possibility that this trench is actually later than that upper yellow surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]). Once the fill is removed, we begin to remove the yellow early Byz[antine] occupation/abandonment layer 772 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]). On the SW side, it comes almost immediately down onto bedrock; on the NE side of the well, it is 20-25cm deep and comes down onto a lighter yellow soil with patches of medium-gray ash [ed. note: possibly [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_848]?]. The soil on the other side of the robber trench, above the decayed bedrock, is similar, although it may have some extra recent trample pressed into the surface. It is clear, however, that a small segment of the 12th c. foundation trench remains unexcavated. In it is a large piece of charcoal, which we take as a possible dating sample.

Anton et al. move to the church, where they continue to remove the gray soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) below the use level in the apse. This soil is full of disarticulated human bone, even below the altar support -- either this bone was kicked around during excavation and reexcavation of the tombs, or it and the bones in it were brought -- intentionally from another church or less intentionally from t. 5 -- from elsewhere & included in the construction material when the church was built.

414 2006-07-11 21:35:18 2006-07-11 21:35:18 closed closed 11-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 11th-12th century 2006 chapel courtyard early byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 12/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=417 Wed, 12 Jul 2006 21:37:35 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=417

In room 38, the next layer of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_840]) in the N corner is excavated and the yellow hard-pack ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_838]) is cleaned off the surface in the W corner. The gray ashy soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_839]) is determined to occupy only the area near the step, and to cover the second, grayer layer of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_840]) -- it is removed as well. The thick yellow clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_826]) is removed from around the construction ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_875]) in the bottom of the bedrock cut to the SE, and the stone covering ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_873]) is revealed

[p. 82: upper part of page: sketch of cuts in N part of courtyard; middle of page: sketch (not oriented to N) of burials under the floor of the church; bottom of page: sketch of bedrock cuts and structure in room 38]

[p. 83]

12 July 2006 cont.

for drawing. The clay contains some pottery and a number of tiles. It seems to have been laid deliberately to seal this area around the stones, although it is also present on the bedrock floor itself. It smells -- like manure or waste, though not quite so strong.

In room 31, E wing, excavation ceases temporarily to concentrate on the emptying of the W wing deposit (almost sterile, sandy soil and decayed bedrock with occasional Hellenistic ceramics) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_852]).

In the courtyard, the yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) over slabs & in cavities where slabs robbed is removed. On the SW side of the robber trench, the situation is different -- 762 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_762]) covered two more circular pits, the fills of which are now apparent & which are given new numbers. There may also be another pit under 772 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_772]) near the well, but needs to be investigated (see sketch opposite).

In the church, deep below floor level [in [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]] but without any obvious cut or grave outline, are two (and perhaps three) mostly complete depositions, lying with their heads to the W along the long axis of the church (see sketch opposite). The one nearest the main street is badly preserved, and its head seems to have been displaced; the one in the center seems not to have its head at all (both head ends seem to have been disturbed by the construction of tomb 2).

417 2006-07-12 21:37:35 2006-07-12 21:37:35 closed closed 12-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard hellenistic Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 13/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=420 Thu, 13 Jul 2006 21:40:58 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=420

Entry written after end of working day -- most of day spent in courtyard trying to get enough done for Chris Salter's work.

In room 38, the rest of the yellow packing clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_826]) is removed so that Allyson can draw the feature in the bottom of the cut. It appears that I removed this clay at the same time as a hard-packed brown soil underneath it -- probably an entirely different layer, rather than simply a lower level of sediment. Only a small patch in the N corner of the cut is left for levels and the taking of material separately ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_857]) -- but its original extent was more or less as in the sketch opposite, including a narrow band covered by clay along the lip of the feature (see sketch). On the NW side of the bedrock ridge, Lea thinks they might have reached a surface on the E side of the space -- but only part of the area is packed down, & that could simply be from trample during work. The rest looks very much like the soil that has been removed above -- a fairly moist, compact, clayey soil with yellow and gray inclusions, substantial amounts of charcoal, and a large quantity of pot & bone ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_840]). In troweling along the NE wall of the bedrock cut, I come across a very deep cavity ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_864]) filled with a much looser, loamy soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_863]) containing a number of Hellenistic sherds. This soil is given a separate context number; some is removed now, the rest will be removed when the level in the cut is lower. There is some confusion about the floor of the pit from last year ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_668]) -- levels suggest that it is 10cm above where they are now, and that the coin they found in the pedestal under the stone belongs to the tile collapse -- but this seems unlikely, since the tile collapse was well above the stone. Need to check documentation, esp[ecially] photos.

In room 31, work stops in the E wing to focus on the removal of the largely sterile tan soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_852]) with large white bedrock spalls filling the lower layer of the bedrock trench

[p. 84: full page sketch top plan of the cuts and layers in the whole courtyard; legend: "asterisks represent approximate concentrations of large slag/hearth floors"]

[p. 85]

13 July 2006 cont.

in the W wing. A bedrock floor covered by a thin layer of ashy gray and yellow clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_867]) appears in the NW end by the end of the day.

Note: some of the stones have fallen off the top of wall 399 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_399]), revealing what seems to be an actual face deep within what we have taken as the face. It may be that this wall was not in fact unnaturally wide, and what we understood as the inside face was actually articulated collapse from one or more of its courses.

In the courtyard, Ishan and I begin to remove the dark black to gray-brown ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_509]) that covers the entire SE half of the remaining unexcavated part of the courtyard. We focus on this area to provide C[hris] S[alter] with enough information to finish his work. The layer is much deeper to the E and SE, and it seems to cover both a compact very dark brown layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_884], probably also [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]) and a more pebbly, loamy medium-brown soil to the SW, towards the cistern and the wall of complex 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]). It varies in color from a dusty grayish-brown to almost pure black near the N corner of the cistern. We also remove a thin layer of pebbly, friable tan soil with some plaster content ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_858]) along the SE trench wall -- it seems to sit on top of the ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_509]), though in fact it may have sat on top of the dark brown ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_884]), as did the ash. Below the brown-gray-black soot in this area is also a layer containing a large amount of white mortar or plaster ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_885]). We collect a large quantity of small pieces of slag from the courtyard in this area, as well as four or five hearth bottoms, most of which were shot in with the total station and their point data put on their bags. This layer -- 509 as last year ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_509]) -- is particularly rich in various sorts of animal bones, as well as pottery.

On the other side of the section wall, the last of 782 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_782]) is cleaned, revealing even more pits ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_856], [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_862]). The potential pit near the well is a pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_854]), as is a larger pit in the 12th c. foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_860]) and a smaller, squarish pit at the corner of that trench & the robber trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_866]). One of these pits ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_860]) contains a large quantity of carbonized material ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_859]), which is sampled for flotation. Although all are circular -- some very much so -- these pits are of varying depths & forms (some shallow, some two-tiered [sketch of section of such pit] -- some with extra cuts at the bottom). They already seem to have been filled in by the Early Byzantine period. The proximity of several of these pits to the well suggests the following sequence: robbing of slabs ---> digging of pits ---> filling of pits & construction of Byzantine use surface ---> at the same time or later than the last, the construction of the well. (see sketch from memory opposite)

In the church, at least four articulated adult depositions can be identified. Most are in very bad shape (bone not well preserved, much more crumbly & easily disintegrated than bones in all tombs excavated to date), and all seem to be set on another, lower layer of disarticulated bones of both adults & children. Still unclear whether these skeletons were buried in the floor of the church or redeposited during construction from another resting place. The soil in the apse ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) is removed down to bedrock; disarticulated human skeletal material appears all the

[p. 86: upper part of page: sketch of plan of church with possible wall dividing apse from nave; middle and bottom of page: sketch of section and top plan of S part of courtyard, with labels]

[p. 87]

13 July 2006 cont.

[way] to the bottom. Under the interior reentrant angle between the apse and the "nave" of the church appears to be an earlier wall -- at first looked like deeper foundations for corners, but rest of apse rests on soil well above this level, and the visible and protruding stones seem very much to be arranged in two faces and in courses (see sketch opposite). At first Larissa thinks it could be for an earlier dividing wall between apse & nave, but too far below the lowest level of the foundation of the rest of the apse [ed. note: further excavation suggests that these are not the remains of the walls, but additional foundations for the base of the arch that would have marked the boundary of the apse].
