Because of Packard Lab inspection, switched Sunday off for today. No work.

423 2006-07-14 21:43:25 2006-07-14 21:43:25 closed closed 14-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 Rabinowitz Trench notebooks 15/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=426 Sat, 15 Jul 2006 21:44:12 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=426

Entry written on 17 July -- working in morning.

In room 38, 840 (fill) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_840]) continues to be removed -- no sign of a use surface equivalent to that on the W end of this side of the room. When Lea et al. draw even with the level of the floor surface of the pit, however, it becomes clear that the pit was not fully excavated in 2005 -- the line of the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_868])/cut clearly continues around its original extent, below the current level of 840. At the same time, the brown hard-pack below the yellow clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_826]) in the deeper pit is removed, and the remaining soil is removed from around the cover (?) stones over the cut in the floor of the cut [the previous sentence refers to the pit in the SE half of room 38].

In room <31a> [this must be an error for "31", W wing], the final layer of clayey fill/deposit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_867]) over the bedrock at the bottom of the rock-cut trench is removed -- this side of the room is complete.

In the courtyard, the final areas of the second section are cleaned. 509 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_509]) is removed from the third section, but there may have been some confusion here. Although 509 is the ashy soil familiar from 2005, it seems to have no particular boundary with the hard-pack at the NW end of this section -- just fades into it, and both are removed at the same time and as 509. It remains to be seen whether we will be able to differentiate between 509 and 752 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_752]), the number given to the upper soil in the 2nd section [of the courtyard]. Furthermore, a large ashy patch in the NW part of the third section has a deposit below 509 removed at the same time as 509, since it comes down onto black soil (which is serving as the layer indicator). I think that the stratigraphic situation is as sketched opposite, with 509/752 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_752]) covering a deposit of gray-brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_876]) which in turn covers more ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]). In addition, a wall (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_922]) is also uncovered along the SW side of the third section; to the NW of this series of three stones is a patch of white hearth ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_882]). We initially think there is a border along the NE side, too, but this turns out to be only one stone that soon comes loose. This feature is clearly cut by what seems to be the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_943]) of the NE wall of complex 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_296]); on either side of it are patches of harder brown or brownish-yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_929]) (see sketch opposite).

[p. 88: upper part of the page: sketch of the structure at the bottom of the bedrock cut in the S half of room 38; lower part of the page: plan of complex 2 with the location of the "room 31 probe" indicated]

[p. 89]

15 July 2006 cont.

In the chapel, depositions beneath the floor ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) continue to be excavated. Several rest directly on bedrock; others are clearly cut by tomb 1, from below the side of which their legs protrude. One of the latter may belong to the skull that was found above at the corner of tomb 1.

426 2006-07-15 21:44:12 2006-07-15 21:44:12 closed closed 15-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 16/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=428 Sun, 16 Jul 2006 21:46:05 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=428

Again, entry written on following day -- things getting busy.

In room 38, the final layers of fill in the odd cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_874]) in the bottom of the large cut on the SE side of the room are removed. This fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_819]) is wet, directly over yellow clay ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_826]) that seems to form part of the natural clay seam Dyma encountered in the well [in the courtyard in 2005]. Under the lower parts of the stone slabs over this cut is a roughly circular arrangement of tiles and small stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_875]), also set into yellow clay beneath brown fill. This structure was photographed & photomodelled but not drawn (see sketch opposite). On the other side of the bedrock ridge, the actual bottom of the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_601]) is cleaned -- now all visible layers in that area (except the beaten-earth floor ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_847])) are the same tan-greenish clayey fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_879]).

In room 31, E wing, surface 872 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_872]) is excavated -- it is the surface on which the last two clay & stone constructions stand, and it also includes fill to a depth of ca. 30cm (floor surface beaten into or trampled onto upper layer of fill).

Sasha begins excavation of what we will call "rm 31 probe" -- essentially a wall-chasing trench ca. 1.5m wide just over & to the NW of the line of the SW wall of room 38, extending ca. 4m to the NW. We are attempting to locate the other side of room 31, in an area where we know the archaeological deposit is thin (and mainly composed of rubble). See sketch opposite.

In the courtyard, the gray-brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_876]) over the ash patch ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]) is removed and the ash patch itself is cleaned for photos & documentation. The rest of section 2 is also fully cleaned for photography.

In the church, the last layer of depositions ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) is removed & the bedrock is cleaned. This cleaning reveals the outline of a cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_902]) in the bedrock floor itself, above which there is a patch of burnt soil & charcoal that Anton identifies as a hearth (?)([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_881]). We also open the deposit of human bones from the area of the wall of the chapel & the street (located in 2002 but not excavated) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_911]). The 2002 fill is removed.

428 2006-07-16 21:46:05 2006-07-16 21:46:05 closed closed 16-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 31 room 31 probe room 38 Trench notebooks 17/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=431 Mon, 17 Jul 2006 21:47:53 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=431

In room 38, final removal of circular structure ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_875]) in hole in large cut, cleaning of remaining brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_821]) (also found under tiles & stone of this construction . Work now concentrates on fill on other side of bedrock ridge, now that rest of pit removed -- beaten-earth floor on SW end of area removed, work begins on the uniform layer of fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_879]) now exposed (though exposed in a not-particularly-chronological manner). Finds include a bronze bell ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3838]) & a group of stones mortared together (saved as an architectural sample).

In rm 31, E wing, bedrock reached. Dyma separates layer above ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_872]) as another context, since slightly more compact. That context covers two more circular pits ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_889], [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_892]) in the bedrock floor of this room. In the room 31 probe, the line of the SW wall of rm 38 is found, and excavation spills in a slightly

[p. 90: blank]

[p. 91]

17 July 2006 cont.

irregular manner over the wall to its NE side. Material being removed is largely modern (glass, bottles, etc.). ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_898])

In the courtyard, the ash patch ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]) is now clearly circular and when removal begins, it becomes clear that the ash fills a regular pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_897]). In terms of sequence, this will be removed (comes down onto a clear tan compact soil), followed by the fine dark-brown-gray layer to the SE, followed by the construction trench for the wall of complex 1.

In the chapel, the hearth area ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_881]) is removed and work begins on the wall between the church & the street ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_911]). The presence of human remains in and around that wall fill suggest that the wall had already been destroyed when the remains were deposited in the street. The fill of the bedrock cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_902]) in the center of the church also begins to be removed. Most of the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_894]) is a hard gray-brown soil, but along the NW wall of the church there is a very distinct layer of yellow soil filling a roughly rectangular area between the corner of the apse & the wall of tomb 1.

431 2006-07-17 21:47:53 2006-07-17 21:47:53 closed closed 17-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 18/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=434 Tue, 18 Jul 2006 21:49:13 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=434

In room 38, work continues on the removal of the yellow-brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_879]) in the NW half of the room. Along the SW wall, Dyma M. thinks the fill is slightly different, but it looks very similar to me -- just less compact, as is usual at the edges of the fills in this room. On the other hand, in this area, an initial removal of another 10cm exposes a smoother, grayer, ashier soil with much less material, at least in the S corner (possibly [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_908]). It is difficult to say whether this is a different layer -- things are moving slowly today and very little was exposed. On the other side of the ridge, Emily removes the material from the second of the two bedrock (semi-)circular cuts ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_901]). Below the millstone ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3843]) and a thick layer of brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_890]) is what appears to be a surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_895]), on top of which sit a coin ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3866]) and a fragments of marble architectural decoration (from a window frame or iconostasis?) ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3845]; [ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3846]).

In room 31, the last soil is removed from the two circular pits ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_889], [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_892]) at the bottom of the larger bedrock cut in the E wing. In the probe, the line of a wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_946]) is followed, extending out from the W corner of room 38 -- but it seems not to be quite in a line with that wall, and I wonder if it doesn't indicate another seam between complexes.

In the courtyard (third section), the situation is both slightly clearer & slightly more confusing. On the one hand, the black ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]) clearly fills two conjoined cuts, one a large oval & the other a smaller circle ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_897]) -- both cut through a light tan-yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) and come down onto (decayed?) bedrock. Another pit -- a rectangle with a circle at its W corner -- is identified in the E corner of the area ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_905]); it too is filled with black ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_896]). This pit, like the smaller part of the other pit, is covered by the dark brown soft powdery soil that occupied most of the E quarter of the area ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_884]). This soil also covers a hard tan soil to the NE ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) and a crumbly, pebbly brown soil to the SW ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]). The foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_943]) of

[p. 92: middle of page: sketch plan of cuts in courtyard surfaces; bottom of page: sketch plan of cuts in bedrock in N half of room 38]

[p. 93]

18 July 2006 cont.

the NE wall of complex 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_296]) is also excavated -- it is a very shallow and fairly narrow cut with an irregular bottom and a variable width. Although it is unconvincing as a foundation trench, the wall (itself founded not on large stones set flat but on medium-large irregular stones set upright at a slight angle) does not go below its bottom, and therefore our identification is probably correct. See sketch opposite (from memory at end of day). There may also be yet another cut (or shallow depression) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_904]) with an ashy, trashy fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_899]) along the middle of the NE section wall -- this may in fact match an ashy patch ([ark_link cxt=CH05SR_576]) found on the other side of that [section] wall last year.

In the church, still some confusion over remains in area of street wall and in apparent pit in the street ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_936]). Edges of that pit are indeterminate, since street surface has been trampled, baked and hardened for four years -- but one side is lined with/filled with a very white mortar/concrete with large stones, and we wonder if the intrusion might be modern.  In the center of the church is a large cut in the bedrock, apparently a circular pit attached to a larger, square (?) cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_902]). We begin to remove the fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) between the tombs today -- the bedrock level is quickly found at the end, but there are three skulls and disarticulated material between that end & the end closer to the apse. Ishan finds four coins from the area between the foot of the tombs in the sieve ([ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3872], [ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3873], [ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3875], [ark_link sfi=CH06SR_3885]).

434 2006-07-18 21:49:13 2006-07-18 21:49:13 closed closed 18-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard plateia Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 19/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=437 Wed, 19 Jul 2006 21:50:22 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=437

In room 38, ongoing excavation of yellow-brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_879]). In the SW part of the NW part of the room, there is a very hard & smooth layer of clayey yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_908]) that seems to be close to bedrock. This soil seems to have an edge against a more friable, softer, slightly grayer yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_906]), and the edge seems to be shared with the bedrock beneath. The most reasonable explanation seems to be that the grayer soil fills a cut in the smoother soil and the bedrock. This fill seems to be cut in turn by another cut -- roughly squarish -- at the N corner of the room, which is filled yet again by a fairly similar soil (a moist clayey loam with lots of pottery and bone, as well as charcoal and clay lumps) that is distinct primarily in its color (browner) and compaction (looser) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_910]). The bedrock appears to be much lower on this side. (see sketch opposite)

In the room 31 probe more confusing information -- the large wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_946]) slightly off line with the SW wall of 38 ([ark_link cxt=CH04SR_264]) is abutted (?) at its NW end by another wall that shows the sleeper-beam slot [ed. note: this section of wall was not assigned a separate number in the field]. This wall follows the same line to the NW -- still no sign of a crosswall to close room 31.

In the courtyard, obvious pits emptied; apparent collapse (?) or pile of 10th c. tile ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_915]) along the edge of the foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_943]) cleaned while brown pebbly soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]) is removed. Tan-yellow soil in N corner (759?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) also removed, seems to go down to bedrock -- but in this area we dig below the level of the three wall-stones ([ark_link cxt=Ch06SR_916]) left here, which now sit on an earth balk, without identifying a contemporary surface or

[p. 94: middle of page: sketch plan of cuts and findspots of objects in church; text below above and below sketch]

find 15: Ae coin: from sieve

find 6: Ae coin: 17cm from NE wall, 96cm from NW wall: 35cm below lip of NE wall

find 7: Ae coin: from sieve

find 1: astragalos -- 28cm from NE wall of cut, 92cm from SW wall, ca. 35cm below lip of cut on NE side

find 2: frag of marble revetment -- 7cm from NE wall, 50cm from NW wall, 37cm below NE lip

find 3: Ae coin -- 54cm from NE wall, 23cm from NW wall, 81cm below biggest rock in NW wall of church above ([level marker])

find 4: pc marble revetment: 91.5cm from NE wall, 96cm from NW wall, 68cm below edge of T 1 between 2 big stones

[p. 95]

19 July 2006 cont.

a wall trench. I think this means we missed a use surface -- the wall is very similar in construction to the other Early Byz[antine] walls in this area, and all of those sat directly on the surface present when they were built. At a later date these walls were partially covered by the accumulation of interior & exterior surfaces -- but we don't have the surface to associate with the initial construction. It's also a bit unclear what is going on to the S of the line of wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_922]) and patch of white hearth ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_882]) -- there is a somewhat tenuous line of stones along the edge of the foundation trench, and then what seems to be quite a deep deposit of the pebbly brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]) (I think Shawn may have associated this soil with 759 at the N corner, so we may be dealing with only one context at this point).

In the church, the rest of the material ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) between the tombs is cleared and the cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_923]) -- perhaps for the construction of tomb 1 -- is emptied. This leaves the square cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_920]) on the NW side of the area in front of the apse; Anton has taken down at least one level ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_903]), but the hard yellow-brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_907]) continues to descend. We're going to return in the afternoon to finish it. [the notes on the facing page represent an attempt to record findspots during after-hours excavation when the total station was no longer set up; all of them are associated with [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_907]]

437 2006-07-19 21:50:22 2006-07-19 21:50:22 closed closed 19-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard early byzantine Rabinowitz room 31 room 38 Trench notebooks 07/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=632 Fri, 07 Jul 2006 17:00:00 +0000 arabinow http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=632

[p. 74: upper part of page: sketch profile of neck and rim of amphora with retrograde stamp: Χαριτη[; lower part of page: sketch top plan of layers in N part of room 38]

[p. 75]

In the road, the bright yellow clay fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_803]) under the lowest surface continues to be excavated. It seems to come down onto bedrock, although there are also various large, loose stones set into it.

In room 38, the fill finally seems to come down on a yellow clayey surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_826]). The rocks ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_820]) in the W corner with the void beneath them seem to be set flat, deliberately, and therefore now form part of a structure rather than a fill. On the other side of the bedrock ridge, the odd deposit of charcoal and yellow mineral (potassium sulfate?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_831]) is cleaned and the rest of 606 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_606]) removed on both sides of the pit.

In the W wing of rm 31, Sasha continues to remove 809 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_809]), the layer of yellow fill with bedrock crumble. Many amphora fragments emerge, including another stamped frag, this one a rim, perhaps also local (see sketch opposite). In the E wing of room 31, the Early Byz[antine] stove/hearth ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_795]) is fully uncovered; on its surface is a round spot of burnt red soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_814]) and gray ash ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_812]) which is given a separate number and then removed.

In room 38, the cleaning at the bottom reveals a gap between the two flat pavers/covers ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_820]) -- in the gap the brown fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_785]) continues, but the stones and ceramics have a black encrustation that we initially took as an indication of burning (looked like the black encrustation on stones from well in courtyard). Gordana and Chris Salter, however, indicate that such encrustation is a product of being exposed to the water table -- either a sulfate-reducing bacteria (Gordana) or manganese leaching out onto the objects (Chris). The bottom of this area seems to be below the water table -- it is filled with a gray clayey mud ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_821]), and water actively begins to creep into it as we dig.

In the courtyard, the yellow layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) is cleaned, and in its surface are found to be many intrusions -- a circular hole/pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_834]) near the well that seems to represent a tree or bush (root voids still visible acc[ording] to Shawn); a large rectangular cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_822]) in the center of the layer that disappears under the section, shallow & filled only with the layer above; and a long narrow cut that also disappears under the section but seems to be filled with a different material [ed. note: unidentified, not noted in Marceaux daybook].

http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=439 Thu, 20 Jul 2006 21:51:58 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=439

Entry written on 7/21. Work ceased around break time for the lab opening celebration.

In room 38, brown clayey fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_910]) at NE end of room continues; along the NW side is a harder, yellower outcrop ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_921]) that may represent the edge of the cut (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_909]) this material fills.

In the courtyard, ongoing removal of brown pebbly soil in S corner of section 3 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]). It covers bedrock in places and in others a hard yellow soil over bedrock [ed. note: it is not clear what layer this refers to; either this layer was not recorded separately, or it is confusion with [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_914]]. It also seems to cover a more compact gray soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_929]) in the S corner, where it comes up against a pile of stones & rubble that may be the remains of another wall ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_922]). A small area of 759 (?) ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_759]) that remained along the section wall b[e]tw[een] second & third sections is also removed, revealing another segment of wall at right angles to & bonded with the three-stone wall already identified ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_916]).

In the church, human remains are excavated from the fill of the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_936]) in the street. Along the church wall, the edge seems to be cut in bedrock; another edge is defined by the patch of mortar, which Yulia Strilenko thinks is not modern; and the other two edges remain unclear. The fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_907]) in the bedrock cut in the center of the nave continues, and this and the fill (still [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_798]) of a very distinct cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_923]) along the wall of t. 1 continue to be excavated.

439 2006-07-20 21:51:58 2006-07-20 21:51:58 closed closed 20-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard Rabinowitz room 38 Trench notebooks 21/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=441 Fri, 21 Jul 2006 21:53:08 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=441

Entry written on 7/23 -- on both 21st & 22nd I spent the whole working day digging.

In room 38, the brown-yellow fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_910]) in the NE end of the pit to the NW continues to be removed. It comes down to bedrock without any particular change in character or consistency; the bedrock floor itself is very smooth. Although the limits are difficult to find, there does seem to be an edge along the NW wall of the cut in the area of the late Byz[antine]

[p. 96: upper part of the page: sketch plan of layers in cut in N side of room 38; middle of page: sketch of NE section wall of courtyard; bottom part of page: sketch plan of layers and walls in courtyard]

[p. 97]

21 July 2006 cont.

pit in this area. The soil here ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_921]) is denser, yellower, and more compact. The finds, however, are similar -- a lot of Hellenistic residual material mixed with quantities of animal bone and Late R[o]m[a]n - Early Byz[antine] ceramics. It is possible that we overcut the yellow layer during the excavation of the browner soil, but in the profile streaks of yellow seem to be interwoven with streaks of brown, and it may also be that this layer is not an earlier fill cut at a later period, with that later cut then filled, but simply an area of generally mixed fill with a slightly different character (see sketch opposite).

In the courtyard, further excavation makes the situation a bit clearer. The yellow, fairly compact soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_782]?) between the wall fragment & the section in the N part of the trench is removed, but I think it is removed together with an earlier surface in phase with the wall itself. We hope to establish this in the section. It becomes clear that the pebbly brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]) exists in an area that is roughly a quarter-circle expanding out from the cistern; that it is covered by the layer of soil with white bedrock chunks along the SE side of the trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_885]); and that it covers in turn 1) a pile of small-medium stone rubble running in a fairly well-defined line along the wall of complex 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_929]); 2) the fill of the very large pit in the center of the courtyard [ed. note: this seems to refer to [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877], but if so the database and GIS suggest that the statement is incorrect and the relationship between the two is not direct]; and 3) the fill of two smaller pits, one under the stone rubble at the S corner ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_927]) and the other -- with 3 hearth floors -- in the center of the courtyard near the SE side ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_925]) [ed. note: this statement also seems to be partially incorrect, since it was later determined that 925 was (also?) covered by [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_914], which was also determined to cover 883]. This suggests to me that the brown pebbly soil is contemporary with the early phase of Late Byz[antine] activity in the courtyard -- but we'll wait for the ceramics results. On the other side of the other small wall stub ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_922]) (along the wall of complex 1), the pile of tiles & pithos frags ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_915]) are found to cover the gray ash layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_882]), which in turn covers what appears to be a relatively smooth use surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_782]). This use surface exists mainly along the SW side of the area, and it also seems to cover the fill of the large pit in the center and the pile of small-stone rubble along the same wall [ed. note: the relationship between the smooth surface ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_782]), the upper layer of ash above the large center pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_877]), the pebbly brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]), and the rubble fill ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_929]) was not established in a satisfactory manner during excavation; both 782 and 877 appear in the database as covering the fill of the large pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_912]), but the relationship between the two was not identified]. The situation here is extremely confusing, but some relative sequences can now be worked out (see sketch opposite).

In the church, final excavation of pit in bedrock under nave ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_920], fill [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_907]), trench along wall of t. 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_923]); ongoing excavation of human remains in pit in street ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_936]). The edges of this pit still have not been defined, and the human remains continue much deeper. An area of mortar projecting at the upper SW edge of this cut seems to continue below, as if the pit had been lined with this mortar deliberately. Still not clear when this intrusion happened, since no modern finds indicate recent disturbance.

441 2006-07-21 21:53:08 2006-07-21 21:53:08 closed closed 21-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 byzantine chapel courtyard hellenistic late byzantine Rabinowitz roman room 38 Trench notebooks 22/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=444 Sat, 22 Jul 2006 21:54:34 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=444

In room 38, the bedrock floor at the NE end of the cut along the NW wall is more or less cleaned, and sections are straightened in this area. We then begin to remove the area of denser yellower soil along the NW section & between the NE & SW ends of the cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_921]). This soil, too, seems to cover a layer of abandonment/accumulation (??) over the bedrock floor of the cut [NB: I cannot now remember

[p. 98: upper part of page: sketch plan of bedrock and cuts in N part of room 38; middle of page: sketch of section along and under NW wall of room 38]

[p. 99]

22 July 2006 cont

if the layer over the floor was under this section or under the edge of the brown fill, or both -- need to check photos, section, and L[ea] C[line]'s documentation]. Material in this fill seems similar to the material in the fill removed previously ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_910]). When this fill has been removed, the ashy yellow soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_908]) above the bedrock ledge at the SW end of the cut is cleaned & documented; it seems to preserve evidence of burning or ash in several places, as well as at least one large fragment of a mortarium lying face-down on the surface. When this layer is excavated, we begin to notice that it is full of very tiny fish bones -- at least three float samples are taken, so it'll be necessary to get these results to the fish people.

This layer comes directly down to bedrock (it's 7-12cm thick); I notice that just on the surface of the bedrock there seems to be some ash/evidence of burning. When fully cleared, the cut has a ledge about 1/3 of the way from the SW wall, with very smooth bedrock surfaces on both sides -- the one to the NE is about 1m-1.2m lower than the one to the SW. If the section wall to the SW is reliable, the higher part of the cut preserves the same NW wall as the trench in 31 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_725]), but that wall disappears at the line of the ledge (see sketch opposite).

In the courtyard, the situation is increasingly complex. The pit in the center of the courtyard ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_913]) begins to be emptied, as the last of the pebbly soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_883]) is removed from the rest of the trench. It is filled by a layer of brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_912]), that in turn covers a lens<e> of white ash in its W corner ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_917]); this ash covers a hard, dark, clayey gray-brown soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_918]) that fills the rest of the pit down to bedrock -- though there is some distinction in its lower layers, where it becomes increasingly clayey. There is also a lens or an interface of small crushed shell at a certain point in the W corner of this layer, but I will have to check w[ith] Shawn for its exact position. The clayey layer -- the lower parts of which increasingly have the aspect of burnt mudbrick -- covers an irregular structure of medium-sized stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_934]) that appears to have been built deliberately in the square part of this pit. Some mortar is visible between these stones; a sample is taken for Yulia Strylenko. The stones seem to form a transverse wall and a small circular wall (see sketch opposite [actually on following page]), and it is possible that some of the (burnt?) clay around them served either as facing for the wall or for a mudbrick superstructure. There are a large number of shells in this layer ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_918]), and both the shells and the stone have a bright white, somewhat powdery surface (calcinated?). At the S end of the pit, the bedrock cut is slightly higher, with a (posthole?) cut in its S corner. At the E corner is another large, round cut ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_931], filled by [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_930]) partially in the bedrock and partially -- it appears -- in the fill of the square cut (& hence later). Part of the bottom of this cut is in a hard, bedrock-like material, but this may simply be a product of the way it was cut into the fill (alternatively, it is possible that the two cuts were made at the same time).

In the church, Anton continues to excavate the pit full of human bones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_936]). Its edge to the SW has not been clearly established. It is very deep and goes down to bedrock, cutting the bedrock on the NE side.

444 2006-07-22 21:54:34 2006-07-22 21:54:34 closed closed 22-7-06 private 0 0 post 0 2006 chapel courtyard Rabinowitz room 38 Trench notebooks 24/7/06 http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=448 Mon, 24 Jul 2006 21:57:00 +0000 prichett_r http://chersonesos.la.utexas.edu/?p=448

[p. 100: upper two-thirds of the page: sketch plan of the cuts and wall remains in the courtyard]

[p. 101]

[at top of page, after date: "(entry written one day late)"]

Last half-day of excavation -- attempt to clear courtyard. Final removal of fill in central pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_918]); also includes removal of clay/decayed bedrock [ed. note: not assigned a number during excavation] that appears to fill the narrow rectilinear cut that approaches the main square cut [ed. note: see GIS for position]. This particular task is somewhat confusing: although the orange-tan clay does seem to fill a cut in the bedrock, it also has very irregular borders AND, most importantly, seems to be part of the material cut by the wide foundation trench ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_841]) of the robbed wall. If this reading of the stratigraphy is accurate, it creates serious issues for phasing, especially since the mortar in the wall in the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_934]) seems to be non-Roman (чемянка, small gravel matrix, isn't characteristic). The cut appears to continue up to the foundation trench, but could have been overexcavated.

Along the wall of complex 1, we remove the pile of small-small/medium stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_929]) on both sides of the earlier wall-stub ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_922]). To the S, they are simply a layer of stones in brown soil that covers a clean layer of compact, slightly darker soil ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_927]) -- the other part of the fill of the pit ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_928]) next to the cistern. This is excavated completely, with the bedrock lip visible on the other side. To the NW of the wall stub, however, there are two different situations. Immediately next to it, the loose stones cover a sandy tan-brown fill, also with some small stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_933]); this fill is located in a shallow, roughly rectangular depression with its long axis parallel to the wall of complex 1 ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_942]). As one moves along this cut/depression to the NW, however, the stone packing becomes more dense and, in its lowest levels, seems actually to be mortared together. I think that these mortared stones ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_932]) are the remains of a wall, perhaps a small wall associated with the functioning of the square cut, or the very tenuous remains of an earlier structure in this area [ed. note: while the feature is not documented in the notebook, the two fills in this area -- 929 and 933 -- also covered what was interpreted as a single poorly-preserved mudbrick or clay packing ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_935]) at the bottom of the cut]. Finally, cleaning of the courtyard reveals one last small, circular cut -- again, perhaps a posthole ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_945]) (see sketch opposite).

The pit outside the church ([ark_link cxt=CH06SR_936], filled by [ark_link cxt=CH06SR_938]) is still not finished -- several bones are visible in the current wall.

Pictures are taken from the crane today -- some will be used for a general photomodel attempt.
